options.optionA: A. The baked goods retailer wins because mutuality of obligation was lacking in that the baked goods retailer made no express promise to buy any of the pastry company's baked buns.
options.optionB: B. The baked goods retailer wins because the agreement was void for indefiniteness of quantity and total price for the year involved.
options.optionC: C. The pastry company wins because the baked goods retailer's promise to sell at retail the pastry company's baked buns exclusively if it sold any such buns at all implied a promise to use its best efforts to sell the pastry company's one-year output of baked buns.
options.optionD: D. The pastry company wins because under applicable law both parties to a sale-of-goods contract impliedly assume the risk of price and demand fluctuations.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Exclusive dealing contracts under the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC), including the implied obligations of sellers and buyers regarding supply and promotion of goods.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The pastry company and the baked goods retailer entered a written agreement for the exclusive supply and sale of baked buns for one year. After signing the contract, the baked goods retailer renounced the agreement due to a sudden decline in customer demand.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under the UCC, exclusive dealing contracts imply an obligation on the part of the seller to use best efforts to supply the good and an obligation on the part of the buyer to use its best efforts to promote the good's sale. This obligation extends to the duration of the contract, regardless of changes in market demand.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the implied obligation of the baked goods retailer to use its best efforts to promote the sale of the pastry company's buns, the court will likely rule in favor of the pastry company, supporting option C.

question: Under a written agreement a pastry company promised to sell its entire output of baked buns at a specified unit price to a baked goods retailer for one year. The baked goods retailer promised not to sell any other supplier's baked buns. The parties' contract included a provision for termination by either party at any time upon reasonable notice. After six months of performance on both sides the pastry company claiming that its old bun-baker had become uneconomical and that it could not afford a new one dismantled the bun-baker and began using the space for making dog biscuits. The pastry company's output of baked buns having ceased the baked goods retailer sued for breach of contract. The baked goods retailer moves for summary judgment on liability and the pastry company moves for summary judgment of dismissal. Which of the following should the court rule?

options.optionA: A. Summary judgment for the baked goods retailer because as a matter of law the pastry company could not discontinue production of baked buns merely because it was losing money on that product.
options.optionB: B. Summary judgment for the pastry company because its cessation of baked-bun production and the baked goods retailer's awareness thereof amounted as a matter of law to valid notice of termination as permitted by the contract.
options.optionC: C. Both motions denied because there are triable issues of fact as to whether the the pastry company gave reasonable notice of termination or whether its losses from continued production of baked buns were sufficiently substantial to justify cessation of production.
options.optionD: D. Both motions denied because the pastry company may legally cease production of baked buns but under the circumstances it must share with the baked goods retailer its profits from the manufacture of dog biscuits until the end of the first year.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Good faith performance of a contract under the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC), specifically with regards to a quantity term measured by the seller's output.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The pastry company ceased production of baked buns, allegedly due to the old bun-baker becoming uneconomical, and began manufacturing dog biscuits instead. The contract allowed termination upon reasonable notice, but the issue is whether the pastry company's discontinuation of bun production was made in good faith.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under the UCC, a seller's output is determined by its actual good faith output. If a seller reduces or discontinues production, it must do so in good faith, rather than to avoid contractual obligations. The court must determine whether the pastry company's decision to stop making buns was made in good faith or not.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Since there is a question of fact regarding the pastry company's good faith in discontinuing bun production, both motions for summary judgment should be denied, supporting option C.

question: On July 18 a shovel manufacturer received an order for the purchase of 500 snow shovels from a wholesaler. The wholesaler had mailed the purchase order on July 15. The order required shipment of the shovels no earlier than September 15 and no later than October 15. Typed conspicuously across the front of the order form was the following: "[the wholesaler] reserves the right to cancel this order at any time before September 1." The manufacturer's mailed response saying "We accept your order" was received by the wholesaler on July 21. As of July 22 which of the following is an accurate statement as to whether a contract was formed?

options.optionA: A. No contract was formed because of the wholesaler's reservation of the right to cancel.
options.optionB: B. No contract was formed because the wholesaler's order was only a revocable offer.
options.optionC: C. A contract was formed but prior to September 1 it was terminable at the will of either party.
options.optionD: D. A contract was formed but prior to September 1 it was an option contract terminable only at the will of the wholesaler.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Formation of a contract, particularly the concept of illusory promises and unconditional reservation of rights, and its impact on the enforceability of a contract.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The wholesaler submitted a purchase order for 500 snow shovels with specific shipment dates, and reserved the right to cancel the order at any time before September 1, while the manufacturer accepted the order on July 21.
explanation.Rule_Application: A promise that unconditionally reserves the right of alternative performances, such as cancellation, is an illusory promise and does not constitute valid consideration for a return promise. Thus, the wholesaler's reservation of the right to cancel the order prior to September 1 makes their promise to purchase the shovels unenforceable.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: As of July 22, no contract was formed between the parties due to the wholesaler's illusory promise, supporting option A.

question: On July 18 a shovel manufacturer received an order for the purchase of 500 snow shovels from a wholesaler. The wholesaler had mailed the purchase order on July 15. The order required shipment of the shovels no earlier than September 15 and no later than October 15. Typed conspicuously across the front of the order form was the following: "[the wholesaler] reserves the right to cancel this order at any time before September 1." The manufacturer's mailed response saying "We accept your order" was received by the wholesaler on July 21. The wholesaler did not cancel the order and the manufacturer shipped the shovels to the wholesaler on September 15. When the shovels conforming to the order in all respects arrived on October 10 the wholesaler refused to accept them. Which of the following is an accurate statement as of October 10 after the wholesaler rejected the shovels?

options.optionA: A. The wholesaler's order for the shovels even if initially illusory became a binding promise to accept and pay for them.
options.optionB: B. The wholesaler's order was an offer that became an option after shipment by the manufacturer.
options.optionC: C. The wholesaler's right to cancel was a condition subsequent the failure of which resulted in an enforceable contract.
options.optionD: D. In view of the wholesaler's right to cancel its order prior to September 1 the shipment of the shovels on September 15 was only an offer by the manufacturer.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Illusory promise and consideration in contract law, particularly when a promise becomes enforceable after the specified period for cancellation has passed.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The wholesaler ordered 500 snow shovels from the manufacturer with the condition to ship between September 15 and October 15, while reserving the right to cancel the order before September 1. The manufacturer accepted the order and shipped the shovels on September 15. The wholesaler refused to accept the shovels upon arrival on October 10.
explanation.Rule_Application: An illusory promise becomes consideration once the specified period for cancellation has passed. In this case, the wholesaler’s right to cancel expired on September 1, making the order a binding promise to accept and pay for the shovels.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: As of October 10, the wholesaler’s order became a binding promise to accept and pay for the shovels, and the correct statement is option A.

question: A high-volume pleasure-boat retailer entered into with a boater a written contract signed by both parties to sell the boater a power boat for $12000. The manufacturer's price of the boat delivered to the retailer was $9500. As the contract provided the boater paid the retailer $4000 in advance and promised to pay the full balance upon delivery of the boat. The contract contained no provision for liquidated damages. Prior to the agreed delivery date the boater notified the retailer that he would be financially unable to conclude the purchase; the retailer thereupon resold the same boat that the boater had ordered to a third person for $12000. If the boater sues the retailer for restitution of the $4000 advance payment which of the following should the court decide?

options.optionA: A. The boater's claim should be denied because as the party in default he is deemed to have lost any right to restitution of a benefit conferred on the retailer.
options.optionB: B. The boater's claim should be denied because but for his repudiation the retailer would have made a profit on two boat-sales instead of one.
options.optionC: C. The boater's claim should be upheld in the amount of $4000 minus the amount of the retailer's lost profit under its contract with the boater.
options.optionD: D. The boater's claims should be upheld in the amount of $3500 ($4000 minus $500 as statutory damages under the UCC).

explanation.Legal_Concept: Restitution of downpayment under the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) in cases of buyer's breach of contract
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The boater breached the contract by notifying the retailer of inability to pay the full balance, the retailer resold the same boat to a third person for $12,000, and the contract had no provision for liquidated damages
explanation.Rule_Application: The UCC allows a breaching buyer a limited right to restitution of a downpayment minus the seller's lost profit due to the breach
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The boater should be entitled to restitution of the $4,000 advance payment minus the amount of the retailer's lost profit under its contract with the boater, supporting option C

question: A developer needing a water well on one of his projects met several times about the matter with a well driller. Subsequently the well driller sent a developer an unsigned typewritten form captioned "WELL DRILLING PROPOSAL" and stating various terms the two had discussed but not agreed upon including a "proposed price of $5000." The form concluded "This proposal will not become a contract until signed by you [the developer] and then returned to and signed by me [the well driller]." The developer signed the form and returned it to the well driller who neglected to sign it but promptly began drilling the well at the proposed site on the developer's project. After drilling for two days the well driller told the developer during one of the developer's daily visits that he would not finish unless the developer would agree to pay twice the price recited in the written proposal. The developer refused the well driller quit and the developer hired substitute to drill the well to completion for a price of $7500. In an action by the developer against the well driller for damages which of the following is the probable decision?

options.optionA: A. The developer wins because his signing of the well driller's form constituted an acceptance of an offer by the well driller.
options.optionB: B. The developer wins because the well driller's commencement of performance constituted an acceptance by the well driller of an offer by the developer and an implied promise by the well driller to complete the well.
options.optionC: C. The well driller wins because he never signed the proposal as required by its terms.
options.optionD: D. The well driller wins because his commencement of performance merely prevented the developer from revoking his offer made on a form supplied by the well driller and did not obligate the well driller to complete the well.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Formation of contracts, particularly the distinction between an offer and an acceptance, as well as the implications of commencement of performance.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The well driller sent an unsigned proposal to the developer, outlining terms including a proposed price, and specifying that the proposal would not become a contract until signed by both parties. The developer signed the form and returned it, but the well driller did not sign it. Nonetheless, the well driller began drilling the well, only to later demand a higher price and quit when refused.
explanation.Rule_Application: Since the form sent by the well driller did not constitute an offer, but rather a proposal, the developer’s signing of the form became an offer that the well driller could accept. By commencing performance, the well driller manifested assent and implicitly agreed to complete the well, creating a contract. The well driller’s subsequent demand for a higher price and quitting the project breached this implied contract.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The probable decision is that the developer wins, as the well driller’s commencement of performance constituted an acceptance of the developer’s offer, creating a contractual obligation to complete the well. This supports option B.

question: A property owner and a landscape architect signed a detailed writing in which the landscape architect agreed to landscape the owner's residential property in accordance with a design prepared by the landscape architect and incorporated in the writing. The owner agreed to pay $10000 for the work upon its completion. The owner's spouse was not a party to the agreement and had no ownership interest in the premises. Shortly before the agreement was signed the owner and landscape architect orally agreed that the writing would not become binding on either party unless the owner's spouse should approve the landscaping design. If the owner's spouse disapproves of the design and the owner refuses to allow the landscape architect to proceed with the work is evidence of the oral agreement admissible in the landscape architect's action against the owner for breach of contract?

options.optionA: A. Yes because the oral agreement required approval by a third party.
options.optionB: B. Yes because the evidence shows that the writing was intended to take effect only if the approval occurred.
options.optionC: C. No because the parol evidence rule bars evidence of a prior oral agreement even if the latter is consistent with the terms of a partial integration.
options.optionD: D. No because the prior oral agreement contradicted the writing by making the parties' duties conditional.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Parol Evidence Rule, particularly the exception for evidence of a condition precedent to a written agreement
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The landscape architect and property owner signed a written agreement for landscaping services. However, they had a prior oral agreement requiring the property owner's spouse to approve the design. The spouse disapproved, and the owner refused to proceed with the work.
explanation.Rule_Application: The parol evidence rule generally bars evidence of prior oral agreements. However, an exception exists for evidence showing a condition precedent to the written agreement. In this case, the prior oral agreement did not contradict or add to the written agreement but rather set a condition for its effectiveness.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The evidence of the oral agreement is admissible because it demonstrates a condition precedent to the written agreement. Therefore, the correct answer is option B.

question: A property owner and a landscape architect signed a detailed writing in which the landscape architect agreed to landscape the owner's residential property in accordance with a design prepared by the landscape architect and incorporated in the writing. The owner agreed to pay $10000 for the work upon its completion. The owner's spouse was not a party to the agreement and had no ownership interest in the premises. At the owner's insistence the written owner-architect agreement contained a provision that neither party would be bound unless the owner's law partner an avid student of landscaping should approve the landscape architect's design. Before the landscape architect commenced the work the owner's law partner in the presence of both the owner and the landscape architect expressly disapproved the landscaping design. Nevertheless the owner ordered the landscape architect to proceed with the work and the landscape architect reluctantly did so. When the landscape architect's performance was 40% complete the owner repudiated his duty if any to pay the contract price or any part thereof. If the landscape architect now sues the owner for damages for breach of contract which of the following concepts best supports the landscape architect's claim?

options.optionA: A. Substantial performance.
options.optionB: B. Promissory estoppel.
options.optionC: C. Irrevocable waiver of condition.
options.optionD: D. Unjust enrichment.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Irrevocable waiver of condition in contract law, where a party waives a condition after it has not been fulfilled, and the other party relies on it.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The owner-architect agreement had a condition requiring the owner's law partner to approve the landscape design, but the law partner disapproved. Despite this, the owner ordered the landscape architect to proceed with the work, which the architect did, completing 40% of it.
explanation.Rule_Application: In contract law, if a party waives a condition after it has not been fulfilled and the other party relies on the waiver, the waiver becomes irrevocable, and the party who waived the condition cannot revoke it.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the owner waived the condition by ordering the work to proceed and the landscape architect relied on it, the owner may not revoke the waiver. Therefore, the landscape architect's claim for damages for breach of contract is supported by the concept of irrevocable waiver of condition, as stated in option C.

question: An expert in lifting and emplacing equipment atop tall buildings contracted in a signed writing to lift and emplace certain air-conditioning equipment atop a builder's building. An exculpatory clause in the contract provided that the expert would not be liable for any physical damage to the builder's building occurring during installation of the air-conditioning equipment. There was also a clause providing for per diem damages if the expert did not complete performance by a specified date and a clause providing that "time is of the essence." Another clause provided that any subsequent agreement for extra work under the contract must be in writing and signed by both parties. With ample time remaining under the contract for commencement and completion of his performance the expert notified the builder that he was selling his business to a man who was equally expert in lifting and emplacing equipment atop tall buildings and that the man had agreed to "take over the the expert-builder contract." If the builder refuses to accept the man's services which of the following clauses in the the expert-builder contract will best support the builder's contention that the expert's duties under the contract were not delegable without the builder's consent?

options.optionA: A. The exculpatory clause.
options.optionB: B. The liquidated-damage clause.
options.optionC: C. The "time is of the essence" clause.
options.optionD: D. The extra-work clause.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Delegation of duties in contracts, specifically the circumstances under which an obligor may delegate duties to another.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The expert notified the builder of selling the business and delegating the contract duties to a new expert, without seeking the builder's consent.
explanation.Rule_Application: An obligor may delegate its duty under a contract to another unless the other party to the contract has a substantial interest in having the original obligor perform. The presence of an exculpatory clause in the contract suggests that the builder has a substantial interest in the expert's performance, as the clause limits the expert's liability for damages to the builder's building.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the exculpatory clause indicates the builder's substantial interest in the expert's specific performance, the builder's refusal to accept the delegation of duties to the new expert is justified, supporting option A.

question: An expert in lifting and emplacing equipment atop tall buildings contracted in a signed writing to lift and emplace certain air-conditioning equipment atop a builder's building. An exculpatory clause in the contract provided that the expert would not be liable for any physical damage to the builder's building occurring during installation of the air-conditioning equipment. There was also a clause providing for per diem damages if the expert did not complete performance by a specified date and a clause providing that "time is of the essence." Another clause provided that any subsequent agreement for extra work under the contract must be in writing and signed by both parties. With ample time remaining under the contract for commencement and completion of his performance the expert notified the builder that he was selling his business to a man who was equally expert in lifting and emplacing equipment atop tall buildings and that the man had agreed to "take over the the expert-builder contract." Assume that the builder orally agreed with the expert to accept the man's services and that the man performed on time but negligently installed the wrong air-conditioning equipment. Will the builder succeed in an action against the expert for damages for breach of contract?

options.optionA: A. Yes because the builder did not agree to release the expert from liability under the expert-builder contract.
options.optionB: B. Yes because the builder received no consideration for the substitution of the man for the expert.
options.optionC: C. No because by accepting the substitution of the man for the expert the builder effected a novation and the expert was thereby discharged of his duties under the expert-builder contract.
options.optionD: D. No because the liquidated-damage clause in the expert-builder contract provided only for damages caused by delay in performance.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Delegation of duties under a contract, specifically the requirement for a novation to discharge the original obligor.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The expert notified the builder that he was selling his business and that the buyer, equally expert, would take over the expert-builder contract. The builder orally agreed to accept the buyer's services, which were performed on time but with a negligent mistake.
explanation.Rule_Application: Unless there is a novation, which releases the original obligor from their duties, the delegation of a contractual duty does not discharge the original obligor's obligation. The oral agreement between the builder and the expert does not constitute a novation.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Since the expert did not obtain a novation or release from the builder, the expert remains liable for the breach of contract caused by the buyer's negligent performance. Therefore, the builder will succeed in an action against the expert for damages, supporting option A.

question: The aged mother of a sister and brother both adults wished to employ a live-in companion so that she might continue to live in her own home. The mother however had only enough income to pay one-half of the companion's $2000 monthly salary. Learning of their mother's plight the sister and brother agreed with each other in a signed writing that on the last day of January and each succeeding month during their mother's lifetime each would give their mother $500. Their mother then hired the companion. The siblings made the agreed payments in January February and March. In April however the brother refused to make any payment and notified his sister and their mother that he would make no further payments. There is a valid contract between the siblings but their mother has declined to sue the brother. Will the sister succeed in an action against the brother in which she asks the court to order the brother to continue to make his payments to their mother under the terms of the the sibling's contract?

options.optionA: A. Yes because the sister's remedy at law is inadequate.
options.optionB: B. Yes because the sister's burden of supporting her mother will be increased if her brother does not contribute his share.
options.optionC: C. No because a court will not grant specific performance of a promise to pay money.
options.optionD: D. No because the brother's breach of contract has caused no economic harm to the sister.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Specific performance in contract law, particularly in cases where monetary damages are inadequate.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The siblings made a valid contract to each pay $500 monthly to support their mother, fulfilling their obligations for three months until the brother breached the contract in April.
explanation.Rule_Application: Specific performance of a contractual obligation may be granted where monetary damages are inadequate, as it is impracticable to calculate damages in this case, where the promise was made to a third party (the mother) rather than directly to the sister.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The sister will succeed in obtaining specific performance from the brother, as the court will order him to continue making payments to their mother, supporting option A.

question: A retailer of guns in a state received on June 1 the following signed letter from a gun-wholesaler in another state: "We have just obtained 100 of the assault rifles you inquired about and can supply them for $250 each. We can guarantee shipment no later than August 1." On June 10 the wholesaler sold and delivered the same rifles to another merchant for $300 each. Unaware of that transaction the retailer on the morning of June 11 mailed the wholesaler a letter rejecting the latter's offer but changing his mind an hour later retrieved from his local post office the letter of rejection and immediately dispatched to the wholesaler a letter of acceptance which the wholesaler received on June 14. On June 9 a valid federal statute making the interstate sale of assault rifles punishable as a crime had become effective but neither the retailer nor the wholesaler was aware until June 15 that the statute was already in effect. As between the retailer and the wholesaler which of the following is an accurate statement?

options.optionA: A. No contract was formed because of wholesaler's June 10 sale of the rifles to another merchant revoked the offer to the retailer.
options.optionB: B. If a contract was formed it is voidable because of mutual mistake.
options.optionC: C. If a contract was formed it is unenforceable because of supervening impracticability.
options.optionD: D. No contract was formed because the retailer's June 11 rejection was effective on dispatch.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Mutual Mistake and Supervening Impracticability in Contract Law
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The wholesaler offered the assault rifles to the retailer for $250 each on June 1 with a guarantee of shipment by August 1. The retailer initially rejected the offer, but then accepted it without knowing the wholesaler had sold the rifles to another merchant for $300 each. Neither party was aware of the federal statute criminalizing the interstate sale of assault rifles, which became effective on June 9.
explanation.Rule_Application: A contract may be discharged due to mutual mistake or supervening impracticability if the circumstances render performance impracticable for both parties, and neither party should bear the risk of the event. In this case, the federal statute renders the contract performance (interstate sale of assault rifles) impracticable, and neither party had reason to know the statute would be in effect.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: As a result, the contract is voidable due to mutual mistake, supporting option B.

question: A man owed his friend $1000 plus interest at 8% until paid on a long-overdue promissory note collection of which would become barred by the statute of limitations on June 30. On the preceding April 1 the man and his friend both signed a writing in which the man promised to pay the note in full on the following December 31 plus interest at 8% until that date and the friend promised not to sue on the note in the meantime. The friend having received some advice from his nonlawyer brother-in-law became concerned about the legal effect of the April 1 agreement. On May 1 acting pro se as permitted by the rules of the local small claims court he filed suit to collect the note. Assuming that there is no controlling statute is the April 1 agreement an effective defense for the man?

options.optionA: A. Yes because the man's promise to pay interest until December 31 was consideration for the friend's promise not to sue.
options.optionB: B. Yes because the law creates a presumption that the man relied on his friend's promise not to sue.
options.optionC: C. No because there was no consideration for the friend's promise not to sue in that the man was already obligated to pay $1000 plus interest at 8% until the payment date.
options.optionD: D. No because the man's April 1 promise is enforceable with or without consideration.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Consideration in contract law, specifically the requirement of sufficient consideration for a promise to be enforceable
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The promissory note collection would become barred by the statute of limitations on June 30, and the April 1 agreement between the man and his friend revived an obligation that would otherwise have become time-barred
explanation.Rule_Application: For a promise to be enforceable, it requires sufficient consideration. In this case, the man's promise to pay the note in full on December 31 plus interest at 8% until that date is sufficient consideration for the friend's promise not to sue, as it revived an obligation that would otherwise have become time-barred
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the sufficient consideration provided by the man's promise, the April 1 agreement is an effective defense for the man, supporting option A

question: A man owed his friend $1000 plus interest at 8% until paid on a long-overdue promissory note collection of which would become barred by the statute of limitations on June 30. On the preceding April 1 the man and his friend both signed a writing in which the man promised to pay the note in full on the following December 31 plus interest at 8% until that date and the friend promised not to sue on the note in the meantime. The friend having received some advice from his nonlawyer brother-in-law became concerned about the legal effect of the April 1 agreement. On May 1 acting pro se as permitted by the rules of the local small claims court he filed suit to collect the note. Assume that on January 2 of the following year the friend's suit has not come to trial the man has not paid the note the friend has retained a lawyer and the lawyer with leave of court amends the complaint to add a second count to enforce the promise the man made in the April 1 agreement. Does the new count state a claim upon which relief can be granted?

options.optionA: A. Yes because the man's failure to pay the note plus interest on December 31 makes the friend's breach of promise not to sue before that date no longer material.
options.optionB: B. Yes because the man's April 1 promise is enforceable by reason of his moral obligation to pay the debt.
options.optionC: C. No because such relief would undermine the policy of the statute of limitations against enforcement of stale claims.
options.optionD: D. No because the man's April 1 promise was lawfully conditioned upon the friend's forbearing to sue prior to December 31.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Constructive Conditions in Contract Law, specifically the doctrine of substantial performance and discharge of obligations in a bilateral agreement.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The friend and the man signed an agreement on April 1, promising to fulfill their respective obligations: payment of the note and forbearance from suing until December 31. However, the friend breached this agreement by filing suit on May 1.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under the doctrine of constructive conditions, the man's obligation to pay the note was conditional upon the friend's substantial performance of refraining from suing until December 31. As the friend breached this obligation, the man's obligation is no longer enforceable.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the friend's breach of the April 1 agreement, the man's promise is no longer enforceable. Therefore, the new count added to the complaint does not state a claim upon which relief can be granted, supporting option D.

question: A father and his adult daughter encountered an old family friend on the street. The daughter said to the family friend "How about lending me $1000 to buy a used car? I'll pay you back with interest one year from today." The father added "And if she doesn't pay it back as promised I will." The family friend thereupon wrote out and handed to the daughter his personal check payable to her for $1000 and the daughter subsequently used the funds to buy a used car. When the debt became due both the daughter and the father refused to repay it or any part of it. In an action by the family friend against the father to recover $1000 plus interest which of the following statements would summarize the father's best defense?

options.optionA: A. He received no consideration for his conditional promise to the family friend.
options.optionB: B. His conditional promise to the family friend was not to be performed in less than a year from the time it was made.
options.optionC: C. His conditional promise to the family friend was not made for the primary purpose of benefiting himself (the father).
options.optionD: D. The loan by the family friend was made without any agreement concerning the applicable interest rate.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Statute of Frauds and the primary purpose doctrine in guaranteeing debts
explanation.Fact_Analysis: A father made a conditional promise to a family friend to guarantee his daughter's loan of $1,000 to buy a used car if she failed to repay it. The family friend is now suing the father to recover the debt plus interest.
explanation.Rule_Application: A promise to guarantee a debt to a third person falls under the Statute of Frauds, requiring a signed writing, unless the primary purpose of making the guarantee was to benefit the promisor himself. In this case, the father's promise was not primarily made to benefit himself, but his daughter.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The father's best defense is that his conditional promise was not made for the primary purpose of benefiting himself, exempting it from the Statute of Frauds, supporting option C.

question: A borrower asked a lender to lend her $1000. The lender replied that he would do so only if the borrower's father would guarantee the loan. At the borrower's request the father mailed a signed letter to the lender: "If you lend $1000 to my daughter I will repay it if she doesn't." On September 15 the lender having read the father's letter lent $1000 to the borrower which the borrower agreed to repay in installments of $100 plus accrued interest on the last day of each month beginning October 31. The father died on September 16. Later that same day unaware of the father's death the lender mailed a letter to the father advising that he had made the $1000 loan to the borrower on September 15.  The borrower did not pay the installments due on October 31 November 30 or December 31 and has informed the lender that she will be unable to make repayments in the foreseeable future. On January 15 the lender is entitled to a judgment against the borrower for which of the following amounts?

options.optionA: A. Nothing because if he sues before the entire amount is due he will be splitting his cause of action.
options.optionB: B. $300 plus the accrued interest because the borrower's breach is only a partial breach.
options.optionC: C. $1000 plus the accrued interest because the borrower's unexcused failure to pay three installments is a material breach.
options.optionD: D. $1000 plus the accrued interest because the failure to pay her debts as they come due indicates that the borrower is insolvent and the lender is thereby entitled to accelerate payment of the debt.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Anticipatory repudiation, which is a doctrine that allows for the immediate recovery of damages for a contractual breach when there is an unequivocal statement of unwillingness or inability to perform a future contractual obligation.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The borrower failed to make three payments and expressed her inability to repay the debt in the future.
explanation.Rule_Application: Anticipatory repudiation applies only when the breach is material and occurs before the repudiating party has received all of the agreed exchange for that duty. Since the lender has already lent the $1,000, the borrower's breach is only a partial breach and the lender can only recover for the unpaid debt that is due and outstanding as of January 15.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the borrower's partial breach, the lender is entitled to a judgment of $300 plus accrued interest, supporting option B.

question: A borrower asked a lender to lend her $1000. The lender replied that he would do so only if the borrower's father would guarantee the loan. At the borrower's request the father mailed a signed letter to the lender: "If you lend $1000 to my daughter I will repay it if she doesn't." On September 15 the lender having read the father's letter lent $1000 to the borrower which the borrower agreed to repay in installments of $100 plus accrued interest on the last day of each month beginning October 31. The father died on September 16. Later that same day unaware of the father's death the lender mailed a letter to the father advising that he had made the $1000 loan to the borrower on September 15. The borrower did not pay the installments due on October 31 November 30 or December 31 and has informed the lender that she will be unable to make repayments in the foreseeable future. Assume that the borrower's entire $1000 debt is due and that she has failed to repay any part of it. In an action by the lender against the father's estate for $1000 plus accrued interest which of the following if any will serve as (an) effective defense(s) for the father's estate? I. There was no consideration to support the father's promise because he did not receive any benefit. II. The father died before the lender accepted his offer. III. The father died before the lender notified him that his offer had been accepted.

options.optionA: A. I only.
options.optionB: B. II only.
options.optionC: C. I and III only.
options.optionD: D. Neither I nor II nor III.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Unilateral contracts, consideration, and the timing of contract acceptance.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The lender received the father’s letter offering to guarantee the loan, and then loaned the borrower $1,000, unaware that the father had died the following day. The borrower failed to repay the loan, and the lender sued the father’s estate.
explanation.Rule_Application: A unilateral contract is formed when the promisor makes an offer and the offeree accepts by performing the required action. In this case, the lender's act of loaning the borrower the $1,000 constituted acceptance of the father's offer. The consideration for the father's promise was the lender's loan to his daughter, which fulfilled his desire to help her. The father's death after the contract was formed does not void the contract.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Neither the lack of consideration (I), the father's death before acceptance (II), nor the father's death before notification (III) provides an effective defense for the father's estate. Therefore, the correct answer is D, None of the above.

question: A radio manufacturer and a retailer after extensive negotiations entered into a final written agreement in which the manufacturer agreed to sell and the retailer agreed to buy all of its requirements of radios estimated at 20 units per month during the period January 1 1988 and December 31 1990 at a price of $50 per unit. A dispute arose in later December 1990 when the retailer returned 25 undefective radios to the manufacturer for full credit after the manufacturer had refused to extend the contract for a second three-year period. In an action by the manufacturer against the retailer for damages due to return of the 25 radios the manufacturer introduces the written agreement which expressly permitted the buyer to return defective radios for credit but was silent as to the return of undefective radios for credit. The retailer seeks to introduce evidence that during the three years of the agreement it had returned for various reasons 125 undefective radios for which the manufacturer had granted full credit. The manufacturer objects to the admissibility of this evidence. The trial court will probably rule that the evidence proffered by the retailer is

options.optionA: A. inadmissible because the evidence is barred by the parol evidence rule.
options.optionB: B. inadmissible because the express terms of the agreement control when those terms are inconsistent with the course of performance.
options.optionC: C. admissible because the evidence supports an agreement that is not within the relevant statute of frauds.
options.optionD: D. admissible because course-of-performance evidence when available is considered the best indication of what the parties intended the writing to mean.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Course of performance in contract law, specifically the admissibility of evidence on the parties’ prior conduct to interpret a written agreement.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The written agreement between the radio manufacturer and retailer permitted the return of defective radios, but was silent on returning undefective radios. The retailer returned 25 undefective radios and the manufacturer refused to grant credit, leading to a dispute.
explanation.Rule_Application: Course-of-performance evidence is admissible to interpret a written agreement when the writing is silent or ambiguous on a particular issue, provided the evidence is consistent with the writing and does not contradict its express terms.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The trial court will likely rule that the retailer’s evidence of returning 125 undefective radios for credit during the three-year period is admissible as course-of-performance evidence to interpret the written agreement, supporting option D.

question: A radio manufacturer and a retailer after extensive negotiations entered into a final written agreement in which the manufacturer agreed to sell and the retailer agreed to buy all of its requirements of radios estimated at 20 units per month during the period January 1 1988 and December 31 1990 at a price of $50 per unit. A dispute arose in later December 1990 when the retailer returned 25 undefective radios to the manufacturer for full credit after the manufacturer had refused to extend the contract for a second three-year period. In an action by the manufacturer against the retailer for damages due to return of the 25 radios the manufacturer introduces the written agreement which expressly permitted the buyer to return defective radios for credit but was silent as to the return of undefective radios for credit. The retailer seeks to introduce evidence that during the three years of the agreement it had returned for various reasons 125 undefective radios for which the manufacturer had granted full credit. The manufacturer objects to the admissibility of this evidence. Assume the following facts. When the retailer returned the 25 radios in question it included with the shipment a check payable to the manufacturer for the balance admittedly due on all other merchandise sold and delivered to the retailer. The check was conspicuously marked "Payment in full for all goods sold to the retailer to date." The manufacturer's credit manager reading this check notation and knowing that the retailer had also returned the 25 radios for full credit deposited the check without protest in the manufacturer's local bank account. The canceled check was returned to the retailer a week later. Which of the following defenses would best serve the retailer?

options.optionA: A. The manufacturer's deposit of the check and its return to the retailer after payment estopped the manufacturer thereafter from asserting that the retailer owed any additional amount.
options.optionB: B. By depositing the check without protest and with knowledge of its wording the manufacturer discharged any remaining duty to pay on the part of the retailer.
options.optionC: C. By depositing the check without protest and with knowledge of its wording the manufacturer entered into a novation discharging any remaining duty to pay on the part of the retailer.
options.optionD: D. The parties' good faith dispute over return of the radios suspended the duty of the retailer if any to pay any balance due.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Accord and satisfaction, particularly the concept of a creditor accepting a debtor's offer to settle a dispute by cashing a check with a 'payment in full' notation.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The retailer returned 25 undefective radios to the manufacturer and sent a check with a 'payment in full' notation. The manufacturer's credit manager, aware of the notation, deposited the check without protest.
explanation.Rule_Application: When a creditor cashes a check with a 'payment in full' notation, it implies acceptance of the debtor's offer to settle the dispute, discharging the debt. In this case, the manufacturer's actions satisfied the conditions for an accord and satisfaction.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the manufacturer cashed the check without protest, it accepted the retailer's offer to settle the dispute, thereby discharging any remaining duty to pay on the part of the retailer. Therefore, the correct defense is option B.

question: A woman entered into a contract with a painter by the terms of which the painter was to paint the woman's office for $1000 and was required to do all of the work over the following weekend so as to avoid disruption of the woman's business. Assume the following facts. If the painter had started to paint on the following Saturday morning he could have finished before Sunday evening. However he stayed home that Saturday morning to watch the final game of the World Series on TV and did not start to paint until Saturday afternoon. By late Saturday afternoon the painter realized that he had underestimated the time it would take to finish the work over the weekend unless he hired a helper. He also stated that to do so would require an additional charge of $200 for the work. The woman told the painter that she apparently had no choice but to pay "whatever it takes" to get the work done as scheduled. The painter hired a friend to help finish the painting and paid the friend $200. The woman has offered to pay the painter $1000. The painter is demanding $1200.  How much is the painter likely to recover?

options.optionA: A. $1000 only because the woman received no consideration for her promise to pay the additional sum.
options.optionB: B. $1000 only because the woman's promise to pay "whatever it takes" is too uncertain to be enforceable.
options.optionC: C. $1200 in order to prevent the woman's unjust enrichment.
options.optionD: D. $1200 because the impossibility of the painter's completing the work alone discharged the original contract and a new contract was formed.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Unilateral modification of a contract, consideration, and the preexisting duty rule in contract law.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The painter was originally contracted to paint the office for $1,000 over the weekend, but underestimated the time required. The woman agreed to pay 'whatever it takes' for the painter to hire a helper to finish on time.
explanation.Rule_Application: A unilateral modification of a contract lacks consideration and is therefore unenforceable. The painter's circumstances were foreseeable and did not justify the modification.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The painter is unlikely to recover the additional $200 as the woman's promise is unenforceable due to lack of consideration. The correct answer is option A, $1,000 only.

question: A business owner entered into a contract with a painter by the terms of which the painter was to paint the owner's office for $1000 and was required to do all of the work over the following weekend so as to avoid disruption of the owner's business. Assume the following facts. The painter commenced work on Saturday morning and had finished half the painting by the time he quit work for the day. That night without the fault of either party the office building was destroyed by fire. Which of the following is an accurate statement?

options.optionA: A. Both parties' contractual duties are discharged and the painter can recover nothing from the owner.
options.optionB: B. Both parties' contractual duties are discharged but the painter can recover in quasi-contract from the owner.
options.optionC: C. Only the painter's contractual duty is discharged because the owner's performance (payment of the agreed price) is not impossible.
options.optionD: D. Only the painter's contractual duty is discharged and the painter can recover his reliance damages from the owner.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Discharge of contractual duties due to supervening impossibility and restitution in quasi-contract
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The painter partially completed painting the office over the weekend, but the office building was unexpectedly destroyed by fire that night, rendering it impossible for the painter to complete the work
explanation.Rule_Application: A supervening event that makes performance of a contractual obligation impossible discharges both parties' duties. However, any benefit conferred prior to the event may be recovered in restitution or quasi-contract
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: As both parties' duties are discharged due to impossibility, and the painter has conferred a benefit by partially completing the work, the painter can recover in quasi-contract from the owner, supporting option B

question: A seller and a buyer standing on Greenacre orally agreed to its sale and purchase for $5000 and orally marked its bounds as "that line of trees down there the ditch that intersects them the fence on the other side and that street on the fourth side." In which of the following is the remedy of reformation most appropriate?

options.optionA: A. As later reduced to writing the agreement by clerical mistake included two acres that are actually beyond the fence.
options.optionB: B. The buyer reasonably thought that two acres beyond the fence were included in the oral agreement but the seller did not. As later reduced to writing the agreement included the two acres.
options.optionC: C. The buyer reasonably thought that the price orally agreed upon was $4500 but the seller did not. As later reduced to writing the agreement said $5000.
options.optionD: D. The buyer reasonably thought that a dilapidated shed backed up against the fence was to be torn down and removed as part of the agreement but the seller did not. As later reduced to writing the agreement said nothing about the shed.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Reformation of written agreements in contract law, particularly when clerical errors have been made, and the role of parol evidence rule in such situations.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The seller and buyer had an oral agreement regarding the sale of Greenacre, including its bounds, which were later reduced to writing. The written agreement may have included two acres beyond the fence due to a clerical mistake.
explanation.Rule_Application: In cases where a clerical error has occurred, a party may seek equitable reformation to correct the written agreement, provided that there was a prior oral agreement. The parol evidence rule does not bar the introduction of evidence to show the mistake that forms the basis for reformation.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the scenario, the remedy of reformation is most appropriate when the written agreement includes two acres beyond the fence due to a clerical mistake, supporting option A.

question: A buyer ordered from a seller 500 bushels of No. 1 Royal Fuzz peaches at a specified price "for prompt shipment." The seller promptly shipped 500 bushels but by mistake shipped No. 2 Royal Fuzz peaches instead of No. 1. The error in shipment was caused by the negligence of the seller's shipping clerk. Which of the following best states the buyer's rights and duties upon delivery of the peaches?

options.optionA: A. The seller's shipment of the peaches was a counteroffer and the buyer can refuse to accept them.
options.optionB: B. The seller's shipment of the peaches was a counteroffer but since peaches are perishable the buyer if it does not want to accept them must reship the peaches to the seller in order to mitigate the seller's losses.
options.optionC: C. The buyer must accept the peaches because a contract was formed when the seller shipped them.
options.optionD: D. Although a contract was formed when the seller shipped the peaches the buyer does not have to accept them.

explanation.Legal_Concept: UCC contract formation and non-conforming goods, specifically the buyer's rights upon delivery.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The seller shipped 500 bushels of No. 2 Royal Fuzz peaches instead of the ordered No. 1, due to their shipping clerk's negligence.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under the UCC, an order with a 'for prompt shipment' clause is interpreted as inviting acceptance by prompt shipment of conforming or non-conforming goods. If the delivered goods fail to conform to the contract, the buyer may reject them within a reasonable time after delivery.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The buyer has the right to reject the non-conforming goods, shipped in error, and thus does not have to accept them, supporting option D.

question: A debtor's $1000 contractual obligation to a creditor was due on July 1. On the preceding June 15 the creditor called her niece and said "As my birthday gift to you you may collect on July 1 the $1000 the debtor owes me." The creditor also called the debtor and told him to pay the $1000 to the niece on July 1. On July 1 the debtor saying that he did not like the niece and wouldn't pay anything to her paid the $1000 to the creditor who accepted it without objection. Will the niece succeed in an action for $1000 against the debtor?

options.optionA: A. Yes because the creditor had effectively assigned the $1000 debt to her.
options.optionB: B. Yes because the creditor's calls to the niece and the debtor effected a novation.
options.optionC: C. No because the creditor's acceptance of the $1000 without objection was in effect the revocation of a gratuitous assignment.
options.optionD: D. No because the debtor cannot be compelled to render performance to an assignee whom he finds personally objectionable.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Assignment of contract rights, particularly gratuitous assignments and their revocation
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The creditor gave her niece the right to collect $1,000 from the debtor as a birthday gift and instructed the debtor to pay the niece on July 1. Instead, the debtor paid the creditor directly, who accepted the payment without objection.
explanation.Rule_Application: In gratuitous assignments, the assignor retains the power to revoke the assignment unless and until the assignee obtains performance from the obligor. In this case, the creditor's acceptance of the payment from the debtor effectively revoked the assignment to the niece.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the creditor revoked the assignment by accepting payment from the debtor, the niece will not succeed in her action for $1,000 against the debtor, supporting option C.

question: A rancher and a fancier of horses signed the following writing: "For $5000 the rancher will sell to the fancier a gray horse that the fancier may choose from among the grays on the rancher's ranch." The fancier refused to accept delivery of a gray horse timely tendered by the rancher or to choose among those remaining on the ground that during their negotiations the rancher had orally agreed to include a saddle worth $100 and also to give the fancier the option to choose a gray or a brown horse. The fancier insisted on one of the rancher's brown horses but the rancher refused to part with any of his browns or with the saddle as demanded by the fancier. If the fancier sues the rancher for damages and seeks to introduce evidence of the alleged oral agreement the court probably will

options.optionA: A. admit the evidence as to both the saddle and the option to choose a brown horse.
options.optionB: B. admit the evidence as to the saddle but not the option to choose a brown horse.
options.optionC: C. admit the evidence as to the option to choose a brown horse but not the promise to include the saddle.
options.optionD: D. not admit any of the evidence.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Parol Evidence Rule, particularly the concept of partial integration of a written contract
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The parties entered into a written agreement for the sale of a gray horse, but the fancier alleged that the rancher orally agreed to include a saddle and give the fancier the option to choose a brown horse
explanation.Rule_Application: Under the Parol Evidence Rule, evidence of prior agreements may be admitted if the writing is only partially integrated, meaning it did not encompass the entire agreement. In this case, the alleged oral agreement regarding the saddle supplements the written agreement, while the alleged oral agreement regarding the option to choose a brown horse contradicts it.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The court will likely admit evidence of the oral agreement regarding the saddle, but exclude evidence of the oral agreement regarding the option to choose a brown horse, supporting option B.

question: A landowner contracted in a signed writing to sell Greenacre a 500-acre tract of farmland to a farmer. The contract provided for exchange of the deed and purchase price of $500000 in cash on January 15. Possession was to be given to the farmer on the same date. On January 15 the landowner notified the farmer that because the tenant on Greenacre wrongfully refused to quit the premises until January 30 the landowner would be unable to deliver possession of Greenacre until then but he assured the farmer that he would tender the deed and possession on that date. When the landowner tendered the deed and possession on January 30 the farmer refused to accept either and refused to pay the $500000. Throughout the month of January the market value of Greenacre was $510000 and its fair monthly rental value was $5000. Will the landowner probably succeed in an action against the farmer for specific performance?

options.optionA: A. Yes because the court will excuse the delay in tender on the ground that there was a temporary impossibility caused by the tenant's holding over.
options.optionB: B. Yes because time is ordinarily not of the essence in a land-sale contract.
options.optionC: C. No because the landowner breached by failing to tender the deed and possession on January 15.
options.optionD: D. No because the landowner's remedy at law for monetary relief is adequate.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Specific Performance in Land-Sale Contracts, particularly the impact of partial breach and the exception to the general rule that time is of the essence in contractual obligations.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The landowner breached the contract by failing to tender the deed and possession on January 15, due to the tenant's refusal to vacate the premises. However, the landowner assured the farmer that he would tender the deed and possession on January 30, which he eventually did.
explanation.Rule_Application: In a land-sale contract, time is not typically of the essence, which means a partial breach due to a brief delay does not excuse the other party's performance. The farmer's refusal to accept the deed and pay the purchase price on January 30 constituted a repudiation of the contract, entitling the landowner to specific performance.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the partial breach and the farmer's subsequent repudiation, the landowner will likely succeed in an action for specific performance, supporting option B.

question: A landowner contracted in a signed writing to sell Greenacre a 500-acre tract of farmland to a farmer. The contract provided for exchange of the deed and purchase price of $500000 in cash on January 15. Possession was to be given to the farmer on the same date. On January 15 landowner notified the farmer that because the tenant on Greenacre wrongfully refused to quit the premises until January 30 the landowner would be unable to deliver possession of Greenacre until then but he assured the farmer that he would tender the deed and possession on that date. Throughout the month of January the market value of Greenacre was $510000 and its fair monthly rental value was $5000. On January 30 the farmer accepted a conveyance and possession of Greenacre and paid the $500000 purchase price but notified the landowner that he was reserving any rights he might have to damages caused by the landowner's breach. The farmer intended to use the land for raising cattle and had entered into a contract for the purchase of 500 head of cattle to be delivered to Greenacre on January 15. Because he did not have possession of Greenacre on that date he had to rent another pasture at a cost of $2000 to graze the cattle for 15 days. The landowner had no reason to know that the farmer intended to use Greenacre for raising cattle or that he was purchasing cattle to be grazed on Greenacre. In an action by the farmer against the landowner for damages the farmer is entitled to recover

options.optionA: A. nothing because by paying the purchase price on January 30 he waived whatever cause of action he may have had.
options.optionB: B. nominal damages only because the market value of the land exceeded the contract price.
options.optionC: C. $2500 only (the fair rental value of Greenacre for 15 days).
options.optionD: D. $2500 (the fair rental value of Greenacre for 15 days) plus $2000 (the cost of grazing the cattle elsewhere for 15 days).

explanation.Legal_Concept: Breach of contract, particularly partial breach and consequential damages.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The landowner failed to deliver possession of Greenacre on the agreed-upon date, January 15, instead providing it on January 30, causing a delay.
explanation.Rule_Application: In the event of a partial breach, the non-breaching party remains obligated to perform the contract but may recover damages for the partial breach. Consequential damages are limited to those reasonably foreseeable to the breaching party at the time of contract formation.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the landowner's partial breach, the farmer is entitled to recover the fair rental value of Greenacre for the 15-day period of delay ($25,000), as this is a reasonably foreseeable consequence of the breach.

question: On December 1 a broker contracted with a collector to sell her one of a certain type of rare coin for $12000 delivery and payment to occur on the next March 1. To fulfill that contract and without the collector's knowledge the broker contracted on January 1 to purchase for $10000 a specimen of that type of coin from a hoarder delivery and payment to occur on February 1. The market price of such coins had unexpectedly fallen to $8000 by February 1 when the hoarder tendered the coin and the broker repudiated. On February 25 the market in such coins suddenly reversed and had stabilized at $12000 on March 1. The broker however had failed to obtain a specimen of the coin and repudiated his agreement with the collector when she tendered the $12000 agreed price on March 1. Later that day after learning by chance of the broker's dealing with the collector the hoarder telephoned the collector and said: "Listen the broker probably owes me at least $2000 in damages for refusing wrongfully to buy my coin for $10000 on February 1 when the market was down to $8000. But I'm in good shape in view of the market's recovery since then and I think you ought to get after the so-and-so." If the collector immediately sues the broker for his breach of the broker-hoarder contract which of the following will the court probably decide?

options.optionA: A. The broker wins because the collector if a beneficiary at all of the broker-hoarder contract was only an incidental beneficiary.
options.optionB: B. The broker wins because as of March 1 neither the hoarder nor the collector had sustained any damage from the broker's repudiation of both contracts.
options.optionC: C. The collector wins because she was an intended beneficiary of the broker-hoarder contract under which damages for the broker's repudiation became fixed on February 1.
options.optionD: D. The collector wins because she took an effective assignment of the hoarder's claim for damages against the broker when the hoarder suggested that the collector "get after the so-and-so."

explanation.Legal_Concept: Third-party beneficiary contracts, specifically the distinction between intended and incidental beneficiaries
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The collector contracted with the broker for a rare coin, while the broker separately contracted with the hoarder to purchase a specimen of the same coin type to fulfill the collector's contract. The hoarder tendered the coin on February 1, but the broker repudiated, and the market price had fallen to $8,000. Later, the market recovered, and the broker breached the contract with the collector
explanation.Rule_Application: To have standing to enforce a promise, a third-party must be an intended beneficiary, meaning recognition of their right to performance is necessary to effectuate the parties' intent. An incidental beneficiary, on the other hand, does not have this right
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the facts, it is unlikely that the hoarder intended to confer a benefit on the collector in the broker-hoarder contract. Therefore, the collector is only an incidental beneficiary and lacks standing to enforce the contract. The broker will likely win, supporting option A

question: For an agreed price of $20 million a builder contracted with a property owner to design and build on the property owner's commercial plot a 15-story office building. In excavating for the foundation and underground utilities the builder encountered a massive layer of granite at a depth of 15 feet. By reasonable safety criteria the building's foundation required a minimum excavation of 25 feet. When the contract was made neither the property owner nor the builder was aware of the subsurface granite for the presence of which neither party had hired a qualified expert to test. Claiming accurately that removal of enough granite to permit the construction as planned would cost him an additional $3 million and a probable net loss on the contract of $2 million the builder refused to proceed with the work unless the property owner would promise to pay an additional $2.5 million for the completed building. If the property owner refuses and sues the builder for breach of contract which of the following will the court probably decide?

options.optionA: A. The builder is excused under the modern doctrine of supervening impossibility which includes severe impracticability.
options.optionB: B. The builder is excused because the contract is voidable on account of the parties' mutual mistake concerning an essential underlying fact.
options.optionC: C. The property owner prevails because the builder assumed the risk of encountering subsurface granite that was unknown to the property owner.
options.optionD: D. The property owner prevails unless subsurface granite was previously unknown anywhere in the vicinity of the property owner's construction site.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Mutual mistake of fact in contract law, specifically the assumption of risk by one party in the context of excavation and construction.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The builder and the property owner entered into a contract to build a 15-story office building without knowing about the subsurface granite layer that would require additional excavation and costs.
explanation.Rule_Application: A party may be held to assume the risk of a mistake if they are in the business of dealing with that type of risk, and they failed to investigate the condition. In this case, the builder, as an excavation expert, should have known to investigate the ground conditions and assume the risk of unknown subsurface conditions.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Since the builder assumed the risk of encountering subsurface granite, they are not excused from performing the contract. The property owner would likely prevail in a breach of contract lawsuit, supporting option C.

question: A notorious spendthrift who was usually broke for that reason received the following letter from his uncle a wealthy and prudent man: "I understand you're in financial difficulties again. I promise to give you $5000 on your birthday next month but you'd better use it wisely or you'll never get another dime from me." The spendthrift thereupon signed a contract with a car dealer to purchase a $40000 automobile and to make a $5000 down payment on the day after his birthday. If the spendthrift sues his uncle for $5000 after the latter learned of the car-purchase contract and then repudiated his promise which of the following is the uncle's best defense?

options.optionA: A. A promise to make a gift in the future is not enforceable.
options.optionB: B. Reliance by the promisee on a promise to make a future gift does not make the promise enforceable unless the value of the promised gift is substantially equivalent to the promisee's loss by reliance.
options.optionC: C. Reliance by the promisee on a promise to make a future gift does not make the promise enforceable unless that reliance also results in an economic benefit to the promisor.
options.optionD: D. Reliance by the promisee on a promise to make a future gift does not make the promise enforceable unless injustice can be avoided only by such enforcement.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Detrimental reliance, a doctrine that allows for the enforcement of a gratuitous promise without consideration if there was reasonable expectation of reliance, actual reliance, and injustice can be avoided only by enforcement.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The uncle sent a letter promising the spendthrift $5000 if used wisely, and the spendthrift relied on this promise by signing a contract to purchase a car with a $5000 down payment.
explanation.Rule_Application: Detrimental reliance requires that the promisee's reliance was reasonable and in line with the promisor's intention, and that injustice can be avoided only by enforcing the promise. In this case, the spendthrift's reliance on the promise was inconsistent with the uncle's intended purpose.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The uncle's best defense is that the spendthrift's reliance was not in line with the uncle's intention, and therefore, injustice does not require enforcement of the promise, supporting option D.

question: A wallpaper hanger sent a general contractor this telegram: Will do all paperhanging on new Doctors' Building per owner's specs for $14000 if you accept within reasonable time after main contract awarded. /s/ the wallpaper hanger Three other competing hangers sent the general contractor similar bids in the respective amounts of $18000 $19000 and $20000. The general contractor used the wallpaper hanger's $14000 figure in preparing and submitting her own sealed bid on Doctors' Building. Before the bids were opened the wallpaper hanger truthfully advised the general contractor that the former's telegraphic sub-bid had been based on a $4000 computational error and was therefore revoked. Shortly thereafter the general contractor was awarded the Doctors' Building construction contract and subsequently contracted with another paperhanger for a price of $18000. The general contractor now sues the wallpaper hanger to recover $4000. Which of the following if proved would most strengthen the general contractor's prospect of recovery?

options.optionA: A. After the wallpaper hanger's notice of revocation the general contractor made a reasonable effort to subcontract with another paperhanger at the lowest possible price.
options.optionB: B. The general contractor had been required by the owner to submit a bid bond and could not have withdrawn or amended her bid on the main contract without forfeiting that bond.
options.optionC: C. The wallpaper hanger was negligent in erroneously calculating the amount of his sub-bid.
options.optionD: D. The general contractor dealt with all of her subcontractors in good faith and without seeking to renegotiate (lower) the prices they had bid.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Irrevocable offers and promissory estoppel in contract law, particularly when an offer induces substantial reliance on the part of the offeree
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The wallpaper hanger sent a telegram with a bid of $14,000, which was used by the general contractor in preparing and submitting their own bid. The wallpaper hanger later revoked their bid due to a computational error, and the general contractor was awarded the main contract. The general contractor subsequently contracted with another paperhanger for $18,000 and is now suing the original wallpaper hanger for $4,000
explanation.Rule_Application: An offer may be considered irrevocable if the offeror reasonably expects the offeree to substantially rely on it and the offeree does rely on it. In this case, the general contractor's reliance on the wallpaper hanger's bid is substantial due to the submission of a bid bond, which makes it difficult for the general contractor to change their bid
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the substantial reliance of the general contractor on the wallpaper hanger's bid, the fact that the general contractor was required to submit a bid bond to guarantee their bid would most strengthen the general contractor's prospect of recovery, supporting option B

question: A wallpaper hanger sent a general contractor this telegram: Will do all paperhanging on new Doctors' Building per owner's specs for $14000 if you accept within reasonable time after main contract awarded. /s/ the wallpaper hanger Three other competing hangers sent the general contractor similar bids in the respective amounts of $18000 $19000 and $20000. The general contractor used the wallpaper hanger's $14000 figure in preparing and submitting her own sealed bid on Doctors' Building. Before the bids were opened the wallpaper hanger truthfully advised the general contractor that the former's telegraphic sub-bid had been based on a $4000 computational error and was therefore revoked. Shortly thereafter the general contractor was awarded the Doctors' Building construction contract and subsequently contracted with another paperhanger for a price of $18000. The general contractor now sues the wallpaper hanger to recover $4000. Which of the following if proved would best support the wallpaper hanger's defense?

options.optionA: A. The general contractor gave the wallpaper hanger no consideration for an irrevocable sub-bid.
options.optionB: B. The wallpaper hanger's sub-bid expressly requested the general contractor's acceptance after awarding of the main contract.
options.optionC: C. Even after paying $18000 for the paperhanging the general contractor would make a net profit of $100000 on the Doctors' Building contract.
options.optionD: D. Before submitting her own bid the general contractor had reason to suspect that the wallpaper hanger had made a computational mistake in figuring his sub-bid.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Unilateral mistake in contract law, specifically the rescission of a contract due to a fundamental assumption made in error, with a material effect on the exchange.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The wallpaper hanger sent a telegraphic sub-bid to the general contractor, which included a $14,000 price. However, this price was based on a $4,000 computational error. The wallpaper hanger later revoked the sub-bid, and the general contractor contracted with another paperhanger for $18,000.
explanation.Rule_Application: A contract may be rescinded due to unilateral mistake if the mistake relates to a fundamental assumption of the contract, has a material effect on the exchange, and the party asserting the mistake should not bear the risk of the mistake. Additionally, the non-mistaken party should have reason to know of the mistake or the effect of the mistake would make enforcement of the contract unconscionable.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: If the general contractor had reason to know of the wallpaper hanger's computational mistake, this would support the wallpaper hanger's defense that the sub-contract should be rescinded due to unilateral mistake, as the mistake was fundamental to the contract and had a material effect on the exchange.
