question: For several weeks a wealthy unemployed widow and Nirvana Motors Inc. negotiated unsuccessfully over the purchase price of a new Mark XX Rolls-Royce Sedan which as Nirvana knew the widow wanted her son to have as a wedding gift. On April 27 Nirvana sent the widow a signed dated memo saying "If we can arrive at the same price within the next week do we have a deal?" The widow wrote "Yes" and her signature at the bottom of his memo and delivered it back to Nirvana on April 29. On May 1 the widow wrote Nirvana a signed letter offering to buy "one new Mark XX Rolls-Royce sedan with all available equipment for $180000 cash on delivery not later than June 1." By coincidence Nirvana wrote the widow a signed letter on May 1 offering to sell her "one new Mark XX Rolls-Royce sedan with all available equipment for $180000 cash on delivery not later than June 1." These letters crossed in the mail and were respectively received and read by the widow and Nirvana on May 2.  On May 4 the widow and Nirvana Motors both signed a single document evidencing a contract for the sale by Nirvana to the widow "as a wedding gift for the widow's son" a new Mark XX Rolls-Royce sedan under the same terms as previously stated in their correspondence. On May 5 the widow handed the son a carbon copy of this document. In reliance on the prospective gift the son on May 20 sold his nearly new Cheetah (an expensive sports car) to a dealer at a "bargain" price of $50000 and immediately informed the widow and Nirvana that he had done so. On May 25 however the widow and Nirvana Motors by mutual agreement rescinded in a signed writing "any and all agreements heretofore made between the undersigned parties for the sale-and-purchase of a new Mark XX Rolls-Royce sedan." Later that day Nirvana sold for $190000 cash to another buyer the only new Mark XX Rolls-Royce that it had in stock or could readily obtain elsewhere. On June 1 the son tendered $180000 in cash to Nirvana Motors and demanded delivery to him "within a reasonable time" of new Mark XX Rolls-Royce sedan with all available equipment. Nirvana rejected the tender and denied any obligation. If the son sues Nirvana for breach of contract which of the following will the court probably decide?

options.optionA: A. The son wins because his rights as an assignee for value of the May 4 Widow-Nirvana contract cannot be cut off by agreement between the original parties.
options.optionB: B. The son wins because his rights as a third-party intended beneficiary became vested by his prejudicial reliance in selling his Cheetah on May 20.
options.optionC: C. Nirvana wins because the son if an intended beneficiary at all of the Widow-Nirvana contract was only a donee beneficiary.
options.optionD: D. Nirvana wins because it reasonably and prejudicially relied on its contract of mutual rescission with the widow by selling the only readily available new Mark XX Rolls-Royce sedan to another buyer.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Third-party beneficiaries, specifically the rights of intended beneficiaries and when their rights vest.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: Nirvana Motors and the widow negotiated the purchase of a Rolls-Royce sedan as a wedding gift for her son. Although the widow and Nirvana mutually rescinded their contract, the son had already sold his sports car in reliance on the prospective gift.
explanation.Rule_Application: An intended beneficiary's rights vest if they materially change their position in justifiable reliance on the promise before receiving notice of the discharge. In this case, the son's sale of his sports car at a discounted price was a material change in position.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the son's prejudicial reliance on the Widow-Nirvana contract, his rights as an intended beneficiary had vested, and Nirvana is likely to be held liable for breach of contract, supporting option B.

question: On June 1 a widget manufacturer entered into a written agreement with a tool maker in which the tool maker agreed to produce and sell to the manufacturer 12 sets of newly designed dies to be delivered August 1 for the price of $50000 payable ten days after delivery. Encountering unexpected expenses in the purchase of special alloy steel required for the dies the tool maker advised the manufacturer that production costs would exceed the contract price; and on July 1 the manufacturer and the tool maker signed a modification to the June 1 agreement increasing the contract price to $60000. After timely receipt of 12 sets of dies conforming to the contract specifications the manufacturer paid the tool maker $50000 but refused to pay more. Which of the following concepts of the Uniform Commercial Code dealing expressly with the sale of goods best supports an action by the tool maker to recover $10000 for breach of the manufacturer's July 1 promise?

options.optionA: A. Bargained-for exchange.
options.optionB: B. Promissory estoppel.
options.optionC: C. Modification of contracts without consideration.
options.optionD: D. Unconscionability in the formation of contracts.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Modification of contracts for the sale of goods under the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC), particularly the dispensation with consideration when modifications are made in good faith.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The tool maker and manufacturer entered a written agreement for the production of 12 sets of dies with a price of $50000. Later, due to unexpected expenses, the parties signed a modification to the agreement increasing the price to $60000. The manufacturer paid the original price, refusing to pay the additional $10000.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under the UCC, a modification to a contract for the sale of goods may be made without additional consideration if it is done in good faith. In this case, the modification was made due to the tool maker's increased production costs, indicating good faith.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The tool maker can recover the $10000 based on the manufacturer's breach of their July 1 promise, as the modification was made in good faith and is therefore binding under the UCC, supporting option C.

question: A construction company contracted with a warehouse owner to construct for $500000 a warehouse and an access driveway at highway level. Shortly after commencing work on the driveway which required for the specified level some excavation and removal of surface material the construction company unexpectedly encountered a large mass of solid rock. The construction company informed the warehouse owner (accurately) that because of the rock the driveway as specified would cost at least $20000 more than figured and demanded that for that reason a total contract price of $520000. Since the warehouse owner was expecting warehousing customers immediately after the agreed completion date he signed a writing promising to pay the additional $20000. Following timely completion of the warehouse and driveway which conformed to the contract in all respects the warehouse owner refused to pay the construction company more than $500000. What is the maximum amount to which the construction company is entitled?

options.optionA: A. $500000 because there was no consideration for warehouse owner's promise to pay the additional $20000.
options.optionB: B. $500000 because the warehouse owner's promise to pay the additional $20000 was exacted under duress.
options.optionC: C. $520000 because modification was fair and was made in the light of circumstances not anticipated by the parties when the original contract was made.
options.optionD: D. $520000 provided that the reasonable value of the construction company's total performance was that much or more.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Unilateral modification of a contract, including the exception for fair and equitable modifications made due to unforeseen circumstances
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The construction company encountered an unexpected mass of solid rock while building the driveway, necessitating a price increase to complete the work as specified
explanation.Rule_Application: A unilateral modification may be enforceable if it is fair and equitable, and made in response to unforeseen circumstances. In this case, the construction company's proposal to increase the contract price accurately reflected the increased cost of excavating the rock
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the modification was made in response to unforeseen circumstances, was fair and equitable, and accurately reflected the increased cost, the construction company should recover the modified contract price of $5,200,000, supporting option C

question: A construction company contracted with a warehouse owner to construct for $500000 a warehouse and an access driveway at highway level. Shortly after commencing work on the driveway which required for the specified level some excavation and removal of surface material the construction company unexpectedly encountered a large mass of solid rock. Upon encountering the rock formation the construction company instead of incurring additional costs to remove it built the access driveway over the rock with a steep grade down to the highway. The warehouse owner who was out of town for several days was unaware of this nonconformity until the driveway had been finished. As built it is too steep to be used safely by trucks or cars particularly in the wet or icy weather frequently occurring in the area. It would cost $30000 to tear out and rebuild the driveway at highway level. As built the warehouse including the driveway has a fair market value of $550000. The warehouse owner has paid $470000 to the construction company but refuses to pay more because of the nonconforming driveway which the construction company has refused to tear out and rebuild. If the construction company sues the warehouse owner for monetary relief what is the maximum amount that the construction company is entitled to recover?

options.optionA: A. $30000 because the fair market value of the warehouse and driveway "as is" exceeds the contract price by $50000 (more than the cost of correcting the driveway).
options.optionB: B. $30000 because the construction company substantially performed and the cost of correcting the driveway would involve economic waste.
options.optionC: C. $30000 minus whatever amount the construction company saved by not building the driveway at the specified level.
options.optionD: D. Nothing because the warehouse owner is entitled to damages for the cost of correcting the driveway.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Breach of a construction contract and the general damages rule for measuring loss to an owner, including cost to complete damages and the exception for economic waste.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The construction company failed to build the driveway at the specified level, instead constructing it over the rock formation, resulting in a steep grade that is too dangerous to use safely. The warehouse owner paid $47,000 but refused to pay more due to the nonconforming driveway, which the construction company refused to tear out and rebuild.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under the general damages rule, the owner is entitled to damages equal to the cost to complete the work as promised, which in this case is $30,000 to tear out and rebuild the driveway. However, an exception applies where the cost to complete damages would be grossly and unfairly out of proportion to the performance contracted for, which is not applicable here.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The warehouse owner is entitled to damages for the cost of correcting the driveway, and the construction company is not entitled to any further payment. Therefore, the correct answer is option D, Nothing.

question: Responding to the county's written advertisement for bids a tire salesman was the successful bidder for the sale of tires to the county for the county's vehicles. The tire salesman and the county entered into a signed written agreement that specified "It is agreed that the tire salesman will deliver all tires required by this agreement to the county in accordance with the attached bid form and specifications for a one-year period beginning September 1 1990." Attached to the agreement was a copy of the bid form and specifications. In the written advertisement to which the tire salesman had responded but not in the bid form the county had stated "Multiple awards may be issued if they are in the best interests of the county." No definite quantity of tires to be bought by the county from the tire salesman was specified in any of these documents. In January 1991 the tire salesman learned that the county was buying some of its tires from one of the tire salesman's competitors. Contending that the tire salesman-county agreement was a requirements contract the tire salesman sued the county for the damages caused by the county buying some of its tires from the competitor. If the county defends by offering proof of the advertisement concerning the possibility of multiple awards should the court admit the evidence?

options.optionA: A. Yes because the provision in the written agreement "all tires required by this agreement" is ambiguous.
options.optionB: B. Yes because the advertisement was in writing.
options.optionC: C. No because of the parol evidence rule.
options.optionD: D. No because it would make the contract illusory.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Parol Evidence Rule in contract law, specifically the exception to the rule when the written contract has an ambiguity
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The tire salesman and the county entered into a signed agreement for the sale of tires, with a provision specifying the delivery of all tires required, but without a definite quantity specified. The county's written advertisement for bids mentioned the possibility of multiple awards, which was not included in the bid form or agreement.
explanation.Rule_Application: The parol evidence rule generally bars introduction of prior agreements that contradict the written contract. However, when the written contract contains an ambiguity, evidence of prior agreements or circumstances may be admitted to clarify the ambiguity. In this case, the ambiguity lies in the phrase 'all tires required by this agreement', which may or may not indicate a requirements contract.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the ambiguity in the written contract, the court should admit evidence of the county's advertisement regarding multiple awards, supporting option A.

question: Responding to the county's written advertisement for bids a tire salesman was the successful bidder for the sale of tires to the county for the county's vehicles. The tire salesman and the county entered into a signed written agreement that specified "It is agreed that the tire salesman will deliver all tires required by this agreement to the county in accordance with the attached bid form and specifications for a one-year period beginning September 1 1990." Attached to the agreement was a copy of the bid form and specifications. In the written advertisement to which the tire salesman had responded but not in the bid form the county had stated "Multiple awards may be issued if they are in the best interests of the county." No definite quantity of tires to be bought by the county from the tire salesman was specified in any of these documents. In January 1991 the tire salesman learned that the county was buying some of its tires from one of the tire salesman's competitors. Contending that the tire salesman-county agreement was a requirements contract the tire salesman sued the county for the damages caused by the county buying some of its tires from the competitor. If the court concludes that the tire salesman-county contract is an agreement by the county to buy its tire requirements from the tire salesman the tire salesman probably will

options.optionA: A. recover under the contracts clause of the United States Constitution.
options.optionB: B. recover under the provisions of the Uniform Commercial Code.
options.optionC: C. not recover because the agreement lacks mutuality of obligation.
options.optionD: D. not recover because the agreement is indefinite as to quantity.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Requirements contracts in the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC), particularly the obligation of the buyer to purchase exclusively from the seller.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The written agreement between the tire salesman and the county specified that the tire salesman would deliver all tires required by the agreement for a one-year period starting September 1, 1990. Although the exact quantity of tires was not specified, the agreement implied that the county would buy all its tire requirements from the tire salesman.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under the UCC, a requirements contract implies that the buyer will purchase all its requirements for the good exclusively from the seller. If the county is buying some tires from a competitor, it would be a breach of this obligation.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the county's actions constitute a breach of the requirements contract, the tire salesman would likely recover damages under the provisions of the Uniform Commercial Code, supporting option B.

question: An automobile retailer had an adult daughter who needed a car in her employment but had only $3000 with which to buy one. The retailer wrote to his daughter "Give me your $3000 and I'll give you the car on our lot that we have been using as a demonstrator." The daughter thanked her father and paid him the $3000. As both the retailer and his daughter knew the demonstrator was reasonably worth $10000. After the daughter had paid the $3000 but before the car had been delivered to her one of retailer's sales staff sold and delivered the same car to a customer for $10000. Neither the salesperson nor the customer was aware of the transaction between the retailer and his daughter. Does the daughter after rejecting a tendered return of the $3000 by her father have an action against him for breach of contract?

options.optionA: A. Yes because the retailer's promise was supported by bargained-for consideration.
options.optionB: B. Yes because retailer's promise was supported by the moral obligation a father owes his child as to the necessities of modern life.
options.optionC: C. No because the payment of $3000 was inadequate consideration to support the retailer's promise.
options.optionD: D. No because the salesperson's delivery of the car to the customer made it impossible for the retailer to perform.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Bargained-for consideration in contract law, specifically the requirement that a promise be supported by sufficient consideration to be enforceable.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The retailer offered to sell his daughter a demonstrator car worth $10,000 for $3,000, which the daughter accepted. However, before delivering the car, the retailer's sales staff sold the same car to a third party for the full price.
explanation.Rule_Application: A promise is enforceable if it is supported by bargained-for consideration, which means that the promisor sought the consideration in exchange for the promise. In this case, the retailer's promise to give his daughter the car was conditioned upon her payment of $3,000, satisfying the requirement of bargained-for consideration.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Since the retailer's promise was supported by bargained-for consideration, the daughter has an action against him for breach of contract, supporting option A.

question: Under the terms of a written contract a builder agreed to construct for a homeowner a garage for $10000. Nothing was said in the parties' negotiations or in the contract about progress payments during the course of the work. After completing 25% of the garage strictly according to the homeowner's specifications the builder demanded payment of $2000 as a "reasonable progress payment." The homeowner refused and the builder abandoned the job. If each party sues the other for breach of contract which of the following will the court decide?

options.optionA: A. Both parties are in breach and each is entitled to damages if any from the other.
options.optionB: B. Only the builder is in breach and liable for the homeowner's damages if any.
options.optionC: C. Only the homeowner is in breach and liable for the builder's damages if any.
options.optionD: D. Both parties took reasonable positions and neither is in breach.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Constructive conditions in contract law, specifically the doctrine that a party's contractual obligation is conditioned upon the other party's substantial performance
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The builder agreed to construct a garage for $10,000, completed 25% of the work, and then demanded payment of $2,000 as a 'reasonable progress payment', which the homeowner refused to pay. The builder abandoned the job, claiming breach by the homeowner.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under constructive conditions, a party's contractual obligation is conditioned upon the other party's substantial performance. In this case, the contract was silent regarding progress payments, so the homeowner was not obligated to pay until the builder substantially performed his promise to build the garage. The builder's abandonment of the job after 25% completion constitutes a material breach of the contract.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the builder breached the contract by abandoning the job, the court will decide that only the builder is in breach and liable for the homeowner's damages, if any, supporting option B.

question: Under the terms of a written contract a builder agreed to construct for a homeowner a garage for $10000. Nothing was said in the parties' negotiations or in the contract about progress payments during the course of the work. After completing 25% of the garage strictly according to the homeowner's specifications the builder assigned his rights under the contract to a bank as security for an $8000 loan. The bank immediately notified the homeowner of the assignment. The builder thereafter without legal excuse abandoned the job before it was half-complete. The builder subsequently defaulted on the loan from the bank. The builder has no assets. It will cost the homeowner at least $8000 to get the garage finished by another builder. If the bank sues the homeowner for $8000 which of the following will the court decide?

options.optionA: A. The bank wins because the builder-homeowner contract was in existence and the builder was not in breach when the bank gave the homeowner notice of the assignment.
options.optionB: B. The bank wins because the bank as a secured creditor over the builder is entitled to priority over the homeowner's unsecured claim against the builder.
options.optionC: C. The homeowner wins because his right to recoupment on account of the builder's breach is available against the bank as the builder's assignee.
options.optionD: D. The homeowner wins because his claim against the builder arose prior to the builder's default on his loan from the bank.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Assignment of contractual rights and the effect of the assignor's breach on the assignee's rights
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The builder completed 25% of the garage, then assigned his contract rights to the bank as security for a loan, after which he abandoned the job and defaulted on the loan. The bank notified the homeowner of the assignment.
explanation.Rule_Application: An assignee acquires no greater rights against the obligor than the assignor had, and the assignee's right to payment remains subject to any defense that the obligor could raise against the assignor. In this case, the builder's material breach of the construction contract is a defense that the homeowner can raise against the bank.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The court will decide in favor of the homeowner because the builder's breach is a valid defense against the bank's claim, supporting option C.

question: On June 1 a wholesale company received a purchase-order form from a retailer in which the latter ordered 1000 anti-recoil widgets for delivery no later than August 30 at a delivered total price of $10000 as quoted in the wholesale company's current catalog. Both parties are merchants with respect to widgets of all types. On June 2 the wholesale company mailed to the retailer its own form across the top of which the wholesale company's president had written "We are pleased to accept your order." This form contained the same terms as the retailer's form except for an additional printed clause in the wholesale company's form that provided for a maximum liability of $100 for any breach of contract by the wholesale company. As of June 5 when the retailer received the wholesale company's acceptance form which of the following is an accurate statement concerning the legal relationship between the wholesale company and the retailer?

options.optionA: A. There is no contract because the liability-limitation clause in the wholesale company's form is a material alteration of the retailer's offer.
options.optionB: B. There is no contract because the retailer did not consent to the liability-limitation clause in the wholesale company's form.
options.optionC: C. There is an enforceable contract whose terms include the liability-limitation clause in the wholesale company's form because liquidation of damages is expressly authorized by the Uniform Commercial Code.
options.optionD: D. There is an enforceable contract whose terms do not include the liability-limitation clause in the wholesale company's form.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Formation of contracts under the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC), particularly the effect of additional or different terms in written acceptance on contract formation and terms.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The retailer submitted an order to the wholesale company, which responded with a written acceptance that included an additional liability-limitation clause, differing from the original terms.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under the UCC, a written acceptance generally operates as an acceptance, even with additional or different terms. However, such terms will not become part of the contract if they materially alter the original terms, unless the offeror expressly agrees.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the wholesale company's acceptance form included a material alteration (the liability-limitation clause), and the retailer did not agree to it, the clause will not be part of the contract. Therefore, there is an enforceable contract, but without the liability-limitation clause, supporting option D.

question: A developer obtained a bid of $10000 to tear down her old building and another bid of $90000 to replace it with a new structure in which she planned to operate a sporting goods store. Having only limited cash available the developer asked a lender for a $100000 loan. After reviewing the plans for the project the lender in a signed writing promised to lend the developer $100000 secured by a mortgage on the property and repayable over ten years in equal monthly installments at 10% annual interest. The developer promptly accepted the demolition bid and the old building was removed but the lender thereafter refused to make the loan. Despite diligent efforts the developer was unable to obtain a loan from any other source. Does the developer have a cause of action against the lender?

options.optionA: A. Yes because by having the building demolished she accepted the lender's offer to make the loan.
options.optionB: B. Yes because her reliance on the lender's promise was substantial reasonable and foreseeable.
options.optionC: C. No because there was no bargained-for exchange of consideration for the lender's promise to make the loan.
options.optionD: D. No because the developer's inability to obtain a loan from any other source demonstrated that the project lacked the financial soundness that was a constructive condition to the lender's performance.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Promissory Estoppel in contract law, specifically the enforcement of a promise despite lack of consideration due to reliance and necessity to prevent injustice.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The lender reviewed the project plans, made a signed written promise to lend $100000, and the developer relied on that promise by accepting the demolition bid, removing the old building, and attempting to secure the loan. The lender then refused to lend, and the developer was unable to find alternative financing.
explanation.Rule_Application: Promissory estoppel allows for the enforcement of a promise where there was reasonable expectation of reliance, actual reliance, and necessity to prevent injustice. The lender should have reasonably expected the developer's reliance, and the developer's actions demonstrate substantial reliance. Enforcement is necessary to prevent the injustice of the lender's refusal to lend after inducing reliance.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The developer has a cause of action against the lender due to promissory estoppel, as the lender's promise was enforceable despite the lack of consideration, supporting option B.

question: A developer obtained a bid of $10000 to tear down her old building and another bid of $90000 to replace it with a new structure in which she planned to operate a sporting goods store. Having only limited cash available the developer asked the lender for a $100000 loan. After reviewing the plans for the project the lender in a signed writing promised to lend the developer $100000 secured by a mortgage on the property and repayable over ten years in equal monthly installments at 10% annual interest. The developer promptly accepted the demolition bid and the old building was removed but the lender thereafter refused to make the loan. Despite diligent efforts the developer was unable to obtain a loan from any other source. Assume that the developer has a cause of action against the lender. If she sues him for monetary relief what is the probable measure of her recovery?

options.optionA: A. Expectation damages measured by the difference between the value of the new building and the old building less the amount of the proposed loan ($100000).
options.optionB: B. Expectation damages measured by the estimated profits from operating the proposed sporting goods store for ten years less the cost of repaying a $100000 loan at 10% interest over ten years.
options.optionC: C. Reliance damages measured by the $10000 expense of removing the old building adjusted by the decrease or increase in the market value of the developer's land immediately thereafter.
options.optionD: D. Nominal damages only because both expectation and reliance damages are speculative and there is no legal or equitable basis for awarding restitution.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Detrimental Reliance, specifically the remedy for breach of promise based on detrimental reliance
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The developer relied on the lender’s promise to lend $100000 and proceeded with the demolition of the old building. The lender then refused to make the loan.
explanation.Rule_Application: In an action based on detrimental reliance, the damages awarded are intended to restore the injured party to the status quo before the promise was made. The measure of damages is the amount necessary to remedy the loss incurred due to the reliance.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the developer’s detrimental reliance on the lender’s promise, the probable measure of her recovery would be reliance damages, measured by the $10000 expense of removing the old building adjusted by the decrease or increase in the market value of the developer’s land immediately thereafter, supporting option C.

question: In a writing signed by both parties on December 1 a man agreed to buy from a distributor a gasoline engine for $1000 delivery to be made on the following February 1. Through a secretarial error the writing called for delivery on March 1 but neither party noticed the error until February 1. Before signing the agreement the man and the distributor orally agreed that the contract of sale would be effective only if the man notified the distributor in writing no later than January 2 that the man had arranged to resell the engine to a third person. Otherwise they agreed orally "There is no deal." On December 15 the man entered into a contract with a mechanic to resell the engine to the mechanic at a profit. The man did not give the distributor notice of the resale until January 25 and the distributor received it by mail on January 26. In the meantime the value of the engine had unexpectedly increased about 75% since December 1 and the distributor renounced the agreement. If the man sues distributor on February 2 for breach of contract which of the following is distributor's best defense?

options.optionA: A. The secretarial error in the written delivery-term was a mutual mistake concerning a basic fact and the agreement is voidable by either party.
options.optionB: B. The man's not giving written notice by January 2 of his resale was a failure of a condition precedent to the existence of a contract.
options.optionC: C. In view of the unexpected 75% increase in value of the engine after December 1 the distributor's performance is excused by the doctrine of commercial frustration.
options.optionD: D. The agreement if any is unenforceable because a material term was not included in the writing.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Conditions precedent in contract law, specifically the requirement of a certain event occurring before contractual performance becomes due.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The parties orally agreed that the contract would only be effective if the man notified the distributor in writing by January 2 that he had arranged a resale to a third person, and the written agreement did not include this term. The man did not give notice until January 25, which was received by the distributor on January 26.
explanation.Rule_Application: A condition precedent is an event that must occur before contractual performance becomes due. If the event does not occur, the contractual obligations are excused. In this scenario, the man's failure to provide written notice by January 2 means the condition precedent was not fulfilled, excusing the distributor's obligations under the contract.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: As the distributor's performance was excused due to the nonoccurrence of the condition precedent, the distributor's best defense is that the man's failure to provide timely written notice of resale meant there was no contract, supporting option B.

question: In a writing signed by both parties on December 1 a man agreed to buy from a distributor a gasoline engine for $1000 delivery to be made on the following February 1. Through a secretarial error the writing called for delivery on March 1 but neither party noticed the error until February 1. Before signing the agreement the man and the distributor orally agreed that the contract of sale would be effective only if the man notified the distributor in writing no later than January 2 that the man had arranged to resell the engine to a third person. Otherwise they agreed orally "There is no deal." On December 15 the man entered into a contract with a mechanic to resell the engine to the mechanic at a profit. On December 16 the man notified the distributor by telephone of the man's resale agreement with the mechanic and explained that a written notice was not feasible because the man's secretary was ill. The distributor replied "That's okay. I'll get the engine to you on February 1 as we agreed." Having learned however that the engine had increased in value about 75% since December 1 the distributor renounced the agreement on February 1. If the man sues the distributor on February 2 for breach of contract which of the following concepts best supports the man's claim?

options.optionA: A. Substantial performance.
options.optionB: B. Nonoccurrence of a condition subsequent.
options.optionC: C. Waiver of condition.
options.optionD: D. Novation of buyers.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Waiver of condition, which is a type of contractual waiver that occurs when a party entitled to enforce a condition of a contract relinquishes that right, allowing the contract to remain valid despite the non-occurrence of the condition.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The man and the distributor had an oral agreement that the contract would be effective only if the man notified the distributor in writing by January 2 of a resale agreement. The man failed to provide written notice but verbally informed the distributor on December 16 and the distributor agreed to proceed with delivery without the written notice.
explanation.Rule_Application: When one party waives a condition, they relinquish their right to enforce it, and the contract remains valid. In this scenario, the distributor's verbal agreement on December 16 waived the condition of written notice, making the contract effective despite the non-occurrence of the condition.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the distributor waived the condition of written notice, the man's claim for breach of contract is supported by the concept of waiver of condition, as stated in option C.

question: A son who knew nothing about horses inherited a thoroughbred colt whose disagreeable behavior made him a pest around the barn. The son sold the colt for $1500 to an experienced racehorse-trainer who knew of the son's ignorance about horses. At the time of the sale the son said to the trainer "I hate to say it but this horse is bad-tempered and nothing special." Assume that soon after the sale the horse won three races and earned $400000 for the trainer. Which of the following additional facts if established by the son would best support his chance of obtaining rescission of the sale to the trainer?

options.optionA: A. The son did not know until after the sale that the purchaser was an experienced racehorse-trainer.
options.optionB: B. At a pre-sale exercise session of which the trainer knew that the son was not aware the trainer clocked the horse in record-setting time far surpassing any previous performance.
options.optionC: C. The horse was the only thoroughbred that the son owned and the son did not know how to evaluate young and untested racehorses.
options.optionD: D. At the time of the sale the son was angry and upset over an incident in which the horse had reared and thrown a rider.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Rescission of a contract due to nondisclosure of a material fact, particularly when one party has a duty to act in good faith in a transaction.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The son sold the thoroughbred colt to an experienced trainer for $15,000, unaware of its true potential. The trainer, aware of the son's ignorance, did not disclose the horse's capabilities. Soon after, the horse won three races, earning $400,000 for the trainer.
explanation.Rule_Application: Nondisclosure of a material fact can be tantamount to a misrepresentation of fact, justifying rescission of a contract. This is especially true where one party has a duty to act in good faith and the nondisclosure corrects the other party's mistake about a basic assumption of the contract.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: If the son can establish that the trainer knew the horse's true abilities and failed to disclose them, he may be able to rescind the sale. Therefore, the additional fact that best supports the son's chance of obtaining rescission is the trainer's knowledge of the horse's record-setting time, supporting option B.

question: A son who knew nothing about horses inherited a thoroughbred colt whose disagreeable behavior made him a pest around the barn. The son sold the colt for $1500 to an experienced racehorse-trainer who knew of the son's ignorance about horses. At the time of the sale the son said to the trainer "I hate to say it but this horse is bad-tempered and nothing special." Which one of the following scenarios would best support an action by the trainer rather than the son to rescind the sale?

options.optionA: A. In his first race after the sale the horse galloped to a huge lead but dropped dead 100 yards from the finish line because of a rare congenital heart defect that was undiscoverable except by autopsy.
options.optionB: B. The horse won $5 million for the trainer over a three-year racing career but upon being retired was found to be incurably sterile and useless as a breeder.
options.optionC: C. After the horse had won three races for the trainer it was discovered that by clerical error unknown to either party the horse's official birth registration listed an undistinguished racehorse as the sire rather than the famous racehorse that in fact was the sire.
options.optionD: D. A week after the sale the horse went berserk and inflicted serious injuries upon the trainer that required his hospitalization for six months and a full year for his recovery.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Mutual mistake in contract law, specifically the grounds for rescission due to a fundamental assumption with a material effect on the exchange and the allocation of risk between parties.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The son sold a thoroughbred colt to an experienced racehorse-trainer despite disclosing its bad temper and lack of exceptional qualities. The trainer is now seeking to rescind the sale based on the discovery of a rare congenital heart defect that caused the horse's death in its first race.
explanation.Rule_Application: A contract can be rescinded due to mutual mistake if the mistake relates to a fundamental assumption with a material effect on the exchange, and the party seeking rescission does not bear the risk of the mistake. Here, the horse's suitability for racing was a fundamental assumption, and the undiscoverable heart defect destroyed the subject matter of the contract.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the mutual mistake and the allocation of risk, the trainer has a plausible argument for rescission, supporting option A.

question: The owner of a fleet of taxis contracted with a dealer in petroleum products for the purchase and sale of the taxi fleet owner's total requirements of gasoline and oil for one year. As part of that agreement the petroleum dealer also agreed with the taxi fleet owner that for one year the petroleum dealer would place all his advertising with the taxi fleet owner's wife who owned her own small advertising agency. When the wife was informed of the owner-dealer contract she declined to accept an advertising account from the a soap company because she could not handle both the petroleum dealer and the soap company accounts during the same year. During the first month of the contract the taxi fleet owner purchased substantial amounts of his gasoline from a supplier other than the petroleum dealer and the petroleum dealer thereupon notified the wife that he would no longer place his advertising with her agency. In an action against the petroleum dealer for breach of contract the wife probably will

options.optionA: A. succeed because she is a third-party beneficiary of the owner-dealer contract.
options.optionB: B. succeed because the taxi fleet owner was acting as the wife's agent when he contracted with the petroleum dealer.
options.optionC: C. not succeed because the failure of a constructive condition precedent excused the petroleum dealer's duty to place his advertising with the wife.
options.optionD: D. not succeed because the wife did not provide any consideration to support the petroleum dealer's promise to place his advertising with her.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Constructive Conditions and Material Breach in Contract Law
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The taxi fleet owner contracted with a petroleum dealer to purchase all required gasoline and oil for one year, and the dealer agreed to advertise with the owner's wife for that period. The owner breached the contract by buying gasoline from another supplier, and the dealer responded by terminating the advertising agreement with the wife.
explanation.Rule_Application: A material breach of a contract by one party excuses the other party's performance, including any promises made to a third party, under the doctrine of constructive conditions. Here, the taxi fleet owner's failure to purchase exclusively from the petroleum dealer justified the dealer's termination of the advertising agreement with the wife.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the material breach by the taxi fleet owner, the petroleum dealer was justified in terminating the advertising agreement, so the wife's claim for breach of contract will likely fail, supporting option C.

question: The owner of a fleet of taxis contracted with a dealer in petroleum products for the purchase and sale of the taxi fleet owner's total requirements of gasoline and oil for one year. As part of that agreement the petroleum dealer also agreed with the taxi fleet owner that for one year the petroleum dealer would place all his advertising with the taxi fleet owner's wife who owned her own small advertising agency. When the wife was informed of the owner-dealer contract she declined to accept an advertising account from the a soap company because she could not handle both the petroleum dealer and the soap company accounts during the same year. The wife was an intended beneficiary under the owner-dealer contract. The taxi fleet owner performed his contract with the petroleum dealer for six months and during that time the petroleum dealer placed his advertising with the wife. At the end of the six months the taxi fleet owner and the wife were divorced and the taxi fleet owner then told the petroleum dealer that he had no further obligation to place his advertising with the wife. The petroleum dealer thereupon notified the wife that he would no longer place his advertising with her. In an action against the petroleum dealer for breach of contract the wife will probably

options.optionA: A. succeed because on the facts of this case the petroleum dealer and the taxi fleet owner could not without the wife's consent modify their contract so as to discharge the petroleum dealer's duties to the wife.
options.optionB: B. succeed because the taxi fleet owner acted in bad faith in releasing the petroleum dealer from his duty with respect to the wife.
options.optionC: C. not succeed because absent a provision in the contract to the contrary the promisor and promisee of a third-party beneficiary contract retain by law the right to modify or terminate the contract.
options.optionD: D. not succeed because the agency relationship if any between the taxi fleet owner and the wife terminated upon their divorce.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Third-party beneficiary contracts, specifically the rights of a beneficiary after reliance or acceptance.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The wife was an intended beneficiary of the contract between the taxi fleet owner and the petroleum dealer. She relied on the contract by declining an alternative advertising account. The taxi fleet owner and the wife were divorced after six months of contract performance, leading the taxi fleet owner to claim the petroleum dealer was released from his advertising obligations to the wife.
explanation.Rule_Application: Once the beneficiary's rights vest, the promisor and promisee may not modify or discharge the contract without the beneficiary's consent. This is because the beneficiary has a vested interest in the contract's performance.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the wife's reliance on the contract and the vested nature of her rights, the petroleum dealer may not unilaterally terminate the advertising agreement without the wife's consent. Therefore, the wife will likely succeed in her breach of contract claim against the petroleum dealer, supporting option A.

question: A woman owns an exceptionally seaworthy boat that she charters for sport fishing at a $500 daily rate. The fee includes the use of the boat with the woman as the captain and one other crew member as well as fishing tackle and bait. On May 1 a father agreed with the woman that the father would have the full-day use of the boat on May 15 for himself and his family for $500. The father paid an advance deposit of $200 and signed an agreement that the deposit could be retained by the woman as liquidated damages in the event the father canceled or failed to appear. At the time of contracting the woman told the father to be at the dock at 5 a.m. on May 15. The father and his family however did not show up on May 15 until noon. In the meantime the owner of the boat agreed at 10 a.m. to take a woman and her family out fishing for the rest of the day. The woman had happened to come by and inquire about the possibility of such an outing. In view of the late hour the owner of the boat charged the woman $400 and stayed out two hours beyond the customary return time. The father's failure to appear until noon was due to the fact that he had been trying to charter another boat across the bay at a lower rate and had gotten lost after he was unsuccessful in getting such a charter. Which of the following is an accurate statement concerning the rights of the parties?

options.optionA: A. The woman can retain the $200 paid by the father because it would be difficult for the woman to establish her actual damages and the sum appears to have been a reasonable forecast in light of anticipated loss of profit from the charter.
options.optionB: B. The woman is entitled to retain only $50 (10% of the contract price) and must return $150 to the father.
options.optionC: C. The woman must return $100 to the father in order to avoid her own unjust enrichment at the father's expense.
options.optionD: D. The woman must return $100 to the father because the liquidated-damage clause under the circumstances would operate as a penalty.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Liquidated Damages and Breach of Contract
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The father failed to appear at the agreed upon time, giving the woman the opportunity to charter the boat to another customer. The woman incurred an opportunity cost by holding the boat for the father, as she could have chartered it to someone else.
explanation.Rule_Application: When a liquidated damages clause is reasonable in light of the anticipated or actual damages resulting from the breach, the breaching party is not entitled to restitution. In this case, the $200 deposit appears to be a reasonable forecast of the woman’s anticipated loss of profit from the charter.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The woman should be able to retain the $200 deposit, as the liquidated damages clause is reasonable, and the father is not entitled to restitution, supporting option A.

question: A woman owns an exceptionally seaworthy boat that she charters for sport fishing at a $500 daily rate. The fee includes the use of the boat with the woman as the captain and one other crew member as well as fishing tackle and bait. On May 1 a father agreed with the woman that the father would have the full-day use of the boat on May 15 for himself and his family for $500. The father paid an advance deposit of $200 and signed an agreement that the deposit could be retained by the woman as liquidated damages in the event the father canceled or failed to appear. On May 15 at 1 a.m. the Coast Guard had issued offshore "heavy weather" warnings and prohibited all small vessels the size of the woman's from leaving the harbor. This prohibition remained in effect throughout the day. The father did not appear at all on May 15 because he had heard the weather warnings on his radio.  Which of the following is an accurate statement?

options.optionA: A. The contract is discharged because of impossibility and the father is entitled to return of his deposit.
options.optionB: B. The contract is discharged because of mutual mistake concerning an essential fact and the father is entitled to return of his deposit.
options.optionC: C. The contract is not discharged because its performance was possible in view of the exceptional seaworthiness of the woman's boat and the father is not entitled to return of his deposit.
options.optionD: D. The contract is not discharged and the father is not entitled to return of his deposit because the liquidated-damage clause in effect allocated the risk of bad weather to the father.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Supervening Impossibility in contract law, which discharges a contract when an unexpected event makes it impossible to perform without fault of either party.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: A contract was formed between a woman who owns a seaworthy boat and a father for a charter on May 15. The father paid a $200 deposit, which was non-refundable in case of cancellation. However, on May 15, the Coast Guard prohibited all small vessels, including the woman's boat, from leaving the harbor due to heavy weather warnings.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under supervening impossibility, a contract may be discharged if an unexpected event makes it impossible to perform without fault of either party. In this case, the Coast Guard's prohibition made it impossible for the woman to fulfill her contractual obligations, discharging the contract.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: As the contract is discharged due to supervening impossibility, the father is entitled to restitution of the $200 deposit, supporting option A.

question: The manager of a state fair contracted with a renowned hog breeder to exhibit the breeder's world champion animal for the three weeks of the annual fair at the conclusion of which the breeder would receive an honorarium of $300. Two days before the opening of the fair the champion animal took sick with boarsitis a communicable disease among swine and under the applicable state quarantine law very probably could not be exhibited for at least a month. Upon learning this the manager can legally pursue which of the following courses of action with respect to his contract with the breeder?

options.optionA: A. Suspend his own performance demand assurances from the breeder and treat a failure by the breeder to give them as an actionable repudiation.
options.optionB: B. Suspend his own performance and recover damages from the breeder for breach of contract unless the breeder at once supplies an undiseased hog of exhibition quality as a substitute for the champion animal.
options.optionC: C. Terminate his own performance and treat the animal's illness as discharging all remaining duties under the contract.
options.optionD: D. Terminate the contract but only if he (the manager) seeks promptly to obtain for the exhibit a suitable substitute for the champion animal from another hog owner.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Supervening impracticability as a ground for rescission of a contract.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The breeder contracted with the manager to exhibit his world champion hog at the state fair, with the breeder to receive an honorarium. However, two days before the fair, the hog became ill with boarsitis, a communicable disease, and would likely be quarantined for a month under state law, making exhibition impossible.
explanation.Rule_Application: A contract may be rescinded due to supervening impracticability where a party's performance becomes impracticable without their fault due to an unexpected event. Here, the hog's illness renders the breeder's performance of exhibiting the specific animal impracticable, as it was a basic assumption of the contract.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the supervening impracticability, the manager should treat both parties' obligations under the contract as discharged, supporting option C.

question: In a signed writing a retired general contracted to purchase a 25-foot travel trailer from a trailer company for $15000 cash on delivery no later than June 1. The general arrived at the trailer company's sales lot on Sunday May 31 to pay for and take delivery of the trailer but refused to do so when he discovered that the spare tire was missing. The trailer company offered to install a spare tire on Monday when its service department would open but the general replied that he did not want the trailer and would purchase another one elsewhere. Which of the following is accurate?

options.optionA: A. The general had a right to reject the trailer but the trailer company was entitled to a reasonable opportunity to cure the defect.
options.optionB: B. The general had a right to reject the trailer and terminate the contract under the perfect tender rule.
options.optionC: C. The general was required to accept the trailer because the defect could be readily cured.
options.optionD: D. The general was required to accept the trailer because the defect did not substantially impair its value.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Perfect tender rule in contracts for the sale of goods under the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC).
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The retired general contracted to purchase a 25-foot travel trailer from a trailer company for $15,000 cash on delivery no later than June 1. The general arrived at the trailer company's sales lot on Sunday May 31 to pay for and take delivery of the trailer but refused to do so when he discovered that the spare tire was missing.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under the UCC, the perfect tender rule allows the buyer to reject a delivery that fails to conform to the contract in any respect. However, the seller must be given an opportunity to cure the defective delivery if the time for performance has not yet expired. In this case, the trailer company's offer to install a spare tire on Monday, May 31, was a seasonable offer to cure the defect.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Therefore, the correct answer is A. The general had a right to reject the trailer but the trailer company was entitled to a reasonable opportunity to cure the defect.

question: A buyer faxed the following signed message to his long-time widget supplier: "Urgently need blue widgets. Ship immediately three gross at your current list price of $600." Upon receipt of the fax the supplier shipped three gross of red widgets to the buyer and faxed to the buyer the following message: "Temporarily out of blue. In case red will help am shipping three gross at the same price. Hope you can use them." Upon the buyer's timely receipt of both the shipment and the supplier's fax which of the following best describes the rights and duties of the buyer and the supplier?

options.optionA: A. The buyer may accept the shipment in which case he must pay the supplier the list price or he must reject the shipment and recover from the supplier for total breach of contract.
options.optionB: B. The buyer may accept the shipment in which case he must pay the supplier the list price or he may reject the shipment in which case he has no further rights against the supplier.
options.optionC: C. The buyer may accept the shipment in which case he must pay the supplier the list price less any damages sustained because of the nonconforming shipment or he may reject the shipment and recover from the supplier for total breach of contract subject to the supplier's right to cure.
options.optionD: D. The buyer may accept the shipment in which case he must pay the supplier the list price less any damages sustained because of the nonconforming shipment or he may reject the shipment provided that he promptly covers by obtaining conforming widgets from another supplier.

explanation.Legal_Concept: UCC provisions on acceptance of goods, particularly in cases where a seller offers non-conforming goods as an accommodation to the buyer.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The buyer faxed an order for blue widgets at a specific price, and the supplier shipped red widgets instead, indicating in a fax that they were temporarily out of blue widgets and hoped the buyer could use the red ones.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under UCC, a shipment of non-conforming goods may not be considered an acceptance if the seller indicates it is offered as an accommodation, which is the case here. Therefore, there is no contract, and the buyer has no right to recover damages against the supplier.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The buyer may accept the shipment and pay the supplier the list price or may reject the shipment with no further rights against the supplier, supporting option B.

question: A flour wholesaler contracted to deliver to a producer of fine baked goods her flour requirements for a one-year period. Before delivery of the first scheduled installment the flour wholesaler sold its business and "assigned" all of its sale contracts to Miller Inc. another reputable and long-time flour wholesaler. The original flour wholesaler informed the baked goods producer of this transaction. Assume that when Miller tendered the first installment to the baked goods producer in compliance with the flour wholesaler-baked goods contract the baked goods producer refused to accept the goods. Which of the following arguments if any legally support(s) the baked goods producer's rejection of the goods? I. Executory requirements contracts are nonassignable. II. Duties under an executory bilateral contract are assumable only by an express promise to perform on the part of the delegatee. III. Language of "assignment" in the transfer for value of bilateral sale-of-goods contract affects only a transfer of rights not a delegation of duties.

options.optionA: A. I only.
options.optionB: B. II and III only.
options.optionC: C. I and II and III.
options.optionD: D. Neither I nor II nor III.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Assignment and delegation of contractual duties under the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) and the potential impact of such assignments on the performance of executory contracts.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: A flour wholesaler sold its business and assigned its sale contracts, including a one-year requirements contract with a baked goods producer, to Miller Inc. The baked goods producer refused to accept the first installment tendered by Miller, claiming the assignment was invalid.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under the UCC, a party may perform its duty through a delegatee unless the other party has a substantial interest in having the original party perform. The assignment of a requirements contract, even if it may potentially affect the seller's burden, will generally be upheld as long as the assignee is comparable to the assignor in terms of reputation and experience.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that Miller is comparable to the flour wholesaler, the assignment should be upheld, and the baked goods producer's rejection of the goods is not legally supported. Therefore, the correct answer is option D, neither I, II, nor III.

question: A flour wholesaler contracted to deliver to a producer of fine baked goods her flour requirements for a one-year period. Before delivery of the first scheduled installment the flour wholesaler sold its business and "assigned" all of its sale contracts to Miller Inc. another reputable and long-time flour wholesaler. The original flour wholesaler informed the baked goods producer of this transaction. Assume that the baked goods producer accepted Miller's delivery of the first installment under the flour wholesaler-baked goods producer contract but that the baked goods producer paid the contract price for that installment to the flour wholesaler and refused to pay anything to Miller. In an action by Miller against the baked goods producer for the contractual amount of the first installment which of the following if any will be an effective defense for the baked goods producer? I. The baked goods producer had not expressly agreed to accept Miller as her flour supplier. II. The baked goods producer's payment of the contractual installment to the flour wholesaler discharged her obligation. III. The flour wholesaler remained obligated to the baked goods producer even though the flour wholesaler had assigned the contract to Miller.

options.optionA: A. I only.
options.optionB: B. II only.
options.optionC: C. I and III only.
options.optionD: D. Neither I nor II nor III.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Assignment of rights and delegation of duties under the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC)
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The flour wholesaler assigned all of its sale contracts to Miller Inc., another reputable flour wholesaler, and informed the baked goods producer. The baked goods producer accepted Miller's delivery of the first installment but paid the contract price to the original flour wholesaler and refused to pay Miller.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under the UCC, a party may perform their duty through a delegatee unless the other party has a substantial interest in having the original party perform. In this case, Miller is comparable to the flour wholesaler, and the baked goods producer should not have a particular interest in having the flour wholesaler perform. Once the assignor receives notice of the assignment, the obligor (baked goods producer) discharges their obligation only by paying the assignee (Miller).
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: None of the defenses are effective. The baked goods producer's payment to the original flour wholesaler did not discharge their obligation, and they should have paid Miller. Therefore, the correct answer is D, neither I nor II nor III.

question: A client consulted a lawyer about handling the sale of the client's building and asked the lawyer what her legal fee would be. The lawyer replied that her usual charge was $100 per hour and estimated that the legal work on behalf of the client would cost about $5000 at that rate. The client said "Okay let's proceed with it" and the lawyer timely and successfully completed the work. Because of unexpected title problems the lawyer reasonably spent 75 hours on the matter and shortly thereafter mailed the client a bill for $7500 with a letter itemizing the work performed and time spent. The client responded by a letter expressing his good-faith belief that the lawyer had agreed to a total fee of no more than $5000. The client enclosed a check in the amount of $5000 payable to the lawyer and conspicuously marked "Payment in full for legal service in connection with the sale of the client's building." Despite reading the "Payment in full. . ." language the lawyer without any notation of protest or reservation of rights endorsed and deposited the check to her bank account. The check was duly paid by the client's bank. A few days later the lawyer unsuccessfully demanded payment from the client of the $2500 difference between the amount of her bill and the check and now sues the client for that difference. What if anything can the lawyer recover from the client?

options.optionA: A. Nothing because the risk of unexpected title problems in a real-property transaction is properly allocatable to the seller's attorney and thus to the lawyer in this case.
options.optionB: B. Nothing because the amount of the lawyer's fee was disputed in good faith by the client and the lawyer impliedly agreed to an accord and satisfaction.
options.optionC: C. $2500 because the client agreed to an hourly rate for as many hours as the work reasonably required and the sum of $5000 was merely an estimate.
options.optionD: D. The reasonable value of the lawyer's services in excess of $5000 if any because there was no specific agreement on the total amount of the lawyer's fee.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Accord and satisfaction, a contractual concept where a debtor offers a lesser payment to a creditor, which if accepted, settles the debt.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The lawyer provided an estimate of $5000 for the legal work, the client agreed, and the lawyer completed the work but unexpectedly spent 75 hours, resulting in a bill of $7500. The client sent a check for $5000 with a note indicating 'Payment in full', the lawyer cashed it without protest.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under the accord and satisfaction doctrine, a creditor's acceptance of a lesser payment, marked 'payment in full', without protest, implies acceptance of the offer, discharging the debt. The client's good-faith belief in the validity of their claim provides sufficient consideration to support the modification.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The lawyer accepted the accord and satisfaction of the debt by cashing the check without protest, and therefore cannot recover any additional amount from the client, supporting option B.

question: On November 1 an accountant and a lawyer contracted for the sale by the accountant to the lawyer of the law books the accountant had inherited from his father. The lawyer agreed to pay the purchase price of $10000 when the accountant delivered the books on December 1. On November 10 the lawyer received a signed letter from the accountant that stated: "I have decided to dispose of the book stacks containing the law books you have already purchased. If you want the stacks I will deliver them to you along with the books on December 1 at no additional cost to you. Let me know before November 15 whether you want them. I will not sell them to anyone else before then." On November 14 the lawyer faxed and the accountant received the following message: "I accept your offer of the stacks." The accountant was not a merchant with respect to either law books or book stacks. The accountant is contractually obligated to deliver the stacks because

options.optionA: A. The lawyer provided a new bargained-for exchange by agreeing to take the stacks.
options.optionB: B. The accountant's letter (received by the lawyer on November 10) and the lawyer's fax-message of November 14 constituted an effective modification of the original sale-of-books contract.
options.optionC: C. The lawyer's fax-message of November 14 operated to rescind unilaterally the original sale-of-books contract.
options.optionD: D. The accountant's letter (received by the lawyer on November 10) waived the bargained-for consideration that would otherwise be required.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Modification of a contract for the sale of goods under the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC)
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The accountant and the lawyer contracted for the sale of law books on November 1 with a delivery date of December 1. On November 10, the accountant offered to deliver the book stacks containing the law books at no additional cost to the lawyer, pending acceptance by November 15. The lawyer accepted this offer on November 14.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under the UCC, a modification of a contract for the sale of goods does not require additional consideration to be binding. The accountant's offer and the lawyer's acceptance constitute a unilateral modification of the original contract.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The accountant is contractually obligated to deliver the stacks because the modification of the original sale-of-books contract was effective, supporting option B.

question: On November 1 an accountant and a lawyer contracted for the sale by the accountant to the lawyer of the law books the accountant had inherited from his father. The lawyer agreed to pay the purchase price of $10000 when the accountant delivered the books on December 1. On November 10 the lawyer received a signed letter from the accountant that stated: "I have decided to dispose of the book stacks containing the law books you have already purchased. If you want the stacks I will deliver them to you along with the books on December 1 at no additional cost to you. Let me know before November 15 whether you want them. I will not sell them to anyone else before then." On November 14 the lawyer faxed and the accountant received the following message: "I accept your offer of the stacks." The accountant was not a merchant with respect to either law books or book stacks. Assume that on November 12 the accountant told the lawyer that he had decided not to part with the stacks. Will this communication operate as a legally effective revocation of his offer to deliver the stacks?

options.optionA: A. Yes because the lawyer had a pre-existing obligation to pay $10000 for the law books.
options.optionB: B. Yes because the accountant was not a merchant with respect to book stacks.
options.optionC: C. No because the accountant had given a signed assurance that the offer would be held open until November 15.
options.optionD: D. No because by delaying his acceptance until November 14 the lawyer detrimentally relied on the accountant's promise not to sell the stacks to anyone else in the meantime.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Firm Offer Rule under the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) and the distinction between merchant and non-merchant sellers.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: On November 10, the accountant sent a signed letter to the lawyer offering to deliver the book stacks if the lawyer wanted them by November 15, with no additional cost. The lawyer faxed acceptance on November 14. However, on November 12, the accountant attempted to revoke the offer.
explanation.Rule_Application: The UCC's firm offer rule only applies to merchants, and the accountant is not a merchant with respect to law books or book stacks. Without consideration, the offer remains revocable at any time prior to acceptance by the lawyer.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: As the accountant's offer did not fall under the UCC firm offer rule, the accountant's communication on November 12 effectively revoked the offer, making option B the correct answer.

question: On November 15 a contractor in a signed writing contracted with a homeowner for an agreed price to personally remodel the homeowner's kitchen according to specifications provided by the homeowner and to start work on December 1. The contractor agreed to provide all materials for the job in addition to all of the labor required. Assume that on November 26 the contractor without legal excuse repudiated the contract and that the homeowner after a reasonable and prolonged effort could not find anyone to remodel his kitchen for a price approximating the price agreed to by the contractor. If one year later the homeowner brings an action for specific performance against the contractor which of the following will provide the contractor with the best defense?

options.optionA: A. An action for equitable relief not brought within a reasonable time is barred by laches.
options.optionB: B. Specific performance is generally not available as a remedy to enforce a contractual duty to perform personal services.
options.optionC: C. Specific performance is generally not available as a remedy in the case of an anticipatory repudiation.
options.optionD: D. Specific performance is not available as a remedy where even nominal damages could have been recovered as a remedy at law.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Specific performance in contract law, particularly in relation to personal service contracts and the limitations of equitable remedies.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The contractor repudiated the contract on November 26, and despite the homeowner's efforts, no suitable replacement was found at a comparable price, resulting in a prolonged delay in the homeowner's kitchen remodel.
explanation.Rule_Application: Specific performance is generally not available as a remedy to enforce a contractual duty to perform personal services. Since the contractor was obligated to personally remodel the kitchen, this contract falls under the personal service category, making specific performance an unsuitable remedy.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the personal service nature of the contract, the contractor's best defense is that specific performance is not available as a remedy, supporting option B.

question: On November 15 a contractor in a signed writing contracted with a homeowner for an agreed price to personally remodel the homeowner's kitchen according to specifications provided by the homeowner and to start work on December 1. The contractor agreed to provide all materials for the job in addition to all of the labor required. On November 26 the homeowner without legal excuse repudiated the contract. Notwithstanding the homeowner's repudiation however the contractor subsequently purchased for $5000 materials that could only be used in remodeling the homeowner's kitchen and promptly notified the homeowner "I will hold you to our contract." If allowed to perform the contractor would have made a profit of $3000 on the job. If the homeowner refuses to retract his repudiation and the contractor sues him for damages what is the maximum that the contractor is entitled to recover?

options.optionA: A. Nothing because he failed to mitigate his damages.
options.optionB: B. $3000 his expectation damages.
options.optionC: C. $5000 on a restitutionary theory.
options.optionD: D. $5000 his reliance damages plus $3000 his expectation damages.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Breach of contract, expectation damages, and mitigation of damages in a construction contract setting
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The homeowner repudiated the contract without legal excuse, and the contractor subsequently purchased materials for the job, notifying the homeowner of his intent to hold him to the contract.
explanation.Rule_Application: The contractor is entitled to recover his expectation damages, which is the profit he would have made if the contract was fulfilled. The contractor is not entitled to recover the $5,000 spent on materials because it was incurred after the breach was notified, and the contractor failed to mitigate damages. The contractor is only entitled to recover $3,000, his expected profit on the job.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The contractor is entitled to recover $3,000, his expectation damages, as the maximum damages. This supports option B.

question: Which of the following fact patterns most clearly suggests an implied-in-fact contract?

options.optionA: A. A county tax assessor mistakenly bills a man for taxes on his neighbor's property which the man in good faith pays.
options.optionB: B. A physician treated a rider without the rider's knowledge or consent while the rider was unconscious as the result of a fall from his horse.
options.optionC: C. A contrator thinking that he was paving the customer's driveway for which the contractor had an express contract mistakenly paved the neighbor's driveway while the neighbor looked on without saying anything or raising any objection.
options.optionD: D. At her mother's request an accountant filled out and filed her mother's "E-Z" income-tax form (a simple short form).

explanation.Legal_Concept: Implied-in-fact contracts and their enforceability based on tacit promises and conduct of the parties
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The scenario involves a contractor mistakenly paving the neighbor's driveway while the neighbor looks on without raising any objections, suggesting an understanding or agreement that the neighbor will compensate the contractor
explanation.Rule_Application: An implied-in-fact contract may be inferred from the parties' conduct, where it can be fairly presumed that the parties understood compensation would be paid for services rendered
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the circumstances, it may be inferred that an implied-in-fact contract exists between the contractor and the neighbor, making option C the correct answer

question: A beverage distribution company agreed in writing with Fizzy Cola Company to serve for three years as a distributor in a six-county area of Fizzy Cola which contains a small amount of caffeine.
