The distribution company promised in the contract to "promote in good faith the sale of Fizzy Cola" in that area; but the contract said nothing about restrictions on the products that the distribution company could distribute. Six months later the distribution company agreed with the Cool Cola Company to distribute its caffeine-free cola beverages in the same six-county area. If Fizzy Cola Company sues the distribution company for breach of their distribution contract which of the following facts if established would most strengthen Fizzy's case?

options.optionA: A. Cool Cola's national advertising campaign disparages the Fizzy Cola product by saying "You don't need caffeine and neither does your cola."
options.optionB: B. Since the distribution company began to distribute Cool Cola the sale of Fizzy Cola have dropped 3% in the six-county area.
options.optionC: C. Prior to signing the contract with Fizzy Cola Company a representative of the distribution company said that the deal with Fizzy would be "an exclusive."
options.optionD: D. For many years in the soft-drink industry it has been uniform practice for distibutors to handle only one brand of cola.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Trade usage under the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) and its role in interpreting contracts
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The distribution contract does not explicitly state whether the distribution company is restricted from distributing competing brands of cola, but trade usage in the soft-drink industry may clarify the parties' understanding of the contract.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under the UCC, trade usage can be used to interpret contracts, as long as it is consistent with the express terms of the contract. In this case, the trade usage of distributors handling only one brand of cola may imply that the distribution company was prohibited from distributing competitors' brands, such as Cool Cola.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The existence of a trade usage in the soft-drink industry where distributors handle only one brand of cola would strengthen Fizzy Cola's case, supporting option D.

question: An amateur computer whiz agreed in writing to design three new games a year for a five-year period for a corporation that distributed TV game systems. The writing provided in a clause separately signed by the computer whiz that "No modifications shall be binding on the corporation unless made in writing and signed by the corporation's authorized representative." Because of family problems the computer whiz delivered and the corporation accepted only two game-designs a year for the first three years; but the games were a commercial success and the corporation made no objection. Accordingly the computer whiz spent substantial sums on new computer equipment that would aid in speeding up future design work. In the first quarter of the fourth year however the corporation terminated the contract on the ground that the computer whiz had breached the annual-quantity term. In the computer whiz's suit against the corporation for damages the jury found that the contract had been modified by conduct and the trial court awarded the computer whiz substantial compensatory damages. Is this result likely to be reversed on appeal?

options.optionA: A. Yes because the contract's no-oral-modification clause was not expressly waived by the corporation.
options.optionB: B. Yes because the contract's no-oral-modification clause was a material part of the agreed exchange and could not be avoided without new consideration.
options.optionC: C. No because the contract's no-oral-modification clause was unconscionable as against an amateur designer.
options.optionD: D. No because the corporation by its conduct waived the annual-quantity term and the computer whiz materially changed his position in reasonable reliance on that waiver.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Waiver by conduct in contract law, particularly the principle that a party can impliedly waive a contractual provision through their actions.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The corporation accepted only two game designs a year for the first three years, despite the agreement specifying three games per year. The corporation made no objections and the computer whiz relied on this by investing in new equipment.
explanation.Rule_Application: A waiver can occur through conduct, where a party treats a breach as only a partial breach and continues to perform the contract. If the non-waiving party relies on the waiver, it becomes irrevocable.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The corporation's acceptance of only two game designs per year for three years constitutes an implied waiver of the annual-quantity term. The computer whiz's reliance on this waiver by investing in new equipment makes it unjust to allow the corporation to retract the waiver. Therefore, the correct answer is option D, no reversal on appeal.

question: A U.S. manufacturer on the west coast gave a hardware retailer who was relocating to the east coast the following "letter of introduction" to a hardware wholesaler on the east coast. This will introduce you to my good friend and former customer a hardware retailer who will be seeking to arrange the purchase of hardware inventory from you on credit. If you will let him have the goods I will make good any loss up to $25000 in the event of his /Signed/ manufacturer. The hardware retailer presented the letter to the hardware wholesaler who then sold and delivered $20000 worth of hardware to the hardware retailer on credit. The hardware wholesaler promptly notified the manufacturer of this sale. Which of the following is NOT an accurate statement concerning the arrangement between the manufacturer and the hardware wholesaler?

options.optionA: A. It was important to enforceability of the manufacturer's promise to the hardware wholesaler that it be embodied in a signed writing.
options.optionB: B. By extending the credit to the hardware retailer the hardware wholesaler effectively accepted the manufacturer's offer for a unilateral contract.
options.optionC: C. Although the manufacturer received no consideration from the hardware retailer the manufacturer's promise is enforceable by the hardware wholesaler.
options.optionD: D. The manufacturer's promise is enforceable by the hardware wholesaler whether or not the hardware wholesaler gave the manufacturer seasonable notice of the extension of credit to the hardware retailer.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Unilateral contracts and the requirement of seasonable notice of acceptance.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The manufacturer provided a letter of introduction to a hardware wholesaler stating that if the wholesaler sold hardware to a hardware retailer on credit, the manufacturer would make good on any loss up to $25000. The wholesaler then extended credit to the retailer and notified the manufacturer of the sale.
explanation.Rule_Application: An offer for a unilateral contract requires acceptance by performance and not a return promise. However, where the offeree has reason to know that the offeror will not learn of the acceptance without notice, the offeree must give seasonable notice of acceptance to the promisor.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The hardware wholesaler's notice of the sale to the manufacturer was a necessary component of the unilateral contract, making option D an inaccurate statement.

question: A broker needed a certain rare coin to complete a set that he had contracted to assemble and sell to a collector. On February 1 the broker obtained such a coin from a hoarder in exchange for $1000 and the broker's signed written promise to re-deliver to the hoarder "not later than December 31 this year" a comparable specimen of the same kind of coin without charge to the hoarder. On February 2 the broker consummated sale of the complete set to the collector.  On October 1 the market price of rare coins suddenly began a rapid sustained rise; and on October 15 the hoarder wrote the broker for assurance that the latter would timely meet his coin-replacement commitment. The broker replied "In view of the surprising market it seems unfair that I should have to replace your coin within the next few weeks." Having received the broker's message on October 17 the hoarder sued the broker on November 15 for the market value of a comparable replacement-coin as promised by the broker in February. The trial began on December 1. If the broker moves to dismiss the hoarder's complaint which of the following is the broker's best argument in support of the motion?

options.optionA: A. The broker did not repudiate the contract on October 17 and may still perform no later than the contract deadline of December 31.
options.optionB: B. Even if the broker repudiated on October 17 the hoarder's only action would be for specific performance because the coin is a unique chattel.
options.optionC: C. Under the doctrine of impossibility which includes unusually burdensome and unforseen impracticability the broker is temporarily excused by the market conditions from timely performance of his coin-replacement obligation.
options.optionD: D. Even if the broker repudiated on October 17 the hoarder has no remedy without first demanding in writing that the broker retract his repudiation.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Repudiation and assurance of due performance in contracts under the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC).
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The hoarder requested assurance of the broker's performance on October 15. The broker responded on October 17, suggesting it would be unfair to meet the coin-replacement commitment given the sudden market price rise.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under the UCC, a party may make a written demand for assurance of due performance if reasonable grounds for insecurity arise. Failure to provide such assurance within a reasonable time may be treated as repudiation of the contract. However, the insecurity must relate to the other party's ability or willingness to perform. In this case, the broker's October 17 reply does not manifest a repudiation of the contract, as it does not unequivocally state an inability or unwillingness to perform.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the broker's October 17 response does not constitute repudiation of the contract, the broker's best argument in support of the motion to dismiss the hoarder's complaint is that the broker may still perform on or before the contract deadline of December 31, supporting option A.

question: A broker needed a certain rare coin to complete a set that he had contracted to assemble and sell to a collector. On February 1 the broker obtained such a coin from a hoarder in exchange for $1000 and the broker's signed written promise to re-deliver to the hoarder "not later than December 31 this year" a comparable specimen of the same kind of coin without charge to the hoarder. On February 2 the broker consummated sale of the complete set to the collector. On October 1 the market price of rare coins suddenly began a rapid sustained rise; on October 15 the hoarder wrote the broker for assurance that the latter would timely meet his coin-replacement commitment. The broker replied "In view of the surprising market it seems unfair that I should have to replace your coin within the next few weeks." After receiving the broker's message on October 17 the hoarder telephoned the broker who said "I absolutely will not replace your coin until the market drops far below its present level." The hoarder then sued the broker on November 15 for the market value of a comparable replacement-coin as promised by the broker in February. The trial began on December 1. If the broker moves to dismiss the hoarder's complaint which of the following is the hoarder's best argument in opposing the motion.

options.optionA: A. The hoarder's implied duty of good faith and fair dealing in enforcement of the contract required her to mitigate her losses on the rising market by suing promptly as she did after becoming reasonably apprehensive of a prospective breach by the broker.
options.optionB: B. Although the doctrine of anticipatory breach is not applicable under the prevailing view if at the time of repudiation the repudiatee owes the repudiator no remaining duty of performance the doctrine applies in this case because the hoarder the repudiatee remains potentially liable under an implied warranty that the coin advanced to the broker was genuine.
options.optionC: C. When either party to a sale-of-goods contract repudiates with respect to a performance not yet due the loss of which will substantially impair the value of the contract to the other the aggrieved party may in good faith resort to any appropriate remedy for breach.
options.optionD: D. Anticipatory repudiation as a deliberate disruption without legal excuse of an ongoing contractual relationship between the parties may be treated by the repudiatee at her election as a present tort actionable at once.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Anticipatory repudiation and breach of contract in the context of sale-of-goods contracts under the UCC.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: On October 17, the broker unequivocally stated that he will not replace the hoarder's coin until the market drops, demonstrating an intention to breach the contract.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under the UCC, when either party repudiates a contract with respect to a future performance that will substantially impair the contract's value, the non-repudiating party may resort to any appropriate remedy for breach.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the broker's clear repudiation, the hoarder is entitled to treat it as a total breach of contract and seek remedies. This supports option C as the hoarder's best argument in opposing the motion to dismiss.

question: A ski-shop operator in a telephone conversation with a glove manufacturer ordered 12 pairs of vortex-lined ski gloves at the glove manufacturer's list price of $600 per dozen "for delivery in 30 days." The glove manufacturer orally accepted the offer and immediately faxed to the ski-shop operator this signed memo: "Confirming our agreement today for your purchase of a dozen pairs of vortex-lined ski gloves for $600 the shipment will be delivered in 30 days." Although the ski-shop operator received and read the glove manufacturer's message within minutes after its dispatch she changed her mind three weeks later about the purchase and rejected the conforming shipment when it timely arrived. On learning of the rejection does the glove manufacturer have a cause of action against the ski-shop operator for breach of contract?

options.optionA: A. Yes because the gloves were identified in the contract and tendered to the ski-shop operator.
options.optionB: B. Yes because the glove manufacturer's faxed memo to the ski-shop operator was sufficient to make the agreement enforceable.
options.optionC: C. No because the agreed price was $600 and the ski-shop operator never signed a writing evidencing a contract with the glove manufacturer.
options.optionD: D. No because the ski-shop operator neither paid for nor accepted any of the goods tendered.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The Statute of Frauds provision in the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) regarding contracts for the sale of goods worth $500 or more, and the exception to the rule when a written confirmation of a contract is sent between merchants.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The contract between the ski-shop operator and the glove manufacturer is for $600 worth of vortex-lined ski gloves with a 30-day delivery period, and the glove manufacturer sent a signed faxed memo confirming the agreement, which the ski-shop operator received and read but failed to object to within 10 days.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under the UCC, a contract for the sale of goods worth $500 or more must be evidenced by a signed writing. However, an exception applies when the contract is between merchants, a written confirmation is sent, and the recipient fails to give notice of objection within 10 days. In this case, the glove manufacturer's faxed memo meets the exception criteria.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The glove manufacturer has a cause of action against the ski-shop operator for breach of contract, as the signed faxed memo confirms the agreement and meets the exception to the Statute of Frauds provision, supporting option B.

question: A burglar stole a collector's impressionist painting valued at $400000. The collector who had insured the painting for $300000 with an insurance company promised to pay $25000 to a full-time investigator for the insurance company if he effected the return of the painting to her in good condition. By company rules the insurance company permits its investigators to accept and retain rewards from policyholders for the recovery of insured property. The investigator by long and skillful detective work recovered the picture and returned it undamaged to the collector. If the collector refuses to pay the investigator anything and he sues her for $25000 what is the probable result under the prevailing modern rule?

options.optionA: A. The collector wins because the investigator owed the insurance company a preexisting duty to recover the picture if possible.
options.optionB: B. The collector wins because the insurance company the investigator's employer had a preexisting duty to return the recovered painting to the collector.
options.optionC: C. The investigator wins because the collector will benefit more from return of the $400000 painting than from receiving the $300000 policy proceeds.
options.optionD: D. The investigator wins because the preexisting duty rule does not apply if the promisee's (the investigator's) duty was owed to a third person.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Pre-existing duty rule in contract law, specifically the exception when the pre-existing duty is owed to a third party
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The investigator, employed by the insurance company, recovered the painting and returned it to the collector. The collector promised to pay the investigator $25,000 for the return of the painting in good condition
explanation.Rule_Application: The pre-existing duty rule does not apply when the duty is owed to a third party. In this case, the investigator's duty was owed to the insurance company, not the collector. The collector's promise to pay the investigator was therefore supported by sufficient consideration
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The probable result is that the investigator wins and the collector must pay the $25,000 as promised, supporting option D

question: A girl who was a minor both in fact and appearance bought on credit and took delivery of a telescope from 30-year-old seller for an agreed price of $100. Upon reaching the age of majority soon thereafter the girl encountered the seller and said "I am sorry for not having paid you that $100 for the telescope when the money was due but I found out it was only worth $75. So I now promise to pay you $75." The girl subsequently repudiated this promise and refused to pay anything. In an action for breach of contract by the seller against the girl the seller's probable recovery is

options.optionA: A. nothing because the girl was a minor at the time of the original transaction.
options.optionB: B. nothing because there was no consideration for the promise made by the girl after reaching majority.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Enforceability of promises made in recognition of past benefits conferred, specifically the exception to the rule for reaffirmed promises made after reaching majority.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The girl purchased a telescope on credit as a minor, with an agreed price of $100. Upon reaching majority, she promised to pay $75, claiming the telescope was worth less. She then repudiated this promise and refused to pay anything.
explanation.Rule_Application: A promise reaffirming a prior, unenforceable promise (due to infancy) is enforceable if made after reaching majority and lacking consideration. This exception applies as the girl's initial promise was not enforceable due to her minority, but her subsequent promise is enforceable.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The seller's probable recovery is $75, as the girl's promise to pay that amount after reaching majority is enforceable under the exception to the rule, supporting option C.

question: A women bought on credit and took delivery of a telescope from a seller for an agreed price of $100. The woman promised to pay the seller "as soon as I am able." The woman subsequently repudiated this promise and refused to pay the seller anything. What effect does this quoted language have on enforceability of the promise?

options.optionA: A. None.
options.optionB: B. It makes the promise illusory.
options.optionC: C. It requires the woman to prove her inability to pay.
options.optionD: D. It requires the seller to prove the woman's ability to pay.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Consideration and illusory promises in contract law, particularly the enforceability of promises with conditional or discretionary elements.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The woman promised to pay the seller $100 for the telescope, conditioning her payment on her ability to do so. She subsequently refused to pay, raising questions about the enforceability of her original promise.
explanation.Rule_Application: A promise is considered illusory if it reserves the right of alternative performances or unconditional discretion. However, courts may construe such promises to include good faith obligations, making them enforceable. Here, the woman's promise to pay 'as soon as I am able' implies an obligation to pay when she has the ability, making it a valid consideration.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The quoted language does not make the promise illusory, but rather establishes a conditional obligation to pay when the woman is able. Therefore, the seller must prove the woman's ability to pay to enforce the promise, supporting option D.

question: A patient owed a physician $25000 for professional services. The physician orally assigned this claim to her adult daughter as a wedding gift. Shortly thereafter on suffering sudden severe losses in the stock market the physician assigned by a signed writing the same claim to her stockbroker in partial satisfaction of advances legally made by the stockbroker in the physician's previous stock-market transactions. Subsequently the patient without knowledge of either assignment paid the physician the $25000 then due which the physician promptly lost at a horse track although she remains solvent. Assuming that Article 9 of the Uniform Commercial Code does NOT apply to either of the assignments in this situation which of the following is a correct statement of the parties' rights and liabilities?

options.optionA: A. As the assignee prior in time the daughter can recover $25000 from the patient who acted at her peril in paying the physician.
options.optionB: B. As the sole assignee for value the stockbroker can recover $25000 from the patient who acted at her peril in paying the physician.
options.optionC: C. Neither the daughter nor the stockbroker can recover from the patient but the daughter though not the stockbroker can recover $25000 from the physician.
options.optionD: D. Neither the daughter nor the stockbroker can recover from the patient but the stockbroker though not the daughter can recover $25000 from the physician.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Assignment of a contract right, specifically the effect of a gratuitous assignment and a subsequent assignment for value
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The physician made a gratuitous assignment of the $25,000 claim to her daughter and then made a subsequent assignment for value to the stockbroker. The patient, unaware of either assignment, paid the physician the owed amount, which the physician lost at a horse track.
explanation.Rule_Application: A gratuitous assignment can be revoked by the assignor prior to the obligor's payment or the assignee's reliance on the assignment. In this case, the physician's assignment to the daughter was revoked by the subsequent assignment to the stockbroker for value. The patient's payment to the physician discharged the debt, but the stockbroker's rights to the claim were not affected.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Neither the daughter nor the stockbroker can recover from the patient, but the stockbroker can recover $25,000 from the physician, supporting option D.

question: On July 15 in a writing signed by both parties a fixture company agreed to deliver to a druggist on August 15 five storage cabinets from inventory for a total price of $5000 to be paid on delivery. On August 1 the two parties orally agreed to postpone the delivery date to August 20. On August 20 the fixture company tendered the cabinets to the druggist who refused to accept or pay for them on the ground that they were not tendered on August 15 even though they otherwise met the contract specifications. Assuming that all appropriate defenses are seasonably raised will the fixture company succeed in an action against the druggist for breach of contract?

options.optionA: A. Yes because neither the July 15 agreement nor the August 1 agreement was required to be in writing.
options.optionB: B. Yes because the August 1 agreement operated as a waiver of the August 15 delivery term.
options.optionC: C. No because there was no consideration to support the August 1 agreement.
options.optionD: D. No because the parol evidence rule will prevent proof of the August 1 agreement.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Waiver in contract law, specifically the enforceability of a waiver without consideration when it involves a non-material term of an agreement.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: A fixture company and a druggist entered into a written agreement on July 15 with a delivery date of August 15. They later orally agreed to postpone delivery to August 20. The fixture company tendered the cabinets on August 20, but the druggist refused to accept them, citing the original delivery date.
explanation.Rule_Application: A waiver of a non-material term of an agreement is enforceable without consideration. The August 1 oral agreement operated as a waiver of the August 15 delivery term, which was a non-material term. The fixture company fulfilled its obligation by tendering the cabinets on August 20, as agreed upon.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Since the waiver was enforceable, the fixture company will succeed in an action against the druggist for breach of contract, supporting option B.

question: By the terms of a written contract signed by both parties on January 15 a computer store agreed to sell a specific ICB personal computer to a customer for $3000 and the customer agreed to pick up and pay for the computer at the store on February 1. The customer unjustifiably repudiated on February 1. Without notifying the customer the store subsequently sold at private sale the same specific computer to a different buyer who paid the same price ($3000) in cash. The ICB is a popular product. The computer store can buy from the manufacturer more units than it can sell at retail. If the store sues the customer for breach of contract the store will probably recover

options.optionA: A. nothing because it received a price on resale equal to the contract price that the customer had agreed to pay.
options.optionB: B. nothing because the store failed to give the customer proper notice of the store's intention to resell.
options.optionC: C. the store's anticipated profit on the sale to the customer plus incidental damages if any because the store lost that sale.
options.optionD: D. $3000 (the contract price) because the customer intentionally breached the contract by repudiation.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Breach of contract, specifically the damages recoverable by a seller under the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) in the context of a buyer's repudiation.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The customer breached the contract by unjustifiably repudiating on the agreed upon date, and the computer store subsequently sold the same computer to a different buyer at the same price ($3,000). The store did not notify the customer of the resale.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under the UCC, a seller can recover damages for a buyer's breach, including the difference between the contract price and the resale price or the market price, plus incidental damages. In this case, since the resale price equals the contract price, the store may recover its lost profit on the sale, plus incidental damages, as it is a 'lost volume' seller that could have made the sale profitably if the contract had been fulfilled.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The computer store will likely recover its anticipated profit on the sale to the customer, plus incidental damages, as it was a 'lost volume' seller that could have made the sale profitably if the contract had been fulfilled, supporting option C.

question: In a single writing a painter contracted with a farmer to paint three identical barns on her rural estate for $2000 each. The contract provided for the farmer's payment of $6000 upon the painter's completion of the work on all three barns. The painter did not ask for any payment when the first barn was completely painted but she demanded $4000 after painting the second barn. Is the farmer obligated to make the $4000 payment?

options.optionA: A. No because the farmer has no duty under the contract to pay anything to the painter until all three barns have been painted.
options.optionB: B. No because the painter waived her right if any to payment on a per-barn basis by failing to demand $2000 upon completion of the first barn.
options.optionC: C. Yes because the contract is divisible.
options.optionD: D. Yes because the painter has substantially performed the entire contract.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Constructive conditions in contracts, particularly the doctrine that a party's obligation is conditional upon the other party's substantial performance.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The painter contracted with the farmer to paint three identical barns for a total of $6000, payable upon completion of all three barns. The painter has completed two barns and is demanding $4000, which is not a payment schedule specified in the contract.
explanation.Rule_Application: In contracts where performance requires a period of time, the other party's performance is conditional upon substantial completion of the obligation, unless the contract specifies otherwise. In this case, the contract explicitly states payment is due upon completion of all three barns, not upon completion of individual barns.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The farmer is not obligated to make the $4000 payment because the painter has not substantially completed the entire contract, which is the condition precedent for the farmer's payment obligation, supporting option A.

question: In a single writing Painter contracted with Farmer to paint three identical barns on her rural estate for $2000 each. The contract provided for Farmer's payment of $6000 upon Painter's completion of the work on all three barns. Painter did not ask for any payment when the first barn was completely painted but she demanded $4000 after painting the second barn. Assume that Farmer rightfully refused Painter's demand for payment. If Painter immediately terminates the contract without painting the third barn what is Painter entitled to recover from Farmer?

options.optionA: A. Nothing because payment was expressly conditioned on completion of all three barns.
options.optionB: B. Painter's expenditures plus anticipated "profit" in painting the first two barns up to a maximum recovery of $4000.
options.optionC: C. The reasonable value of Painter's services in painting the two barns less Farmer's damages if any for Painter's failure to paint the third barn.
options.optionD: D. The amount that the combined value of the two painted barns has been increased by Painter's work.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Restitution and part performance in contract law, specifically the entitlement of a breaching party to recover the reasonable value of conferred benefits less any damages incurred by the non-breaching party.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: Painter contracted with Farmer to paint three identical barns for $6,000, with payment conditional on completing all three. Painter completed two barns but refused to continue, demanding $4,000. Farmer rightfully refused, and Painter terminated the contract.
explanation.Rule_Application: In restitution, a breaching party can recover the reasonable value of their services, minus any damages incurred by the non-breaching party. Here, Painter is entitled to recover the value of painting two barns, minus any additional costs Farmer may incur to complete the third barn.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Painter is entitled to recover the reasonable value of painting the two barns, less any damages incurred by Farmer, as specified in option C.

question: On December 15 a lawyer received from a retailer of supplies an offer consisting of its catalog and a signed letter stating "We will supply you with as many of the items in the enclosed catalog as you order during the next calendar year. We assure you that this offer and the prices in the catalog will remain firm throughout the coming year." Assume that no other correspondence passed between the retailer and the lawyer until the following April 15 (four months later) when the retailer received from the lawyer a faxed order for "100 reams of your paper catalog item #101." Did the lawyer's April 15 fax constitute an effective acceptance of the retailer's offer at the prices specified in the catalog?

options.optionA: A. Yes because the retailer had not revoked its offer before April 15.
options.optionB: B. Yes because a one-year option contract had been created by the retailer's offer.
options.optionC: C. No because under applicable law the irrevocability of the retailer's offer was limited to a period of three months.
options.optionD: D. No because the lawyer did not accept the retailer's offer within a reasonable time.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Firm Offer Rule under the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC)
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The retailer made a signed written offer to supply goods to the lawyer for a year, with an assurance that the offer and prices would remain firm for the coming year. The lawyer received the offer on December 15 and did not respond until April 15, when they faxed an order for goods.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under the UCC's firm offer rule, a merchant's signed written offer that gives assurance it will remain firm is irrevocable for a reasonable time, but in no case longer than three months. However, if accepted before revocation or lapse, the offer becomes a binding contract.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Since the lawyer accepted the offer before the three-month period lapsed and before any revocation by the retailer, the acceptance is effective, and the retailer is bound to supply the goods at the prices specified in the catalog, supporting option A.

question: On December 15 a lawyer received from a retailer of supplies an offer consisting of its catalog and a signed letter stating "We will supply you with as many of the items in the enclosed catalog as you order during the next calendar year. We assure you that this offer and the prices in the catalog will remain firm throughout the coming year." Assume that on January 15 having at that time received no reply from the lawyer the retailer notified the lawyer that effective February 1 it was increasing the prices of certain specified items in its catalog. Is the price increase effective with respect to catalog orders the retailer receives from the lawyer during the month of February?

options.optionA: A. No because the retailer's original offer including the price term became irrevocable under the doctrine of promissory estoppel.
options.optionB: B. No because the retailer is a merchant with respect to office supplies; and its original offer including the price term was irrevocable throughout the month of February.
options.optionC: C. Yes because the retailer received no consideration to support its assurance that it would not increase prices.
options.optionD: D. Yes because the period for which the retailer gave assurance that it would not raise prices was longer than three months.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Firm Offer Rule under the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC), specifically the irrevocability of an offer for the sale of goods when made by a merchant in a signed writing.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The retailer, a merchant, made an offer to the lawyer on December 15 with a signed letter and catalog, assuring firm prices throughout the coming year. On January 15, the retailer notified the lawyer of a price increase effective February 1 for certain items.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under the UCC, a merchant's firm offer contained in a signed writing remains irrevocable for a period not exceeding three months. Since the offer was made on December 15 and the price increase was notified on January 15, the three-month period has not yet elapsed, making the offer still firm.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the retailer's offer was a firm offer under the UCC, and the three-month period has not yet expired, the price increase is not effective with respect to catalog orders received from the lawyer during February, supporting option B.

question: A buyer contracted in writing with a shareholder who owned all of XYZ Corporation's outstanding stock to purchase all of her stock at a specified price per share. At the time this contract was executed the buyer's contracting officer said to the shareholder "Of course our commitment to buy is conditioned on our obtaining approval of the contract from our parent company." The shareholder replied "Fine. No problem." Assume that the parent company orally approved the contract but that the shareholder changed her mind and refused to consummate the sale on two grounds: (1) when the agreement was made there was no consideration for her promise to sell and (2) the parent company's approval of the contract was invalid. If the buyer sues the shareholder for breach of contract is the buyer likely to prevail?

options.optionA: A. Yes because the buyer's promise to buy bargained for and made in exchange for the shareholder's promise to sell was good consideration even though it was expressly conditioned on an event that was not certain to occur.
options.optionB: B. Yes because any possible lack of consideration for the shareholder's promise to sell was expressly waived by the shareholder when the agreement was made.
options.optionC: C. No because mutuality of obligation between parties was lacking when the agreement was made.
options.optionD: D. No because the condition of the parent company's approval of the contract was an essential part of the agreed exchange and was not in a signed writing.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Consideration in contract law, specifically the concept of illusory promises and conditional obligations
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The shareholder and buyer entered into a written contract for the sale of the shareholder's stock, where the buyer's contracting officer verbally stated that the sale was conditioned on the buyer's parent company's approval, to which the shareholder agreed. The parent company orally approved the contract, but the shareholder later refused to complete the sale, claiming lack of consideration and invalid approval.
explanation.Rule_Application: A promise is considered illusory if the promisor reserves the right of alternative performances or unconditional cancellation. However, if the obligation is conditioned upon an event outside of the promisor's control, the promise is not illusory. In this case, the buyer's obligation was conditioned upon the parent company's approval, which is outside of the buyer's control, making the promise valid.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The buyer's promise to buy is valid consideration for the shareholder's promise to sell, making the contract enforceable. Therefore, the buyer is likely to prevail in a breach of contract suit, supporting option A.

question: A buyer contracted in writing with a shareholder who owned all of XYZ Corporation's outstanding stock to purchase all of her stock at a specified price per share. At the time this contract was executed the buyer's contracting officer said to the shareholder "Of course our commitment to buy is conditioned on our obtaining approval of the contract from our parent company." The shareholder replied "Fine. No problem." The shareholder subsequently refused to consummate the sale on the ground that the buyer had neglected to request the parent company's approval of the contract which was true. The parent company's chief executive officer however is prepared to testify that the parent company would have routinely approved the contract if requested to do so. The buyer can also prove that he has made a substantial sale of other assets to finance the stock purchase although he admittedly had not anticipated any such necessity when he entered into the stock purchase agreement. If the buyer sues the shareholder for breach of contract is the buyer likely to prevail?

options.optionA: A. Yes because the condition of the parent company's approval of the contract being designed to protect only the buyer and the parent company can be and has been waived by those entities.
options.optionB: B. Yes because the buyer detrimentally relied on the shareholder's commitment by selling off other assets to finance the stock purchase.
options.optionC: C. No because the express condition of the parent company's approval had not occurred prior to the lawsuit.
options.optionD: D. No because obtaining the parent company's approval of the contract was an event within the buyer's control and the buyer's failure to obtain it was itself a material breach of contract.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Express conditions in contracts, specifically the effect of non-occurrence of an express condition on contractual obligations
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The buyer and shareholder entered into a written contract for the buyer to purchase all of the shareholder's stock, with the buyer's officer stating that the commitment was conditioned on obtaining approval from the buyer's parent company. The shareholder subsequently refused to complete the sale, citing the buyer's failure to request this approval
explanation.Rule_Application: An express condition in a contract affects the obligation of the party subject to the condition. If the nonoccurrence of the condition has been waived by that party, the contractual obligation remains. Here, the buyer's commitment to buy was conditioned on the parent company's approval, but the buyer and the parent company are ready to consummate the sale, indicating a waiver of the nonoccurrence of the condition
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the waiver of the nonoccurrence of the condition by the buyer and the parent company, the buyer is likely to prevail in a lawsuit against the shareholder for breach of contract, supporting option A

question: A buyer contracted in writing with a shareholder who owned all of XYZ Corporation's outstanding stock to purchase all of her stock at a specified price per share. At the time this contract was executed the buyer's contracting officer said to the shareholder "Of course our commitment to buy is conditioned on our obtaining approval of the contract from our parent company." The shareholder replied "Fine. No problem." The shareholder is willing and ready to consummate the sale of her stock to the buyer but the latter refuses to perform on the ground (which is true) that the parent company has firmly refused to approve the contract. If the shareholder sues the buyer for breach of contract and seeks to exclude any evidence of the oral condition requiring the parent company's approval the court will probably

options.optionA: A. admit the evidence as proof of a collateral agreement.
options.optionB: B. admit the evidence as proof of a condition to the existence of an enforceable obligation and therefore not within the scope of the parol evidence rule.
options.optionC: C. exclude the evidence on the basis of a finding that the parties' written agreement was a complete integration of their contract.
options.optionD: D. exclude the evidence as contradicting the terms of the parties' written agreement whether or not the writing was a complete integration of the contract.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Parol Evidence Rule, particularly the exception for extrinsic evidence of a condition to the existence of an enforceable obligation.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: A buyer and a shareholder entered into a written contract for the buyer to purchase all of the shareholder's stock. During the execution of the contract, the buyer mentioned that their commitment to buy was conditioned on obtaining approval from their parent company, and the shareholder agreed.
explanation.Rule_Application: The parol evidence rule generally bars extrinsic evidence of prior agreements, but an exception applies when the evidence is offered to prove a condition to the existence of an enforceable obligation. In this scenario, the buyer's mention of the condition to obtain approval from their parent company is admissible as evidence of a condition to the contract.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the evidence of the oral condition requiring approval from the parent company is admissible, the court will likely admit the evidence, supporting option B.

question: A tenant rented a commercial building from a landlord and operated a business in it. The building's large front window was smashed by vandals six months before expiration of the tenant-landlord lease. The tenant who was obligated thereunder to effect and pay for repairs in such cases promptly contracted with a window company to replace the window for $2000 due 30 days after satisfactory completion of work. The landlord was then unaware of the tenant-window company contract. The window company was aware that the building was under lease but dealt entirely with the tenant. Sixty days after the window company's satisfactory completion of the window replacement and prior to the expiration of the tenant's lease the tenant then insolvent ceased doing business and vacated the building. In so doing the tenant forfeited under the lease provisions its right to the return of a $2000 security deposit with the landlord. The deposit had been required however for the express purpose (as stated in the lease) of covering any damage to the leased property except ordinary wear and tear. The only such damage occurring during the tenant's occupancy was the smashed window. The window company's $2000 bill for the window replacement is wholly unpaid. Assuming that the window company has no remedy quasi in rem under the relevant state mechanic's lien statute which of the following would provide the window company's best chance of an effective remedy in personam against the landlord?

options.optionA: A. An action in quasi contract for the reasonable value of a benefit unofficiously and non-gratuitously conferred on the landlord.
options.optionB: B. An action based on promissory estoppel.
options.optionC: C. An action based on an implied-in-fact contract.
options.optionD: D. An action as third-party intended beneficiary of the tenant-landlord lease.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Restitution, quasi-contract, and unjust enrichment in contract law, particularly the doctrine of restitution to recover the value of a benefit conferred on another party.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: A tenant contracted with a window company to repair a smashed window in a building leased from a landlord. The tenant, who was responsible for repairs, went insolvent and forfeited a security deposit meant to cover damages.
explanation.Rule_Application: Generally, a party that confers a benefit cannot recover in restitution from a third party if they have a contract with another. However, exceptions exist where the third party has not paid for the work and the claimant has no other avenues for recovery. In this case, the landlord benefited from the window company's work, the tenant is insolvent, and the lease contemplated the tenant's responsibility for repairs.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Considering the circumstances, the window company's best chance of an effective remedy in personam against the landlord would be an action in quasi contract for the reasonable value of the benefit conferred on the landlord, supporting option A.

question: A tenant rented a commercial building from a landlord and operated a business in it. The building's large front window was smashed by vandals six months before expiration of the tenant-landlord lease. The tenant who was obligated thereunder to effect and pay for repairs in such cases promptly contracted with a window company to replace the window for $2000 due 30 days after satisfactory completion of work. The landlord was then unaware of the tenant-window company contract. The window company was aware that the building was under lease but dealt entirely with the tenant. Sixty days after the window company's satisfactory completion of the window replacement and prior to the expiration of the tenant's lease the tenant then insolvent ceased doing business and vacated the building. In so doing the tenant forfeited under the lease provisions its right to the return of a $2000 security deposit with the landlord. The deposit had been required however for the express purpose (as stated in the lease) of covering any damage to the leased property except ordinary wear and tear. The only such damage occuring during the tenant's occupancy was the smashed window. The window company's $2000 bill for the window replacement is wholly unpaid. Upon vacating the building the tenant mailed a $1000 check to the window company bearing on its face the following conspicuous notation: "This check is in full and final satisfaction of your $2000 window replacement bill." Without noticing this notation the window company cashed the check and now sues the tenant for the $1000 difference. If the tenant's only defense is accord and satisfaction is the tenant likely to prevail?

options.optionA: A. No because the window company failed to notice the tenant's notation on the check.
options.optionB: B. No because the amount owed by the tenant to the window company was liquidated and undisputed.
options.optionC: C. Yes because by cashing the check the window company impliedly agreed to accept the $1000 as full payment of its claim.
options.optionD: D. Yes because the window company failed to write a reservation-of-rights notation on the check before cashing it.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Accord and satisfaction, a contractual concept in which a debtor offers to settle a debt through a partial payment, with the creditor's acceptance implying full satisfaction of the debt.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The tenant, as debtor, mailed a check to the window company, as creditor, with a conspicuous notation stating it was in full and final satisfaction of the $2,000 window replacement bill. The window company cashed the check without noticing the notation.
explanation.Rule_Application: For an accord and satisfaction to be enforceable, the debt must be genuinely in dispute, meaning the amount owed or basis for the debt is uncertain or disputed. Here, the amount owed was liquidated and undisputed, as the tenant was obligated to pay $2,000 for the window replacement.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the debt was not in dispute and the amount owed was clear, the tenant's attempt to use accord and satisfaction is unlikely to prevail, supporting option B.

question: A potential buyer telegraphed a vendor on June 1 "At what price will you sell 100 of your QT-Model garbage-disposal units for delivery around June 10?" Thereafter the following communications were exchanged: “i. Telegram from the vendor received by the potential buyer on June 2: “"You're in luck. We have only 100 QT's all on clearance at 50% off usual wholesale of $120 per unit for delivery at our shipping platform on June 12."” “ii. Letter from the potential buyer received in U.S. mail by the vendor on June 5: "I accept. Would prefer to pay in full 30 days after invoice."” “iii. Telegram from the vendor received by the potential buyer on June 6: "You must pick up at our platform and pay C.O.D."” “iv. Letter from the potential buyer received in U.S. mail by the vendor on June 9: "I don't deal with people who can't accommodate our simple requests."” “v. Telegram from the potential buyer received by the vendor on June 10 after the vendor has sold and delivered all of the QT's to another buyer earlier that day: "Okay. I'm over a barrel and will pick up the goods on your terms June 12."” The potential buyer now sues the vendor for breach of contract. Which of the following arguments will best serve the vendor's defense?

options.optionA: A. The vendor's telegram received on June 2 was merely a price quotation not an offer.
options.optionB: B. The potential buyer's letter received on June 5 was not an acceptance because it varied the terms of the vendor's initial telegram.
options.optionC: C. The potential buyer's use of the mail in response to the vendor's initial telegram was an ineffective method of acceptance.
options.optionD: D. The potential buyer's letter received on June 9 was an unequivocal refusal to perform that excused the vendor even if the parties had previously formed a contract.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Formation of contracts for the sale of goods under the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC)
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The sequence of events involved multiple communications between the potential buyer and the vendor, including a telegram with a price quotation, acceptance letters with varying terms, and subsequent rejections or repudiations.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under the UCC, a written acceptance of a contract for the sale of goods can operate as such even if it states additional or different terms. However, these additional terms do not become part of the contract if they materially alter it, unless the offeror expressly agrees. A later communication from one party repudiating the agreement can excuse the other party from performance.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The vendor's best defense is that the potential buyer's letter received on June 9 unequivocally refused to perform under the previously formed contract, which excused the vendor from further obligations. This supports option D.

question: A famous chef entered into a written agreement with his friend a well-known interior decorator respected for his unique designs in which the decorator agreed for a fixed fee to design the interior of the chef's new restaurant and upon the chef's approval of the design plan to decorate and furnish the restaurant accordingly. The agreement was silent as to assignment or delegation by either party. Before beginning the work the decorator sold his decorating business to Newman under an agreement in which the decorator assigned to Newman and Newman agreed to complete the chef-decorator contract. Newman also an experienced decorator of excellent repute advised the chef of the assignment and supplied him with information confirming both Newman's financial responsibility and past commercial success. Is the chef obligated to permit Newman to perform the chef-decorator agreement?

options.optionA: A. Yes because the agreement contained no prohibition against assignment or delegation.
options.optionB: B. Yes because the chef received adequate assurances of Newman's ability to complete the job.
options.optionC: C. No because the decorator's duties were of a personal nature involving his reputation taste and skill.
options.optionD: D. No because the decorator's purported delegation to Newman of his obligations to the chef effected a novation.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Assignment of contracts, particularly in the context of personal services contracts involving reputation, taste, and skill.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: A chef hired a well-known interior decorator to design and furnish a new restaurant. The decorator assigned the contract to Newman, an experienced decorator, without the chef's consent and advised the chef of the assignment, providing assurances of Newman's ability to complete the job.
explanation.Rule_Application: A contractual duty may be delegated to another unless the other party to the contract has a substantial interest in having the original obligor perform. In personal services contracts, the other party typically has such an interest due to the involvement of reputation, taste, and judgment.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: As the decorator's duties involved personal services and unique designs, the chef has a substantial interest in having the decorator perform the contract. Therefore, the decorator's assignment of the contract to Newman without the chef's consent amounts to a breach of contract, and the chef is not obligated to permit Newman to perform the agreement, supporting option C.

question: A famous chef entered into a written agreement with his friend a well-known interior decorator respected for his unique designs in which the decorator agreed for a fixed fee to design the interior of the chef's new restaurant and upon the chef's approval of the design plan to decorate and furnish the restaurant accordingly. The agreement was silent as to assignment or delegation by either party. Before beginning the work the decorator sold his decorating business to Newman under an agreement in which the decorator assigned to Newman and Newman agreed to complete the chef-decorator contract. Newman also an experienced decorator of excellent repute advised the chef of the assignment and supplied him with information confirming both Newman's financial responsibility and past commercial success. If the chef allows Newman to perform and approves his design plan but Newman fails without legal excuse to complete the decorating as agreed against whom does the chef have an enforceable claim for breach of contract?

options.optionA: A. The decorator only because the decorator's agreement with Newman did not discharge his duty to the chef and Newman made no express promise to the chef.
options.optionB: B. Newman only because the decorator's duty to the chef was discharged when the decorator obtained a skilled decorator (Newman) to perform the chef-decorator contract.
options.optionC: C. Newman only because the chef was an intended beneficiary of the decorator-Newman agreement and the decorator's duty to the chef was discharged when the chef permitted Newman to do the work and approved Newman's designs.
options.optionD: D. Either the decorator because his agreement with Newman did not discharge his duty to the chef or Newman because the chef was an intended beneficiary of the decorator-Newman agreement.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Delegation of duties in contracts, specifically the impact of delegation on the contractual obligations of the parties involved.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The decorator sold his business to Newman, assigning his contractual duties to Newman. Newman advised the chef of the assignment, provided information on his financial responsibility and past success, and the chef approved Newman's design plan. However, Newman failed to complete the decorating work without a legal excuse.
explanation.Rule_Application: Unless the obligee agrees otherwise, delegation of a contractual duty does not discharge the obligation of the delegating obligor. The chef is an intended beneficiary of the decorator-Newman agreement, allowing him to enforce the contract against either party.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The chef has an enforceable claim for breach of contract against both the decorator (original obligor) and Newman (delegatee), supporting option D.

question: A landholder was land-rich by inheritance but money-poor having suffered severe losses on bad investments but still owned several thousand acres of unencumbered timberland. He had a large family and his normal fixed personal expenses were high. Pressed for cash he advertised a proposed sale of standing timber on a choice 2000-acre tract. The only response was an offer by a logger the owner of a large integrated construction enterprise after inspection of the advertised tract. The logger offered to buy sever and remove the standing timber from the advertised tract at a cash price 70% lower than the regionally prevailing price for comparable timber rights. The landholder by then in desperate financial straits and knowing little about timber values signed and delivered to the logger a letter accepting the offer. If before the logger commences performance the landholder's investment fortunes suddenly improve and he wishes to get out of the timber deal with the logger which of the following legal concepts affords his best prospect of effective cancellation?

options.optionA: A. Bad faith.
options.optionB: B. Equitable estoppel.
options.optionC: C. Unconscionability.
options.optionD: D. Duress.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Unconscionability in contracts, including both procedural and substantive elements.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The landholder, desperate for cash and lacking knowledge about timber values, signed an agreement with the logger to sell standing timber at a significantly lower price (70% lower) than the prevailing market rate, which could be seen as an unreasonably favorable term for the logger.
explanation.Rule_Application: A court may refuse to enforce or modify an unconscionable contract. In this case, the landholder's lack of bargaining power, combined with the unfairly low price, could be considered substantive unconscionability.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the circumstances of the contract, the landholder's best prospect for effective cancellation lies in arguing that the contract is unconscionable, supporting option C.

question: A landholder was land-rich by inheritance but money-poor having suffered severe losses on bad investments but still owned several thousand acres of unencumbered timberland. He had a large family and his normal fixed personal expenses were high. Pressed for cash he advertised a proposed sale of standing timber on a choice 2000-acre tract. The only response was an offer by a logger the owner of a large integrated construction enterprise after inspection of the advertised tract. The logger offered a fair price for the timber rights in question and the landholder accepted the offer. The 2000-acre tract was an abundant wild-game habitat and had been used for many years with the landholder's permission by area hunters. The logger's performance of the timber contract would destroy this habitat. Without legal excuse and over the landholder's strong objection the logger repudiated the contract before commencing performance. The landholder could not afford to hire a lawyer and take legal action and made no attempt to assign any cause of action he might have had against the logger. If the logger is sued for breach of the contract by the landholder's next-door neighbor whose view of a nearby lake is obscured by the standing timber the neighbor will probably

options.optionA: A. lose as only an incidental beneficiary if any of the logger-landholder contract.
options.optionB: B. lose as a maintainer of nuisance litigation.
options.optionC: C. prevail as a third-party intended beneficiary of the logger-landholder contract.
options.optionD: D. prevail as a surrogate for the landholder in view of his inability to enforce the contract.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Third-party beneficiary contracts, specifically the requirements for a party to acquire standing to enforce a promise in a contract to which they are not a party.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The logger and the landholder entered into a contract for the sale of timber rights, with the landholder accepting the logger's offer. The logger then repudiated the contract without performing, which would have destroyed the wild-game habitat on the tract. The landholder's next-door neighbor, whose view of a nearby lake would be improved by the logging, brings a lawsuit against the logger for breach of the contract.
explanation.Rule_Application: To have standing as a third-party beneficiary, a party must be an intended beneficiary of the promise, which requires that recognition of a right to performance is appropriate to effectuate the intent of the parties. This typically involves the promisor knowing that the promisee intended to confer a benefit on the beneficiary.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The neighbor lacks standing to enforce the logger-landholder contract because they are not an intended beneficiary of the promise. The contract was between the logger and the landholder, and the neighbor's potential benefit from the logging is incidental. Therefore, the neighbor will probably lose the lawsuit, supporting option A.

question: A written construction contract began with the following recital: "This Agreement between Land Inc. (hereafter called 'Owner') and Builder Inc. and Boss its President (hereafter called 'Contractor') witnesseth: "The signatures to the contract appeared in the following format:  LAND INC. By /s/ Oscar Land  President BUILDER INC. By /s/ George Mason Vice President /s/ Mary Boss President Mary Boss Builder Inc. became insolvent and defaulted. Land Inc. sued Boss individually for the breach and at the trial Boss proffered evidence from the pre-contract negotiations that only Builder Inc. was to be legally responsible for performing the contract. If the court finds the contract to be completely integrated is Boss's proffered evidence admissible?

options.optionA: A. Yes because the writing is ambiguous as to whether or not Boss was intended individually to be a contracting party.
options.optionB: B. Yes because the evidence would contradict neither the recital nor the form of Boss's signature.
options.optionC: C. No because the legal effect of Boss's signature cannot be altered by evidence of prior understandings.
options.optionD: D. No because the application of the "four corners" rule under which the meaning of a completely integrated contract must be ascertained solely from its own terms.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Parol Evidence Rule and the exception for ambiguous contracts
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The construction contract began with a recital stating an agreement between Land Inc. and Builder Inc. and Boss its President, with the signatures of the parties appearing in a certain format. However, it is unclear from the contract whether Boss signed individually or only as representative of Builder Inc.
explanation.Rule_Application: The parol evidence rule generally bars extrinsic evidence of prior statements where the agreement is completely integrated. However, an exception applies where the extrinsic evidence is offered to interpret an ambiguity in the final written agreement. Since the contract is ambiguous regarding Boss's individual liability, extrinsic evidence from the pre-contract negotiations is admissible to clarify the parties' understanding.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the ambiguity in the contract, the court may consider the proffered evidence to determine whether Boss was intended to be individually liable, supporting option A.

question: A fixtures company in a signed writing contracted with an apartment complex for the sale to the apartment complex of 50 identical sets of specified bathroom fixtures 25 sets to be delivered on March 1 and the remaining 25 sets on April 1. The agreement did not specify the place of delivery or the time or place of payment. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.optionA: A. The fixtures company must tender 25 sets to the apartment complex at the apartment complex's place of business on March 1 but does not have to turn them over to the apartment complex until the complex pays the contract price for the 25 sets.
options.optionB: B. The fixtures company has no duty to deliver 25 sets on March 1 at the fixtures company's place of business unless the apartment complex tenders the contract price for the 25 sets on that date.
options.optionC: C. The fixtures company must deliver 25 sets on March 1 and the apartment complex must pay the contract price for the 25 sets within a reasonable time after their delivery.
options.optionD: D. The fixtures company must deliver 25 sets on March 1 but the apartment complex's payment is due only upon the delivery of all 50 sets.

explanation.Legal_Concept: UCC's default rules for delivery and payment in the absence of specific contractual provisions
explanation.Fact_Analysis: A signed contract between a fixtures company and an apartment complex for the sale of 50 sets of bathroom fixtures with two delivery dates, without specifying the place of delivery or time and place of payment
explanation.Rule_Application: Under UCC, unless the contract specifies otherwise, the buyer's obligation to pay is conditioned upon tender of the goods by the seller, and the place of delivery is the seller's place of business, with payment due at the time and place of delivery
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The correct answer is option B, as the fixtures company has no duty to deliver 25 sets on March 1 at the apartment complex's place of business, unless the apartment complex tenders the contract price for the 25 sets on that date.

question: A fixtures company in a signed writing contracted with an apartment complex for the sale to the apartment complex of 50 identical sets of specified bathroom fixtures 25 sets to be delivered on March 1 and the remaining 25 sets on April 1. The agreement did not specify the place of delivery or the time or place of payment. On March 1 the fixtures company tendered 24 sets to the apartment complex and explained "One of the 25 sets was damaged in transit from the manufacturer to us but we will deliver a replacement within 5 days." Which of the following statements is correct?

options.optionA: A. The apartment complex is entitled to accept any number of the 24 sets reject the rest and cancel the contract both as to any rejected sets and the lot due on April 1.
options.optionB: B. The apartment complex is entitled to accept any number of the 24 sets and to reject the rest but is not entitled to cancel the contract as to any rejected sets or the lot due on April 1.
options.optionC: C. The apartment complex must accept the 24 sets but is entitled to cancel the rest of the contract.
options.optionD: D. The apartment complex must accept the 24 sets and is not entitled to cancel the rest of the contract.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Installment contracts under the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC), including the buyer's obligations when faced with a non-conforming installment
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The fixtures company tendered 24 sets of bathroom fixtures to the apartment complex on March 1, explaining that one of the 25 sets was damaged in transit but promising a replacement within 5 days.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under the UCC, an installment contract provides for separate lots of goods to be separately accepted. When an installment is non-conforming, the buyer must accept it if the seller gives adequate assurance of curing the defect, unless the non-conformity substantially impairs the value of the installment and cannot be cured.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the fixtures company's assurance of delivering a replacement set within 5 days, the apartment complex must accept the 24 sets tendered on March 1 and cannot cancel the rest of the contract, supporting option D.

question: On March 1 a mechanic contracted to repair a textile company's knitting machine and to complete the job by March 6. On March 2 the textile company contracted to manufacture and deliver specified cloth to a knitwear company on March 15. The textile company knew that it would have to use the machine then under repair to perform this contract. Because the knitwear company order was for a rush job the knitwear company and the textile company included in their contract a liquidated damages clause providing that the textile company would pay $5000 for each day's delay in delivery after March 15. The mechanic was inexcusably five days late in repairing the machine and as a result the textile company was five days late in delivering the cloth to the knitwear company. The textile company paid $25000 to the knitwear company as liquidated damages and now sues the mechanic for $25000. Both the mechanic and the textile company knew when making their contract on March 1 that under ordinary circumstances the textile company would sustain little or no damages of any kind as a result of a five-day delay in the machine repair. Assuming that the $5000 liquidated damages clause in the knitwear-textile contract is valid which of the following arguments will serve as the mechanic's best defense to the textile company's action?

options.optionA: A. Time was not of the essence in the mechanic-textile contract.
options.optionB: B. The mechanic had no reason to foresee on March 1 that the knitwear company would suffer consequential damages in the amount of $25000.
options.optionC: C. By entering into the knitwear company contract while knowing that its knitting machine was being repaired the textile company assumed the risk of any delay's loss to the knitwear company.
options.optionD: D. In all probability the liquidated damages paid by the textile company to the knitwear company are not the same amount as the actual damages sustained by the knitwear company in consequence of the textile company's late delivery of the cloth.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Foreseeability of damages in contract law, particularly in relation to liquidated damages clauses
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The mechanic was contracted to repair a knitting machine by March 6. The textile company, knowing it needed the machine for a rush job, contracted to deliver cloth to a knitwear company by March 15 with a liquidated damages clause of $5000 per day's delay. The mechanic was five days late, causing the textile company to be five days late, resulting in a $25000 liquidated damages payment.
explanation.Rule_Application: Damages for breach of contract can only be recovered for losses that the breaching party had reason to foresee as probable at the time the contract was made. In this case, the mechanic did not have reason to foresee the $25000 loss due to the textile company's contract with the knitwear company.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the mechanic did not have reason to foresee the specific loss sustained by the textile company, the mechanic's best defense is that they did not have reason to foresee the consequential damages, supporting option B.

question: A written construction contract under which a contractor agreed to build a new house for an owner at a fixed price of $200000 contained the following provision: Prior to construction or during the course thereof this contract may be modified by mutual agreement of the parties as to "extras" or other departures from the plans and specifications provided by the owner and attached hereto. Such modifications however may be authorized only in writing signed by both parties. During construction the contractor incorporated into the structure overhanging gargoyles and other "extras" orally requested by the owner for orally agreed prices in addition to the contract price. The owner subsequently refused to pay anything for such extras aggregating $30000 at the agreed prices solely on the ground that no written signed authorization for them was ever effected. If the contractor sues the owner on account of the "extras" which if any of the following will effectively support the owner's defense? I. The parol evidence rule. II. The preexisting duty rule. III. Failure of an express condition. IV. The statute of frauds.

options.optionA: A. I and III only.
options.optionB: B. I and IV only.
options.optionC: C. II and IV only.
options.optionD: D. Neither I II III nor IV

explanation.Legal_Concept: No-oral-modification clause in a written contract, specifically in construction contracts
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The construction contract had a provision that any modifications to the agreement were only valid if made in writing and signed by both parties. However, the contractor made oral agreements with the owner to incorporate extras into the structure, including gargoyles, and the owner refused to pay for them citing the lack of written authorization
explanation.Rule_Application: A no-oral-modification clause is a valid contractual provision that requires all changes to the agreement to be made in writing and signed by both parties. In this case, the contractor's reliance on oral agreements for the extras does not bind the owner to pay for them
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: As the contract provision is clear and enforceable, the contractor's claim for payment for the extras would be unsuccessful. Therefore, none of the options I, II, III, or IV would effectively support the owner's defense, making the correct answer option D

question: On April 1 an owner and a buyer signed a writing in which the owner in consideration of $100 to be paid to the owner by the buyer offered the buyer the right to purchase Greenacre for $100000 within 30 days. The writing further provided "This offer will become effective as an option only if and when the $100 consideration is in fact paid." On April 20 the owner having received no payment or other communication from the buyer sold and conveyed Greenacre to a citizen for $120000. On April 21 the owner received a letter from the buyer enclosing a cashier's check for $100 payable to the owner and stating "I am hereby exercising my option to purchase Greenacre and am prepared to close whenever you're ready." Which of the following if proved best support the buyer's suit against the owner for breach of contract?

options.optionA: A. The buyer was unaware of the sale to the citizen when the owner received the letter and check from the buyer on April 21.
options.optionB: B. On April 15 the buyer decided to purchase Greenacre and applied for and obtained a commitment from a bank for a $75000 loan to help finance the purchase.
options.optionC: C. When the April 1 writing was signed the owner said to the buyer "Don't worry about the $100; the recital of '$100 to be paid' makes this deal binding."
options.optionD: D. The owner and the buyer are both professional dealers in real estate.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Option contracts, particularly the requirement of consideration to make an offer irrevocable and the rules governing the lapse or revocation of such offers.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The owner and buyer signed a written agreement on April 1, which included the condition that the $100 consideration must be paid for the offer to become effective as an option. The owner sold Greenacre to a third party on April 20 without receiving payment or communication from the buyer. The buyer sent a letter and cashier's check for $100 to the owner on April 21, stating their intention to exercise the option and purchase Greenacre.
explanation.Rule_Application: For an option contract to be enforceable, consideration must be paid. However, even if consideration is not furnished, the offer can still be accepted by the offeree unless the offer lapses or the offeree receives notice of revocation.
