explanation.Legal_Concept: Future interest in property law, specifically the concept of a contingent interest.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The farmer conveyed Greenacre to the farmer's son with a condition precedent that the son must earn a college degree by age 30. The son had not met this condition, and the farmer still holds the present interest in the property. The college classmate occupied the house with the farmer's oral permission, rent-free.
explanation.Rule_Application: A contingent interest, like the one conveyed to the farmer's son, does not immediately vest the property rights in the grantee. Until the condition is met, the present interest remains with the grantor. In this case, the farmer remains the landlord, and the college classmate is the tenant of the farmer.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the farmer's son has not yet earned his college degree and the condition precedent has not been met, the college classmate is still a tenant of the farmer, not of the farmer's son. Therefore, the correct answer is option D.

question: An owner owned 80 acres of land, fronting on a town road. Two years ago, the owner sold to a buyer the back 40 acres. The 40 acres sold to the buyer did not adjoin any public road. The owner's deed to the buyer expressly granted a right-of-way over a specified strip of the owner's retained 40 acres, so the buyer could reach the town road. The deed was promptly and properly recorded. Last year, the buyer conveyed the back 40 acres to a doctor. They had discussed the right-of-way over the owner's land to the road, but the buyer's deed to the doctor made no mention of it. The doctor began to use the right-of-way as the buyer had, but the owner sued to enjoin such use by the doctor. The court should decide for

options.optionA: A. the doctor, because he has an easement by implication.
options.optionB: B. the doctor, because the easement appurtenant passed to him as a result of the buyer's deed to him.
options.optionC: C. the owner, because the buyer's easement in gross was not transferable.
options.optionD: D. the owner, because the buyer's deed failed expressly to transfer the right-of-way to the doctor.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Easement appurtenant and its transferability to subsequent landowners.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The owner of the land originally sold 40 acres to a buyer, granting a right-of-way for the buyer to access the town road. This right-of-way was properly recorded. The buyer then sold the 40 acres to a doctor, but the deed did not mention the right-of-way. The doctor began using the right-of-way, prompting the owner to sue to enjoin its use.
explanation.Rule_Application: An easement appurtenant automatically runs with the land and does not need to be re-identified in later deeds once it has been properly recorded. As a result, the doctor, as the subsequent landowner, has the right to use the right-of-way granted in the original deed.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Based on the automatic transfer of the easement appurtenant, the court should decide in favor of the doctor, supporting option B.

question: The owner of Greenacre, a tract of land, mortgaged Greenacre to a bank to secure his preexisting obligation to the bank. The mortgage was promptly and properly recorded. The owner and a buyer then entered into a valid written contract for the purchase and sale of Greenacre, which provided for the transfer of "a marketable title, free of encumbrances." The contract did not expressly refer to the mortgage. Shortly after entering into the contract, the buyer found another property that much better suited her needs and decided to try to avoid her contract with the owner. When the buyer discovered the existence of the mortgage, she asserted that the title was encumbered and that she would not close. The owner responded by offering to provide for payment and discharge of the mortgage at the closing from the proceeds of the closing. The buyer refused to go forward, and the owner brought an appropriate action against her for specific performance. If the court holds for the owner in this action, it will most likely be because

options.optionA: A. the mortgage is not entitled to priority because it was granted for preexisting obligations.
options.optionB: B. the doctrine of equitable conversion supports the result.
options.optionC: C. The owner's arrangements for the payment of the mortgage fully satisfied the owner's obligation to deliver marketable title.
options.optionD: D. the existence of the mortgage was not the buyer's real reason for refusing to close.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Marketable title in real estate transactions, specifically the seller's obligation to deliver title free of encumbrances
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The buyer and seller entered into a contract for the sale of Greenacre with a provision for a 'marketable title, free of encumbrances.' A preexisting mortgage on Greenacre was recorded, but not mentioned in the contract. The buyer discovered the mortgage and refused to close, citing the encumbrance. The seller offered to pay off the mortgage at closing
explanation.Rule_Application: A seller is required to deliver marketable title, free of encumbrances. However, if a seller can provide arrangements to remove the encumbrance, such as paying off the mortgage, then the title can still be considered marketable. In this case, the seller's offer to pay off the mortgage at closing would render the title marketable
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Because the seller has made arrangements to remove the encumbrance, the title will be marketable, and the seller's action for specific performance will likely succeed, supporting option C

question: A plaintiff and a defendant own adjacent parcels of land. On each of their parcels was a low-rise office building. The two office buildings were of the same height. Last year the defendant decided to demolish the low-rise office building on her parcel and to erect a new high-rise office building of substantially greater height on the parcel as permitted by the zoning and building ordinances. She secured all the governmental approvals necessary to pursue her project. As the defendant's new building was in the course of construction, the plaintiff realized that the shadows it would create would place her (the plaintiff's) building in such deep shade that the rent she could charge for space in her building would be substantially reduced. The plaintiff brought an appropriate action against the defendant to enjoin the construction in order to eliminate the shadow problem and for damages. The plaintiff presented uncontroverted evidence that her evaluation as to the impact of the shadow on the fair rental value of her building was correct. There is no statute or ordinance (other than the building and zoning ordinances) that is applicable to the issues before the court. The court should

options.optionA: A. grant to the plaintiff the requested injunction.
options.optionB: B. award the plaintiff damages measured by the loss of rental value, but not an injunction.
options.optionC: C. grant judgment for the defendant, because she had secured all the necessary governmental approvals for the new building.
options.optionD: D. grant judgment for the defendant, because the plaintiff has no legal right to have sunshine continue to reach the windows of her building.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Property rights, including the rights to sunlight, fresh air, and view
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The defendant received all necessary governmental approvals to construct a high-rise office building, and the plaintiff's building will be placed in deep shade due to the new construction, reducing rental value
explanation.Rule_Application: Property owners have no inherent right to sunlight, fresh air, or view; the plaintiff has no legal basis for a cause of action against the defendant, as there are no negative easements or restrictive covenants in place
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Since the plaintiff has no legal right to sunlight, the correct verdict is judgment for the defendant, supporting option D

question: A seller owned Blackacre, improved with an aging four-story warehouse. The warehouse was built to the lot lines on all four sides. On the street side, recessed loading docks permitted semi-trailers to be backed in. After the tractors were unhooked, the trailers extended into the street and occupied most of one lane of the street. Over the years, as trailers became larger, the blocking of the street became more severe. The municipality advised the seller that the loading docks could not continue to be used because the trailers blocked the street; it gave the seller 90 days to cease and desist. During the 90 days, the seller sold and conveyed Blackacre by warranty deed for a substantial consideration to a buyer. The problem of the loading docks was not discussed in the negotiations.Upon expiration of the 90 days, the municipality required the buyer to stop using the loading docks. This action substantially reduced the value of Blackacre.The buyer brought an appropriate action against the seller seeking cancellation of the deed and return of all monies paid. Such action should be based upon a claim of

options.optionA: A. misrepresentation.
options.optionB: B. breach of the covenant of warranty.
options.optionC: C. failure of consideration.
options.optionD: D. mutual mistake.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Misrepresentation in property transactions, specifically the reliance on false or omitted information by a buyer that affects the value of the property.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The seller of Blackacre failed to disclose the municipality's instruction to cease and desist using the loading docks due to blocking the street, which significantly impacted the property's value. The buyer was unaware of this issue during the negotiations and only discovered it after the sale.
explanation.Rule_Application: A misrepresentation occurs when a party makes a false statement or omission of material fact that the other party relies upon to their detriment. In this case, the seller's failure to disclose the loading dock issue constitutes a misrepresentation, as it significantly affects the property's value and usefulness.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the buyer relied on the seller's omission to their detriment, the buyer's claim should be based on misrepresentation, supporting option A.

question: A land owner owned in fee simple Lots 1 and 2 in an urban subdivision. The lots were vacant and unproductive. They were held as a speculation that their value would increase. The land owner died and, by his duly probated will, devised the residue of his estate (of which Lots 1 and 2 were part) to his sister for life with remainder in fee simple to his niece. The land owner's executor distributed the estate under appropriate court order, and notified the sister that future real estate taxes on Lots 1 and 2 were her responsibility to pay. Except for the statutes relating to probate and those relating to real estate taxes, there is no applicable statute. The sister failed to pay the real estate taxes due for Lots 1 and 2. To prevent a tax sale of the fee simple, the niece paid the taxes and demanded that the sister reimburse her for same. When the sister refused, the niece brought an appropriate action against the sister to recover the amount paid. In such action, the niece should recover

options.optionA: A. the amount paid, because a life tenant has the duty to pay current charges.
options.optionB: B. the present value of the interest that the amount paid would earn during the sister's lifetime.
options.optionC: C. nothing, because the sister's sole possession gave the right to decide whether or not taxes should be paid.
options.optionD: D. nothing, because the sister never received any income from the lots.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Life tenant's duties and responsibilities, particularly in regards to payment of current charges such as taxes.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The sister held a life estate in Lots 1 and 2, while the niece held a vested remainder in fee simple. The sister failed to pay real estate taxes, prompting the niece to step in and prevent a tax sale.
explanation.Rule_Application: A life tenant has a duty not to commit voluntary or permissive waste, including paying real estate taxes. However, this responsibility is limited to the amount of income generated by the property. In this case, the property is vacant and unproductive, generating no income.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the property generated no income, the sister is not responsible for paying taxes and the niece has no recourse against her. Therefore, the niece should recover nothing, supporting option D.

question: A farmer and a rancher owned Greenacre, a large farm, in fee simple as tenants in common, each owning an undivided one-half interest. For five years the farmer occupied Greenacre and conducted farming operations. The farmer never accounted to the rancher for any income, but the farmer did pay all real estate taxes when the taxes were due and kept the buildings located on Greenacre insured against loss from fire, storm, and flood. The rancher lived in a distant city and was interested only in realizing a profit from the sale of the land when market conditions produced the price the rancher wanted. The farmer died intestate, survived only by the farmer's sole heir. Thereafter, the sole heir occupied Greenacre but was inexperienced in farming operations. The result was a financial disaster. The sole heir failed to pay real estate taxes for two years. The appropriate governmental authority held a tax sale to recover the taxes due. At such sale the rancher was the only bidder and obtained a conveyance from the appropriate governmental authority upon payment of an amount sufficient to discharge the amounts due for taxes, plus interest and penalties, and the costs of holding the tax sale. The amount paid was one-third of the reasonable market value of Greenacre. Thereafter, the rancher instituted an appropriate action against the sole heir to quiet title in and to recover possession of Greenacre. The sole heir asserted all defenses available to her. Except for the statutes related to real estate taxes and tax sales, there is no applicable statute. In this lawsuit, the rancher is entitled to a decree quieting title so that the rancher is the sole owner in fee simple of Greenacre

options.optionA: A. because the rancher survived the farmer.
options.optionB: B. because the farmer's sole heir defaulted in the obligations undertaken by the farmer.
options.optionC: C. unless the farmer's sole heir pays the rancher one-half of the reasonable market value of Greenacre.
options.optionD: D. unless the farmer's sole heir pays the rancher one-half of the amount the rancher paid for the tax deed.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Rights and duties of tenants in common, particularly the right to contribution for expenditures such as taxes, mortgage payments, and repairs.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The farmer occupied Greenacre, paid real estate taxes, and kept buildings insured, while the rancher lived in a distant city with no involvement in farming operations. Upon the farmer's death, the sole heir occupied the land but failed to pay taxes, leading to a tax sale where the rancher obtained a conveyance by paying one-third of the reasonable market value of Greenacre.
explanation.Rule_Application: Tenants in common have a right to contribution from each other for certain expenditures, such as taxes. The rancher paid the taxes and obtained a conveyance, so the sole heir must contribute one-half of the amount the rancher paid for the tax deed to retain her one-half interest in the property.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The correct verdict would be that the rancher is entitled to a decree quieting title, unless the farmer's sole heir pays the rancher one-half of the amount the rancher paid for the tax deed, supporting option D.

question: A landowner owned Greenacre, a tract of land, in fee simple. The landowner entered into a valid written agreement with a purchaser under which the landowner agreed to sell and the purchaser agreed to buy Greenacre by installment purchase. The contract stipulated that the landowner would deliver to the purchaser, upon the payment of the last installment due, "a warranty deed sufficient to convey the fee simple." The contract contained no other provision that could be construed as referring to title. The purchaser entered into possession of Greenacre. After making 10 of the 300 installment payments obligated under the contract, the purchaser discovered that there was outstanding a valid and enforceable mortgage on Greenacre, securing the payment of debt in the amount of 25% of the purchase price the purchaser had agreed to pay. There was no evidence that the landowner had ever been late in payments due under the mortgage and there was no evidence of any danger of insolvency of the landowner. The value of Greenacre now is four times the amount on the debt secured by the mortgage. The purchaser quit possession of Greenacre and demanded that the landowner repay the amounts the purchaser had paid under the contract. After the landowner refused the demand, the purchaser brought an appropriate action against the landowner to recover damages for the landowner's alleged breach of the contract. In such action, should damages be awarded to the purchaser?

options.optionA: A. No, because the time for the landowner to deliver marketable title has not arrived.
options.optionB: B. No, because the purchaser assumed the risk by taking possession.
options.optionC: C. Yes, because in the absence of a contrary express agreement, an obligation to convey marketable title is implied.
options.optionD: D. Yes, because the risk of loss assumed by the purchaser in taking possession relates only to physical loss.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The concept of marketable title in real estate transactions, specifically the timing of when marketable title must be delivered to the buyer.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The contract stipulated that the landowner would deliver a warranty deed sufficient to convey fee simple upon payment of the last installment, and the purchaser made 10 of the 300 installment payments before discovering the outstanding mortgage.
explanation.Rule_Application: An obligation to convey marketable title is not implied until the time for performance arrives, which in this case is the delivery of the deed upon payment of the 300th installment.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Since the time for performance has not yet arrived, the landowner is not in breach of contract, and damages should not be awarded to the purchaser, supporting option A.

question: A landowner owned Blackacre in fee simple and conveyed Blackacre to a teacher by warranty deed. An adjoining owner asserted title to Blackacre and brought an appropriate action against the teacher to quiet title to Blackacre. The teacher demanded that the landowner defend the teacher's title under the deed's covenant of warranty, but the landowner refused. The teacher then successfully defended at her own expense. The teacher brought an appriopriate action against the landowner to recover the teacher's expenses incurred in defending against the adjoining owner's action to quiet title to Blackacre. In this action, the court should decide for

options.optionA: A. the teacher, because in effect it was the landowner's title that was challenged.
options.optionB: B. the teacher, because the landowner's deed to her included the covenant of warranty.
options.optionC: C. the landowner, because the title the landowner conveyed was not defective.
options.optionD: D. the landowner, because the adjoining owner may elect which of the landowner or the teacher to sue.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Covenant of warranty in property law, specifically the guarantee of marketable title and the grantor's duty to defend against valid claims against the title.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The landowner conveyed Blackacre to the teacher by warranty deed, which included a covenant of warranty. The teacher demanded the landowner defend against an action to quiet title brought by an adjoining owner, but the landowner refused. The teacher successfully defended the title at their own expense.
explanation.Rule_Application: A breach of the covenant of warranty occurs when a third party interferes with possession of the land, not when a third party makes a claim against the grantee. The grantor must only defend against a wrongful claim or eviction. The teacher prevailed over the adjoining owner in the quiet title action, indicating no valid claim existed.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the landowner conveyed good title and did not fail to defend against any valid claims, the landowner should prevail. Therefore, the correct verdict would be for the landowner, supporting option C.

question: A landowner executed an instrument in the proper form of a deed, purporting to convey his land to a friend. The landowner handed the instrument to the friend, saying, "This is yours, but please do not record it until after I am dead. Otherwise, it will cause me no end of trouble with my relatives." Two days later, the landowner asked the friend to return the deed to him because he had decided that he should devise the land to the friend by will rather than by deed. The friend said that he would destroy the deed and a day or so later falsely told the landowner that the deed had been destroyed. Six months later, the landowner, who had never executed a will, died intestate, survived by a daughter as his sole heir at law. The day after the landowner's death, the friend recorded the deed from him. As soon as the daughter discovered this recording and the friend's claim to the land, she brought an appropriate action against the friend to quiet title to the land.  For whom should the court hold?

options.optionA: A. The daughter, because the death of the landowner deprived the subsequent recordation of any effect.
options.optionB: B. The daughter, because the friend was dishonest in reporting that he had destroyed the deed.
options.optionC: C. The friend, because the deed was delivered to him.
options.optionD: D. The friend, because the deed was recorded by him.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Delivery in the context of deeds, specifically the intent required for a deed to be validly transferred.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The landowner handed the deed to the friend, stating 'This is yours,' and the friend later refused to return the deed and falsely claimed to have destroyed it. The landowner died intestate without a will, and the friend recorded the deed after the landowner's death.
explanation.Rule_Application: A deed is considered delivered when the grantor intends to transfer title and relinquish dominion and control over the document. In this case, the landowner's words and actions demonstrate the necessary intent, and the friend's refusal to return the deed confirms that delivery occurred.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the deed was validly delivered to the friend, the court should hold for the friend, supporting option C.

question: A seller owned a single family house. A buyer gave the seller a signed handwritten offer to purchase the house. The offer was unconditional and sufficient to satisfy the statute of frauds, and when the seller signed an acceptance an enforceable contract resulted. The house on the land had been the seller's home, but he had moved to an apartment, so the house was vacant at all times relevant to the proposed transaction. Two weeks after the parties had entered into their contract, one week after the buyer had obtained a written mortgage lending commitment from a lender, and one week before the agreed-upon closing date, the house was struck by lightning and burned to the ground. The loss was not insured, because three years earlier, the seller had let his homeowner's insurance policy lapse after he had paid his mortgage debt in full. The handwritten contract was wholly silent as to matters of financing, risk of loss, and insurance. The buyer declared the contract voided by the fire, but the seller asserted a right to enforce the contract despite the loss. There is no applicable statute. If a court finds for the seller, what is the likely reason?

options.optionA: A. The contract was construed against the buyer, who drafted it.
options.optionB: B. The lender's written commitment to make a mortgage loan to the buyer made the contract of sale fully binding on the buyer.
options.optionC: C. The risk of loss falls on the party in possession, and constructive possession passed to the buyer on the contract date.
options.optionD: D. The risk of loss passed to the buyer on the contract date under the doctrine of equitable conversion.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Doctrine of equitable conversion, which determines the risk of loss in a contract for sale of real estate when the contract is silent on the matter.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The handwritten contract between the buyer and seller was unconditional and enforceable, but silent on matters of financing, risk of loss, and insurance. After the contract was signed, the house was destroyed by a fire, leaving the parties to dispute who bears the risk of loss.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under the doctrine of equitable conversion, the risk of loss falls on the party with the equitable title, which is the buyer in this scenario. Since the contract was silent on the matter, the buyer is deemed to have taken on the risk of loss at the time the contract was signed.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the application of the doctrine of equitable conversion, the court would likely find in favor of the seller, supporting option D, as the buyer bears the risk of loss.

question: A farmer borrowed $100,000 from a bank and gave the bank a promissory note secured by a mortgage on the farm that she owned. The bank promptly and properly recorded the mortgage, which contained a due-on-sale provision. A few years later, the farmer borrowed $5,000 from a second bank and gave it a promissory note secured by a mortgage on her farm. The bank promptly and properly recorded the mortgage. Subsequently, the farmer defaulted on her obligation to the first bank, which then validly accelerated the debt and instituted nonjudicial foreclosure proceedings as permitted by the jurisdiction. The second bank received notice of the foreclosure sale but did not send a representative to the sale. At the foreclosure sale, a buyer who was not acting in collusion with the farmer outbid all other bidders and received a deed to the farm. Several months later, the original farmer repurchased her farm from the buyer, who executed a warranty deed transferring the farm to her. After the farmer promptly and properly recorded that deed, the second bank commenced foreclosure proceedings on the farm. The farmer denied the validity of the second bank's mortgage. Does the second bank continue to have a valid mortgage on the farm?

options.optionA: A. Yes, because of the doctrine of estoppel by deed.
options.optionB: B. Yes, because the original owner reacquired title to the farm.
options.optionC: C. No, because the purchase at the foreclosure sale by the buyer under these facts eliminated the second bank's junior mortgage lien.
options.optionD: D. No, because of the due-on-sale provision in the farmer's mortgage to the first bank.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Priority of mortgage liens and the effect of foreclosure on junior mortgage liens
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The first bank, having priority, accelerated the debt and instituted non-judicial foreclosure proceedings. The second bank received notice of the foreclosure sale but failed to appear. The buyer at the sale obtained the title free of any mortgage liens, which was then transferred back to the farmer via a warranty deed.
explanation.Rule_Application: In a foreclosure sale, the buyer obtains title free of any junior mortgage liens. If a junior mortgage holder fails to protect its interest by appearing at the sale or taking other action, it will lose its lien on the property.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Since the second bank failed to act, the foreclosure sale eliminated its junior mortgage lien, making option C the correct answer.

question: Six years ago, a landlord and a tenant entered into a 10-year commercial lease of land. The written lease provided that, if a public entity under the power of eminent domain condemned any part of the land, the lease would terminate and the landlord would receive the entire condemnation award. Thereafter, the city condemned approximately two-thirds of the land. The tenant notified the city and the landlord that an independent appraisal of the value of the tenant's possessory interest established that it substantially exceeded the tenant's obligation under the lease and that the tenant was entitled to share the award. The appraisal was accurate. In an appropriate action among the landlord, the tenant, and the city as to the right of the tenant to a portion of the condemnation award, for whom will the court likely find?

options.optionA: A. The landlord, because the condemnation superseded and canceled the lease.
options.optionB: B. The landlord, because the parties specifically agreed as to the consequences of condemnation.
options.optionC: C. The tenant, because the landlord breached the landlord's implied warranty of quiet enjoyment.
options.optionD: D. The tenant, because otherwise the landlord would be unjustly enriched.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Eminent Domain and Condemnation Awards
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The landlord and tenant entered into a 10-year lease, specifying that if any part of the land was condemned, the lease would terminate and the landlord would receive the entire condemnation award. The city condemned approximately two-thirds of the land, and the tenant claimed entitlement to a share of the award based on an independent appraisal showing the value of their possessory interest exceeded their lease obligation.
explanation.Rule_Application: When parties specifically agree to the consequences of condemnation in a lease, their agreement will be upheld. In this case, the parties explicitly stated that the landlord would receive the entire condemnation award if any part of the land was condemned, regardless of the tenant's possessory interest.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Based on the express terms of the lease, the court will likely find in favor of the landlord, supporting option B.

question: A landlord and a tenant orally agreed to a commercial tenancy for a term of six months beginning on July 1. Rent was to be paid by the first day of each month, and the tenant paid the first month's rent at the time of the agreement. When the tenant arrived at the leased premises on July 1, the tenant learned that the previous tenant had not vacated the premises at the end of her lease term on May 31 and did not intend to vacate. The tenant then successfully sued the previous tenant for possession. The tenant did not inform the landlord of the eviction action until after the tenant received possession. The tenant then sued the landlord, claiming damages for that portion of the lease period during which the tenant was not in possession. If the court finds for the landlord, what will be the most likely explanation?

options.optionA: A. By suing the previous tenant for possession, the tenant elected that remedy in lieu of a suit against the landlord.
options.optionB: B. The landlord had delivered the legal right of possession to the tenant.
options.optionC: C. The tenant failed to timely vacate as required to sue for constructive eviction.
options.optionD: D. The tenant had not notified the landlord before bringing the eviction action.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Landlord's obligation to deliver possession of the leased premises to the tenant at the beginning of the tenancy term
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The tenant entered into an oral agreement with the landlord for a six-month lease starting on July 1, paid the first month's rent upfront, and upon arrival discovered the previous tenant still occupying the premises. The tenant then sued the previous tenant for possession, succeeded, and later sued the landlord for damages for the period without possession
explanation.Rule_Application: The landlord's duty is to deliver the legal right of possession, not necessarily actual possession, at the commencement of the lease term. If the landlord has granted the legal right of possession, the tenant has no claim for damages or constructive eviction against the landlord
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Since the landlord had delivered the legal right of possession to the tenant, the court's ruling in favor of the landlord is justified, supporting option B

question: Six months ago, a man told his cousin that he would give her his farm as a gift on her next birthday. The cousin then entered into a valid written contract to sell the farm to an investor with the closing to take place "one week after [the cousin's] next birthday." The man failed to convey the farm to the cousin on her birthday. One week after the cousin's birthday, on the intended closing date, the investor first learned of the cousin's inability to convey the farm because the man had breached his promise. The investor considered suing the cousin but realized that she could not compel the cousin to convey the farm because it was still owned by the man. Two weeks after the cousin's birthday, the man died. Under his valid will, the man devised the farm to the cousin. Within a week, the executor of the man's estate gave the cousin an executor's deed to the farm in compliance with state law. The investor promptly learned of this transfer and demanded that the cousin convey the farm to her. The cousin refused. The investor sued the cousin for specific performance. Who will likely prevail?

options.optionA: A. The cousin, because the contract to convey was not signed by the legal owner of the farm as of the date of the contract and was therefore void.
options.optionB: B. The cousin, because she received title by devise rather than by conveyance.
options.optionC: C. The investor, because the contract to convey merged into the executor's deed to the cousin.
options.optionD: D. The investor, because the contract to convey remained enforceable by her within a reasonable period of time after the proposed closing date.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Specific performance of a contract, particularly in the context of real estate transactions and the time constraints on enforcing such contracts.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The man failed to convey the farm to the cousin on her birthday as promised, but later devised it to her under his will. The cousin received an executor's deed to the farm and refused to convey it to the investor, prompting the investor to sue for specific performance.
explanation.Rule_Application: A valid contract for the sale of real property remains enforceable within a reasonable time period after the proposed closing date unless time is of the essence. Here, the cousin acquired the farm within a reasonable time after the intended closing date, allowing the investor to seek specific performance.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the contract was valid and the cousin acquired the farm within a reasonable time, the investor should prevail in seeking specific performance, supporting option D.

question: A man decided to give his farm to his nephew. The man took a deed to his attorney and told the attorney to deliver the deed to the nephew upon the man's death. The man also told the attorney to return the deed to him if he asked. None of these instructions to the attorney were in writing, and the deed was not recorded. The man then e-mailed the nephew informing him of the arrangement. Shortly thereafter, the nephew died testate. In his will, he devised the farm to his daughter. Several years later, the man died intestate, survived by two sons. The nephew's daughter immediately claimed ownership of the farm and demanded that the attorney deliver the deed to her. Must the attorney deliver the deed to the daughter?

options.optionA: A. No, because a gratuitous death escrow is void unless supported by a written contract.
options.optionB: B. No, because the man never placed the deed beyond his control.
options.optionC: C. Yes, because the death of the nephew rendered the gratuitous death escrow irrevocable by the man.
options.optionD: D. Yes, because the deed to the nephew was legally delivered when the man took it to his attorney.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Death escrow, particularly the requirement of placing the deed beyond the grantor's control
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The man delivered a deed to his attorney with instructions to deliver it to the nephew upon the man's death. The man also instructed the attorney to return the deed to him if he asked, which indicates that he reserved control over the deed.
explanation.Rule_Application: A death escrow is created when the grantor places the deed beyond their control, reserving no power over it. The man's retention of control over the deed through his instruction to return it if asked means he did not create a valid death escrow.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Since the man did not create a valid death escrow, the attorney is not obligated to deliver the deed to the nephew's daughter. Thus, the correct answer is option B, 'No, because the man never placed the deed beyond his control.'

question: Question 31 Real Property - Rights in Land In 2000, the owner of a 100-acre tract prepared and duly recorded a subdivision plan called Happy Acres. The plan showed 90 one-acre lots and a ten-acre tract in the center that was designated "Future Public School." The owner published and distributed a brochure promoting Happy Acres which emphasized the proximity of the lots to the school property and indicated potential tax savings "because the school district will not have to expend tax money to acquire this property." There is no specific statute concerning the dedication of school sites. The owner sold 50 of the lots to individual purchasers. Each deed referred to the recorded plan and also contained the following clause: "No mobile home shall be erected on any lot within Happy Acres." A woman was one of the original purchasers from the owner. In 2006, the owner sold the remaining 40 lots and the ten-acre tract to a man by a deed which referred to the plan and contained the restriction relating to mobile homes. The man sold the 40 lots to individual purchasers and the ten-acre tract to a friend. None of the deeds from the man referred to the plan or contained any reference to mobile homes. The friend has announced his intention of erecting a fast food restaurant on the ten-acre tract, and the woman has filed an action to enjoin the friend. If the woman wins, it will be because

options.optionA: A. the woman has an equitable servitude concerning the use of the tract.
options.optionB: B. the woman, as a taxpayer, has legal interest in the use of the tract.
options.optionC: C. the woman is a creditor beneficiary of the owner's promise with respect to the tract.
options.optionD: D. the friend is not a bona fide purchaser.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Equitable servitudes, particularly the enforcement of restrictions on land use through deed provisions and subdivision plans.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The owner of the 100-acre tract Happy Acres created a subdivision plan with restrictions on mobile homes and designated a 10-acre tract for a future public school. The owner sold 50 lots to individuals, and each deed referenced the plan and contained the mobile home restriction. Later, the owner sold the remaining lots and the 10-acre tract to a man, who sold them to others without referencing the plan. A woman, one of the original purchasers, is seeking to enjoin a friend who bought the 10-acre tract from the man from erecting a fast food restaurant.
explanation.Rule_Application: To enforce an equitable servitude, there must be intent for the restriction to bind subsequent grantees, notice of the servitude, and a connection between the restriction and the land. The subdivision plan and deed language provide notice, and the restriction touches and concerns the land. Therefore, the equitable servitude is enforceable, and the woman may prevail in her injunction.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The woman will likely win her injunction based on the enforceable equitable servitude, which restricts the use of the 10-acre tract.

question: In 2000, the owner of a 100-acre tract prepared and duly recorded a subdivision plan called Happy Acres. The plan showed 90 one-acre lots and a ten-acre tract in the center that was designated "Future Public School." The owner published and distributed a brochure promoting Happy Acres which emphasized the proximity of the lots to the school property and indicated potential tax savings "because the school district will not have to expend tax money to acquire this property." There is no specific statute concerning the dedication of school sites. The owner sold 50 of the lots to individual purchasers. Each deed referred to the recorded plan and also contained the following clause: "No mobile home shall be erected on any lot within Happy Acres." A woman was one of the original purchasers from the owner. In 2006, the owner sold the remaining 40 lots and the ten-acre tract to a man by a deed which referred to the plan and contained the restriction relating to mobile homes. The man sold the 40 lots to individual purchasers and the ten-acre tract to a friend. None of the deeds from the man referred to the plan or contained any reference to mobile homes. One of the individual purchasers, who purchased his lot from the man, has placed a mobile home on it, and the woman brings an action against this purchaser to force him to remove it. The result of this action will be in favor of

options.optionA: A. the woman, because the restrictive covenant in her deed runs with the land.
options.optionB: B. the woman, because the presence of the mobile home may adversely affect the market value of her land.
options.optionC: C. the purchaser, because his deed did not contain the restrictive covenant.
options.optionD: D. the purchaser, because he is not a direct but a remote grantee of the owner.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Covenants running with the land at law, particularly the four elements required for their enforceability.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: A recorded subdivision plan and deeds referencing the plan, with one original purchaser bringing an action against another purchaser for violating a restrictive covenant.
explanation.Rule_Application: To be enforceable, a covenant must have intent to run with the land, notice, 'touch and concern' of the covenant to the land, and privity of estate. The recorded subdivision plan and deeds referencing it provide the necessary notice and privity of estate, and the restriction on mobile homes 'touches and concerns' the land.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the presence of all four elements, the restrictive covenant runs with the land, and the woman's action to enforce it will likely be successful, supporting option A.

question: In 2000, the owner of a 100-acre tract prepared and duly recorded a subdivision plan called Happy Acres. The plan showed 90 one-acre lots and a ten-acre tract in the center that was designated "Future Public School." The owner published and distributed a brochure promoting Happy Acres which emphasized the proximity of the lots to the school property and indicated potential tax savings "because the school district will not have to expend tax money to acquire this property." There is no specific statute concerning the dedication of school sites. The owner sold 50 of the lots to individual purchasers. Each deed referred to the recorded plan and also contained the following clause: "No mobile home shall be erected on any lot within Happy Acres." A woman was one of the original purchasers from the owner. In 2006, the owner sold the remaining 40 lots and the ten-acre tract to a man by a deed which referred to the plan and contained the restriction relating to mobile homes. The man sold the 40 lots to individual purchasers and the ten-acre tract to a friend. None of the deeds from the man referred to the plan or contained any reference to mobile homes. In 2007, the school board of the district in which Happy Acres is situated has voted to erect a new school on the ten-acre tract. In an appropriate action between the school board and the friend to determine title, the result will be in favor of

options.optionA: A. the friend, because the school board has been guilty of laches.
options.optionB: B. the friend, because his deed did not refer to the subdivision plan.
options.optionC: C. the school board, because the friend had constructive notice of the proposed use of the tract.
options.optionD: D. the school board, because there has been a dedication and acceptance of the tract.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Public dedication of land, specifically the requirements for effective dedication and acceptance, and their impact on title to the land.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The owner's subdivision plan and brochure indicated the ten-acre tract would be used for a public school, showing an expressed intent to dedicate the land. The school board's vote to erect a new school on the tract demonstrates an acceptance of the dedication.
explanation.Rule_Application: When there is both an expressed intent to dedicate land for public use and an acceptance of the dedication, title to the land passes to the public entity. In this scenario, the owner's initial dedication and the school board's subsequent acceptance transferred title to the school board.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the effective dedication and acceptance, the correct verdict would be in favor of the school board, supporting option D.

question: In 1960, the owner in fee simple of Barrenacres, a large, undeveloped tract of land, granted an easement to the Water District "to install, inspect, repair, maintain, and replace pipes" within a properly delineated strip of land twenty feet wide across Barrenacres. The easement permitted the Water District to enter Barrenacres for only the stated purposes. The Water District promptly and properly recorded the deed. In 1961, the Water District installed a water main which crossed Barrenacres within the described strip; the Water District has not since entered Barrenacres. In 1965, the landowner sold Barrenacres to a purchaser, but the deed, which was promptly and properly recorded, failed to refer to the Water District easement. The purchaser built his home on Barrenacres in 1965, and since that time he has planted and maintained, at great expense in money, time, and effort, a formal garden area which covers, among other areas, the surface of the twenty-foot easement strip. In 2006, the Water District proposed to excavate the entire length of its main in order to inspect, repair, and replace the main, to the extent necessary. At a public meeting, at which the purchaser was present, the Water District announced its plans and declared its intent to do as little damage as possible to any property involved. The purchaser objected to the Water District plans. The purchaser asked his attorney to secure an injunction against the Water District and its proposed entry upon his property. The best advice that the attorney can give is that the purchaser's attempt to secure injunctive relief will be likely to\

options.optionA: A. succeed, because the purchaser's deed from the landowner did not mention the easement
options.optionB: B. succeed, because more than forty years have passed since the Water District last entered Barrenacres.
options.optionC: C. fail, because the Water District's plan is within its rights.
options.optionD: D. fail, because the Water District's plan is fair and equitable.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Express easement in gross, specifically the rights and limitations of the holder to use the granted easement for the specified purposes.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The Water District was granted a 20-foot wide easement strip across Barrenacres for the purposes of installing, inspecting, repairing, maintaining, and replacing pipes. The purchaser built his home on Barrenacres and planted a garden area, including the easement strip, but the Water District has not entered the property since 1961.
explanation.Rule_Application: The Water District, as the holder of an express easement in gross, is entitled to reasonable use of the easement according to the granted purposes. Since the proposed excavation and maintenance of the water main are within the scope of the original grant, the Water District's actions constitute reasonable use.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The purchaser's attempt to secure injunctive relief will likely fail, as the Water District's plan is within its rights as the holder of the express easement in gross, supporting option C.

question: A landowner was the owner of a large subdivision. A purchaser became interested in purchasing a lot but could not decide between Lot 40 and Lot 41. The price and fair market value of each of those two lots was $5,000. The purchaser paid the landowner $5,000, which the landowner accepted, and the landowner delivered to the purchaser a deed which was properly executed, complete, and ready for recording in every detail except that the space in the deed for the lot number was left blank. The landowner told the purchaser to fill in either Lot 40 or Lot 41 according to his decision and then to record the deed. The purchaser visited the development the next day and completely changed his mind, selecting Lot 25. He filled in Lot 25 and duly recorded the deed. The price of Lot 25 and its fair market value was $7,500. Immediately upon learning what the purchaser had done, the landowner brought an appropriate action against the purchaser to rescind the transaction. If the landowner loses, the most likely basis for the judgment is that

options.optionA: A. The landowner's casual business practices created his loss.
options.optionB: B. the need for certainty in land title records controls.
options.optionC: C. the agency implied to complete the deed cannot be restricted by the oral understanding.
options.optionD: D. the recording of the deed precludes any questioning of its provisions in its recorded form.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Implied agency in property law, specifically the authority of an agent to act on behalf of a principal in the absence of explicit instructions.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The landowner delivered a properly executed deed to the purchaser, leaving blank the space for the lot number. The landowner instructed the purchaser to fill in either Lot 40 or Lot 41. The purchaser instead filled in Lot 25, which was not one of the agreed-upon options, and recorded the deed.
explanation.Rule_Application: In the absence of explicit instructions, an implied agency may arise, granting the agent (purchaser) authority to act on behalf of the principal (landowner). Here, the landowner's act of leaving the lot number blank and instructing the purchaser to fill it in created an implied agency, allowing the purchaser to complete the deed as they saw fit.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the implied agency created by the landowner's actions, the purchaser's filling in Lot 25 and recording the deed would likely be upheld, supporting option C.

question: A tenant occupied an apartment in a building owned by a landlord. She paid rent of $125 in advance each month. During the second month of occupancy, the tenant organized the other tenants in the building as a tenants' association, and the association made demands of the landlord concerning certain repairs and improvements the tenants wanted. When the tenant tendered rent for the third month, the landlord notified her that rent for the fourth and subsequent months would be $200 per month. The tenant protested and pointed out that all other tenants paid rent of $125 per month. Thereupon, the landlord gave the required statutory notice that the tenancy was being terminated at the end of the third month. By an appropriate proceeding, the tenant contests the landlord's right to terminate. If the tenant succeeds, it will be because

options.optionA: A. a periodic tenancy was created by implication.
options.optionB: B. the doctrine prohibiting retaliatory eviction is part of the law of the jurisdiction.
options.optionC: C. the $200 rent demanded violates the agreement implied by the rate charged to other tenants.
options.optionD: D. the law implies a term of one year in the absence of any express agreement.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Retaliatory eviction in landlord-tenant law, specifically the prohibition on a landlord terminating a tenancy in response to a tenant's exercise of their legal rights.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The landlord increased the tenant's rent and served a notice of termination after the tenant formed a tenants' association to advocate for repairs and improvements.
explanation.Rule_Application: Retaliatory eviction laws prohibit a landlord from terminating a tenancy in response to a tenant's exercise of their legal rights, such as organizing a tenants' association. This protection is designed to prevent landlords from intimidating or punishing tenants for exercising their rights.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the landlord's actions were in direct response to the tenant's formation of the tenants' association, the tenant has a strong claim that the termination is retaliatory and therefore invalid, supporting option B.

question: The owner in fee simple of Brownacre conveyed Brownacre by quitclaim deed to her daughter who paid no consideration for the conveyance. The deed was never recorded. About a year after the delivery of the deed, the grantor decided that this gift had been ill-advised. She requested that her daughter destroy the deed, which the daughter dutifully and voluntarily did. Within the month following the destruction of the deed, the grantor and the daughter were killed in a common disaster. Each of the successors in interest claimed title to Brownacre. In an appropriate action to determine the title to Brownacre, the probable outcome will be that

options.optionA: A. The grantor was the owner of Brownacre, because the daughter was a donee and therefore could not acquire title by quitclaim deed.
options.optionB: B. The grantor was the owner of Brownacre, because title to Brownacre reverted to her upon the voluntary destruction of the deed by the daughter.
options.optionC: C. The daughter was the owner of Brownacre, because her destruction of the deed to Brownacre was under the undue influence of the grantor.
options.optionD: D. The daughter was the owner of Brownacre, because the deed was merely evidence of her title, and its destruction was insufficient to cause title to pass back to the grantor.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Transfer of legal title in land, specifically the requirements for a valid conveyance of property, and the effect of a deed's destruction on title ownership.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The grantor in fee simple conveyed Brownacre to her daughter by quitclaim deed with no consideration, which was delivered but never recorded. The grantor later requested the deed's destruction, which the daughter voluntarily did. Both parties died in a common disaster, with each successor claiming title.
explanation.Rule_Application: To transfer legal title, the grantor must execute and deliver the deed to the grantee, demonstrating intent to pass title. Physical possession of the deed is not required. Once conveyed, title can only be reversed by the grantee executing and delivering a new deed back to the grantor, not by destroying the original deed.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The daughter was the owner of Brownacre, because the quitclaim deed's execution, delivery, and acceptance transferred title, and its subsequent destruction was insufficient to revert title to the grantor, supporting option D.

question: A landowner contracted to sell a tract of land to a painter by general warranty deed. However, at the closing the painter did not carefully examine the deed and accepted a quitclaim deed without covenants of title. The painter later attempted to sell the land to a purchaser, who refused to perform because the landowner had conveyed an easement for a highway across the land before the painter bought the property. The painter sued the landowner for damages. Which of the following arguments will most likely succeed in the landowner's defense?

options.optionA: A. The existence of an easement does not violate the contract.
options.optionB: B. The mere existence of an easement which is not being used does not give rise to a cause of action.
options.optionC: C. The painter's cause of action must be based on the deed and not on the contract.
options.optionD: D. The proper remedy is rescission of the deed.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Doctrine of merger, where a contract merges into a deed, destroying any unmemorialized provisions.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: A painter purchased land from a landowner via a quitclaim deed without covenants of title. The painter later discovered a pre-existing easement and sued the landowner for damages.
explanation.Rule_Application: As the painter accepted the quitclaim deed, the sale contract merged into the deed, eliminating any provisions not included in the deed. Thus, the painter's claim must arise from the deed, rather than the original contract.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The landowner's most successful defense is that the painter's cause of action must be based on the deed, not on the contract, supporting option C.

question: A landlord leased a warehouse building and the lot on which it stood to a tenant for a term of ten years. The lease contained a clause prohibiting the tenant from subletting his interest. Can the tenant assign his interest under the lease?

options.optionA: A. Yes, because restraints on alienation of land are strictly construed.
options.optionB: B. Yes, because disabling restraints on alienation of land are invalid.
options.optionC: C. No, because the term "subletting" includes "assignment" when the term is employed in a lease.
options.optionD: D. No, because even in the absence of an express prohibition on assignment, a tenant may not assign without the landlord's permission.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Assignment vs. sublease in property law, and the validity of restrictions on alienation of leased property
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The lease agreement prohibits subletting, but does not explicitly mention assignment. This distinction is crucial in determining whether the tenant can assign his interest under the lease.
explanation.Rule_Application: A landlord may place limits on alienation within the terms of the lease, but such restrictions will be strictly construed according to their explicit terms. In this case, the restriction only prohibits subletting, and thus, assignment is not explicitly prohibited.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Therefore, the correct answer is A, as the tenant can assign his interest under the lease, since the lease only prohibits subletting, not assignment.

question: An owner in fee simple laid out a subdivision of 325 lots on 150 acres of land. He obtained governmental approval (as required by applicable ordinances) and, between 1998 and 2000, he sold 140 of the lots, inserting in each of the 140 deeds the following provision: "The grantee, for himself and his heirs, assigns and successors, covenants and agrees that the premises conveyed herein shall have erected thereon one single-family dwelling and that no other structure (other than a detached garage, normally incident to a single-family dwelling) shall be erected or maintained; and, further, that no use shall ever be made or permitted to be made than occupancy by a single family for residential purposes only." Because of difficulty encountered in selling the remaining lots for single family use, in January 2001, the owner advertised the remaining lots with prominent emphasis: "These lots are not subject to any restriction and purchasers will find them adaptable to a wide range of uses." Suppose that the owner sold 50 lots during 2001 without inserting in the deeds any provision relating to structures or uses. A businessman purchased one of the 50 lots and proposes to erect a service station and to conduct a retail business for the sale of gasoline, etc. A woman purchased a lot from a man who had purchased from the owner in 1998, and the deed had the provision that it quoted in the fact situation. The woman brings suit to prevent the businessman from erecting the service station and from conducting a retail business. In the litigation between the woman and the businessman, which of the following constitutes the best defense for the businessman?

options.optionA: A. The owner's difficulty in selling with provisions relating to use establishes a change in circumstances which renders any restrictions which may once have existed unenforceable.
options.optionB: B. Enforcement of the restriction, in view of the change of circumstances, would be an unreasonable restraint on alienation.
options.optionC: C. Since the proof (as stated) does not establish a danger of monetary loss to the woman, the woman has failed to establish one of the necessary elements in a cause of action to prevent the businessman from using his lots for business purposes.
options.optionD: D. The facts do not establish a common building or development scheme for the entire subdivision.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Equitable servitudes, particularly the enforcement of restrictions on land use by subsequent grantees in a subdivision
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The owner laid out a subdivision of 325 lots, selling 140 lots between 1998 and 2000 with a deed restriction on use, while selling 50 lots in 2001 without restrictions. The woman purchased a lot from a man who had bought from the owner in 1998, with a deed containing the restriction, and seeks to prevent the businessman from using his lot for business purposes.
explanation.Rule_Application: An equitable servitude requires intent for the restriction to be enforceable, notice to subsequent grantees, and the restriction to touch and concern the land. The restriction on the first 140 lots meets these requirements, but it only binds owners of those lots and does not apply to the remaining lots, including the businessman's lot.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The businessman's best defense is that the restriction does not apply to his lot, as there is no common building or development scheme for the entire subdivision that would bind all 325 lots, supporting option D.

question: A landowner owned Brightacre (a tract of land) in fee simple. He conveyed it "to [his friend], his heirs and assigns; but if [his cousin] shall be living thirty years from the date of this deed, then to [his cousin], his heirs and assigns." The limitation "to [his cousin], his heirs and assigns" is

options.optionA: A. valid, because the cousin's interest is a reversion.
options.optionB: B. valid, because the interest will vest, if at all, within a life in being.
options.optionC: C. valid, because the cousin's interest is vested subject to divestment.
options.optionD: D. invalid.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The Rule Against Perpetuities (RAP) in property law, specifically its application to executory interests and the vesting of interests within a life in being.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The conveyance grants Brightacre to the friend, but with a conditional limitation that it will pass to the cousin if he is alive thirty years from the date of the deed.
explanation.Rule_Application: The RAP voids interests that would vest outside of a life in being plus 21 years. Since the cousin's interest will vest, if at all, within his own lifetime, it satisfies the RAP and is valid.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The limitation 'to [his cousin], his heirs and assigns' is valid because the cousin's interest will vest, if at all, within a life in being, supporting option B.

question: A testator owned Hilltop in fee simple. By his will, he devised as follows: "Hilltop to such of my grandchildren who shall reach the age of 21; and by this provision I intend to include all grandchildren whenever born." At the time of his death, the testator had three children and two grandchildren. Courts hold such a devise valid under the common-law Rule Against Perpetuities. What is the best explanation of that determination?

options.optionA: A. All of the testator's children would be measuring lives.
options.optionB: B. The rule of convenience closes the class of beneficiaries when any grandchild reaches the age of 21.
options.optionC: C. There is a presumption that the testator intended to include only those grandchildren born prior to his death.
options.optionD: D. There is a subsidiary rule of construction that dispositive instruments are to be interpreted so as to uphold interests rather than to invalidate them under the Rule Against Perpetuities.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The Rule Against Perpetuities (RAP) in property law, specifically its application to vested remainders, contingent remainders, and executory interests.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The devise in question leaves Hilltop to grandchildren who reach the age of 21, with the testator intending to include all grandchildren whenever born. At the time of the testator's death, there are three children and two grandchildren.
explanation.Rule_Application: The RAP voids interests that would vest outside of a life in being plus 21 years. In this case, all of the testator's children would be measuring lives, ensuring that the devise would not vest outside of the permitted time frame.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: As the devise does not violate the RAP, the court would hold it valid, supporting option A.

question: A testator owned Hilltop in fee simple. By his will, he devised as follows: "Hilltop to such of my grandchildren who shall reach the age of 21; and by this provision I intend to include all grandchildren whenever born." At the time of his death, the testator had three children and two grandchildren. Which of the following additions to or changes in the facts above would produce a violation of the common-law Rule Against Perpetuities?

options.optionA: A. A posthumous child was born to the testator.
options.optionB: B. The testator's will expressed the intention to include all afterborn grandchildren in the gift.
options.optionC: C. The instrument was an inter vivos conveyance rather than a will.
options.optionD: D. The testator had no grandchildren living at the time of his death.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The common-law Rule Against Perpetuities (RAP) and its application to vested remainders, contingent remainders, and executory interests.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The testator devised Hilltop to such grandchildren who would reach the age of 21, intending to include all grandchildren whenever born. At the time of death, the testator had three children and two grandchildren.
explanation.Rule_Application: To determine if the RAP applies, we need to identify the type of interest created and whether it would vest outside of a life in being plus 21 years. In this case, the interest is an executory interest, and it would not violate the RAP as it would vest within the 21-year period. However, if the instrument were an inter vivos conveyance rather than a will, it could potentially create an interest that vests outside of the 21-year period, violating the RAP.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The correct answer is option C, as an inter vivos conveyance rather than a will would potentially produce a violation of the RAP.

question: A seller and a buyer execute an agreement for the sale of real property on September 1, 2001. The jurisdiction in which the property is located recognized the principle of equitable conversion and has no statute pertinent to this problem. Assume for this question only that the buyer dies before closing, there being no breach of the agreement by either party. Which of the following is appropriate in most jurisdictions?

options.optionA: A. The buyer's heir may specifically enforce the agreement.
options.optionB: B. The seller has the right to return the down payment and cancel the contract.
options.optionC: C. Death terminates the agreement.
options.optionD: D. Any title acquired would be unmarketable by reason of the buyer's death.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Equitable conversion in real estate law, specifically the doctrine's effect on ownership and risk between contracting and closing.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The buyer and seller executed an agreement for the sale of real property. The buyer dies before closing, but there was no breach of the agreement by either party.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under the doctrine of equitable conversion, once the contract is signed, the risk of loss for any damage to the property that occurs before the closing, and is not the seller's fault, falls on the buyer. This means the buyer equitably owns the property, and their estate would be required to pay for that property at the closing.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the doctrine of equitable conversion, the correct outcome would be that the buyer's heir may specifically enforce the agreement, supporting option A.

question: A landowner holds title in fee simple to a tract of 1,500 acres. He desires to develop the entire tract as a golf course, country club, and residential subdivision. He contemplates forming a corporation to own and to operate the golf course and country club; the stock in the corporation will be distributed to the owners of lots in the residential portions of the subdivision, but no obligation to issue the stock is to ripen until all the residential lots are sold. The price of the lots is intended to return enough money to compensate the landowner for the raw land, development costs (including the building of the golf course and the country club facilities), and developer's profit, if all of the lots are sold. The landowner's market analyses indicate that he must create a scheme of development that will offer prospective purchasers (and their lawyers) a very high order of assurance that several aspects will be clearly established: I. Aside from the country club and golf course, there will be no land use other than for residential use and occupancy in the 1,500 acres. II. The residents of the subdivision will have unambiguous rights and access to the club and golf course facilities. III. Each lot owner must have an unambiguous right to transfer his lot to a purchaser with all original benefits. IV. Each lot owner must be obligated to pay annual dues to a pro rata share (based on the number of lots) of the club's annual operating deficit (whether or not such owner desires to make use of club and course facilities). Of the following, the greatest difficulty that will be encountered in establishing the scheme is that

options.optionA: A. any judicial recognition will be construed as state action which, under current doctrines, raises a substantial question whether such action would be in conflict with the Fourteenth Amendment.
options.optionB: B. the scheme, if effective, renders title unmarketable.
options.optionC: C. one or more of the essential aspects outlined by the landowner will result in a restraint on alienation.
options.optionD: D. there is a judicial reluctance to recognize an affirmative burden to pay money in installments and over an indefinite period as a burden which can be affixed to bind future owners of land.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Restrictive covenants and servitudes in property law, particularly the enforceability of affirmative covenants to pay annual dues.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The landowner plans to develop a golf course, country club, and residential subdivision, where lot owners will have access to club facilities, be obligated to pay annual dues, and have unambiguous rights to transfer lots.
explanation.Rule_Application: Affirmative covenants, such as the obligation to pay annual dues, can be challenging to enforce because they require future landowners to perform a specific action, which may be seen as an unreasonable restraint on the use of the land. This can make it difficult to establish the scheme.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The greatest difficulty in establishing the scheme is the judicial reluctance to recognize an affirmative burden to pay money in installments and over an indefinite period as a burden which can be affixed to bind future owners of land, supporting option D.

question: A father gave his son a power of attorney containing the following provision: "My attorney is specifically authorized to sell and convey any part or all of my real property." The son conveyed part of his father's land to a buyer by deed in the customary form containing covenants of title. The buyer sues the father for breach of a covenant. The outcome of the buyer's suit will be governed by whether

options.optionA: A. deeds without covenants are effective to convey realty.
options.optionB: B. the jurisdiction views the covenants as personal or running with the land.
options.optionC: C. the buyer is a bona fide purchaser.
options.optionD: D. the power to "sell and convey" is construed to include the power to execute the usual form of deed used to convey realty.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The scope of authority granted to an agent under a power of attorney, particularly the authorization to execute documents and convey real property.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The son, acting as the father's attorney under a power of attorney, conveyed part of the father's land to a buyer by a deed containing covenants of title. The buyer is now suing the father for breach of a covenant.
explanation.Rule_Application: A power of attorney grants an agent specific authority to act on behalf of the principal. In this case, the power of attorney explicitly authorized the son to sell and convey the father's real property. The scope of this authority includes the execution of the customary form of deed used to convey realty, which would include covenants of title.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The outcome of the buyer's suit will depend on whether the power of attorney granted the son the authority to execute the deed, which is the case here. Therefore, the correct answer is D, as the power to sell and convey is construed to include the power to execute the usual form of deed used to convey realty.

question: An owner held 500 acres in fee simple absolute. In 1990 the owner platted and obtained all required governmental approvals of two subdivisions of 200 acres each. In 1990 and 1991 commercial buildings and parking facilities were constructed on one, Royal Center, in accordance with the plans disclosed by the plat for each subdivision. Royal Center continues to be used for commercial purposes. The plat of the other, Royal Oaks, showed 250 lots, streets, and utility and drainage easements. All of the lots in Royal Oaks were conveyed during 1990 and 1991. The deeds contained provisions, expressly stated to be binding upon the grantee, his heirs and assigns, requiring the lots to be used only for single-family, residential purposes until 2015. The deeds expressly stated that these provisions were enforceable by the owner of any lot in the Royal Oaks subdivision. At all times since 1979, the 200 acres of Royal Center have been zoned for shopping center use, and the 200 acres in Royal Oaks have been zoned for residential use in a classification which permits both single-family and multiple-family use. In an appropriate attack upon the limitation to residential use by single families, if the evidence disclosed no fact in addition to those listed above, the most probable judicial resolution would be that

options.optionA: A. there is no enforceable restriction because judicial recognition constitutes state action which is in conflict with the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.
options.optionB: B. there is no enforceable restriction because of the owner's conflict of interest in that he did not make the restriction applicable to the 100 acres he retains.
options.optionC: C. the restriction in use set forth in the deeds will be enforced at the suit of any present owner of a lot in Royal Oaks residential subdivision.
options.optionD: D. any use consistent with zoning will be permitted but that any such uses that are in conflict with the restrictions in the deeds will give rise to a right to damages from the owner or the owner's successor.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Equitable servitudes, specifically the enforceability of restrictions on land use in a residential subdivision.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: A plat of a residential subdivision, Royal Oaks, was recorded and all lots were conveyed with deeds containing use restrictions for single-family, residential purposes until 2015. The restrictions were intended to be binding on grantees, their heirs, and assigns, and were enforceable by any lot owner in the subdivision.
explanation.Rule_Application: For an equitable servitude to be enforceable, three elements must be established: intent for the restriction to bind subsequent grantees, notice of the servitude, and that the restriction touches and concerns the land. In this scenario, the recorded deeds provide notice, the restriction touches and concerns the land, and the intent is clear from the deed language.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that all three elements for an equitable servitude are present, the restriction will be enforced at the suit of any present owner of a lot in Royal Oaks residential subdivision, supporting option C.

question: A seller and a buyer entered into a written contract for the sale and purchase of land which was complete in all respects except that no reference was made to the quality of title to be conveyed. Which of the following will result?

options.optionA: A. The contract will be unenforceable.
options.optionB: B. The seller will be required to convey a marketable title.
options.optionC: C. The seller will be required to convey only what he owned on the date of the contract.
options.optionD: D. The seller will be required to convey only what he owned at the date of the contract plus whatever additional title rights he may acquire prior to the closing date.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The warranty of marketable title implied in land sales contracts, which requires the seller to provide a title free of encumbrances.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: A written contract exists for the sale and purchase of land, but it does not specify the quality of title to be conveyed.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under the warranty of marketable title, the seller is obligated to provide a title that is free of encumbrances, such as mortgages, restrictions, covenants, easements, or other limiting provisions not explicitly identified in the contract.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the implied warranty of marketable title, the seller will be required to convey a marketable title, supporting option B.
